sp.p: Or perchance some will be so charitable to give us suck'd bones from stinking breaths, and rotten teeth, or greasie scraps from fowl hands; But go wife, prithy bid my Steward send me 500. pounds more, or let it alone, I will run on the score, and pay my losings at a lump.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: No dear Husband, play no more.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p:
How! not play any more say you, shall I break good Company with sitting out; Besides, it is a question whether I have power to leave off, now I have once begun; for Play is Witch-craft, it inchants temperance, prudence, patience, reason and judgment, and it kicks away time, and bids him
go as an old bald-pated fellow as he is, also it chains the life with fears, cares and griefs of losing to a pair of Cards and set of Dice.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: For Heaven sake pitty me! If you consider not your self.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious:
sp.p: Can you think a Husband considers his wife, when he forgets, or regards not himself, when all love is self-love, for a man would have his Wife to be loving and chaste for his honours sake, to be thrifty for his profit sake, to be patient for quiet sake, to be cleanly, witty and beautifull for his pleasure sake, and being thus, he loves her; For if she be false, unkind, prodigal, froward sluttish, foolish, and ill-favoured, he hates her.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorant.
sp.p: But if a Husband loves his wife, he will be carefull to please her, prudent for her, subsistence, industrious for her convenience, valiant to protect her, and conversable to entertain her, and wise to direct and guide her.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: To rule and govern her, you mean wife.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: Yes, but a Husbands follies will be but corrupt Tutors, and ill Examples for a wife to follow; wherefore dear Husband, play no more, but come amongst the effeminate Societie, you will finde more pleasure at less charges.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: Well wife, You shall perswade me for this time.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: I thank you Husband.

div.head: Scene 12.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Orphant, and Foster Trusty, as two Pilgrims.

sp.speaker: FOster Trusty.
sp.p: My childe, you were best sit and rest your self, you cannot chose but be very weary, for we have travelled a great journey to day.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: Truly I am as fresh, and my spirits are as lively, as if I had not trod a step to day.

sp.speaker: Foster Trusty.
sp.p: I perceive love can work miracles.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: Are not you Father a weary?

sp.speaker: Foster Trusty.
sp.p: It were a shame for me to be weary, when you are not; But my childe, we must change these Pilgrims weeds, when we are out of our own Countrey; as when we are in Italy, otherwise we cannot pretend to stay in the Venetian Armie, but must travel as Pilgrims do to Ierusalem: But it were best we put our selves into Beggers garments until we come into the Armie, for fear we should be strip'd by Thieves; for I have heard, Thieves will strip Travellers, if their cloths be not all ragges.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: 'Tis true, and Thieves as I have heard, will rob Pilgrims soonest, finding many good Pilladge, wherefore we will accoutre our selves like to ragged Beggers.

div.head: Scene 13.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Bashfull, as in a melancholly humour, and Reformer her Woman.

sp.speaker: REformer.
sp.p: Lord Madam! I hope you are not seriously troubled for being out of Countenance.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Yes truely.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: What? as to make you melancholly!

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Yes, very melancholly, when I think I have made my self a scorn, and hath indangered my reputation.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Your reputation! Heaven bless you, but your life is so innocent, harmless, chaste, pure and sweet, and your actions so just and honest, as all the Divels in Hell cannot indanger your reputation.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: But spitefull tongues, which are worse than Divels, may hurt my reputation.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: But spite cannot have any thing to say.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Spite will lye, rather than not speak, for envie is the mother to spite, and slander is the Mid-wife.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Why, what can they say?

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: They will say I am guilty of some immodest act, or at least thoughts, or else of some heynous and horrid crime, otherwise I could not be ashamed, or out of countenance, if I were innocent.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: They cannot say ill, or think ill, but if they could, and did, what are you the worse, as long as you are innocent.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Yes truely, for I desire to live in a pure esteem, and an honourable respect in every breast, and to have a good report spoke on me, since I deserve no other.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: There is an old saying, that opinion travels without a Passe-port, and they that would have every ones good opinion, must live in every mans age: But I am very confident, there is none lives or dyes without censures, or detraction; even the Gods themselves, that made man, hath given man power and free will to speak, at least to think what they will; That makes so many Athiests in thought, and so many several factions by disputation, and since the Gods cannot, or will not be free from censures, why should you trouble your self with what others say, wherefore pray put off this indiscreet and troublesome humour, for if you would not regard censure, you would be more confident.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: I will do what I can to mend.

div.head: Scene 14.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Orphant, and Foster Trusty, like two poor Beggers.

sp.speaker: FOster.
sp.p: Childe, you must beg of every one that comes by, otherwise we shall not seem right Beggers.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: If our necessities were according to our outward appearance, we were but in a sad condition; for I shall never get any thing by begging, for I have neither learn'd the tone, nor the Beggers phrase to more pity or charity.

sp.speaker: Foster Trusty.
sp.p: Few Beggers move pity, they get more by importunity, than by their oratorie, or the givers charity.

div.stage: She goeth to them and beggs.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: Noble Gentlemen, pity the shiftless youth, and infirm old age that hath no means to live, but what compassionate charity will bestow.

sp.speaker: 1. Gentleman.
sp.p: You are a young boy, and may get your living by learning to work.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: But my Father being very old, is past working, and I am so young, as I have not arrived to a learning degree of age, and by that time I have learn'd to get my living, my Father may be starved for want of food.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: Why, your Father may beg for himself whilst you learn to work.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: My Father's feeble legs can never run after the flying speed of pityless hearts, nor can he stand so long to wait for conscience aimes, nor knock so hard to make devotion hear.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: I perceive you have learn'd to beg well, though not to work, and because you shall know my devotion is not deaf, there is something for your Father and you.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: Nay, faith boy, thou shalt have some of the scraps of my charity to, there is for thee.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: Heaven bless you; and grant to you, all your good desires.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: Honourable Lady, let the mouth of necessity suck the breast of your charity to feed the hungry Beggers.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Away you rogue, a young boy and beg! You should be strip'd, whip'd, and set to work.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: Alas Madam, naked poverty is alwaies under the lash of miserie, which forceth us to work in the quarries of stony hearts, but we finde the mineral so hard, as we cannot get out enough to build up a livelyhood.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Imploy your selves upon some other work then.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: Good Sir relieve a poor begger.

sp.speaker: Trades-man.
sp.p: Faith boy, I am so poor, as I want relief my self; yet of what I have, thou shalt share with me; there is a peny of my two pence, which is all I have, and Heaven do thee good with it.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: I perceive poverty pities poverty, as feeling the like miserie, where riches is cruel, and hard-hearted, not knowing what want is.

sp.speaker: Foster Trusty.
sp.p: I perceive wit can work upon every thing, and can form it self into what shape it please, and thy wit playes the Begger so well, as we needed not to have stored our selves from our own Stocks, but have lived upon the Stocks of others.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: But if all Stocks were as insipid as the Ladies, we should have starved, if we had not brought sap from our own home; But Father, I am weighed down with the peny the poor Trades-man gave me.

sp.speaker: Foster Trusty.
sp.p: Why, it is not so heavy.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: It is so heavy, as it burthens my conscience, and I shall never be at ease, not be able to travel any farther, until I have restored the peny to the giver again.

sp.speaker: Foster Nurse.
sp.p: How should we do that, for it is as hard and difficult to find out that man, as to finde out the first cause of effects.

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: Well, I will play the Philosopher, and search for him.

sp.speaker: Foster Nurse.
sp.p: But if you should meet him, perchance you will not know he was he.

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: O yes, for his extraordinary charity made me take particular notice of him.

div.stage: Enter the Trades-man as returning back.

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: Most charitable and â€”

sp.speaker: Trades-man.
sp.p: What boy, wouldst thou have the other peny,

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: Most Noble Sir, I have received from a bountifull hand, a summe of money, and since you were so charitable to divide the half of your store to me, so I desire I may do the like to you.

sp.speaker: Trades-man.
sp.p: No boy, keep it for thy self, and thy old Father; I have a Trade, and shall get more.

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: Pray take it for luck-sake, otherwise I shall never thrive.

sp.speaker: Trades-man.
sp.p: Faith I finde boy, thou art not as most of the World are; the more riches they get, the more covetous they grow.

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: Sir, pray take this.

sp.speaker: Trades-man.
sp.p: What do you give me here, a piece of Gold?

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Trades-man.
sp.p: That were extortion, to take a pound for a peny.

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: No, it is not extortion, since I can better space this pound now, than you could your peny, when you gave it me; wherefore it is but justice,

sp.speaker: Trades-man.
sp.p:
Well, I will keep it for thee, and when you want it, come to
me again, and you shall have it: I live in the next street, at the signe of the Holy-lamb.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: Pray make use of it, for I may chance never to see you more.

div.head: Scene 15.
div.stage: Enter Sir Studious and the Lady Ignorance his Wife.

sp.speaker: SIr P. Studious.
sp.p: Faith Wife, with sipping of your Gossiping-cups, I am half drunk.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: Lord Husband! There were some of the Ladies that drank twice as much as you did, and were not drunk, and to prove they were not drunk, was that they talked as much before they drunk, as after; For there was such a confusion of words, as they could not understand each other, and they did no more, when they had drunk a great quantity of Wine.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: That was a signe they were drunk, that they talked less, but how chance that you drank so little.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: Truly, Wine is so nauseous to my taste, and so hatefull to my nostrils, as I was sick when the cup was brought to me.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: I know not what it was to you, but to me it was pleasant, for your Ladies were so gamesome, merry and kind, as they have fired me with amorous love ever since.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Madam, the Lady Wagtail, and other Ladies, have sent to know if your Ladyship were within, that they might come and wait upon you.

div.stage: Sir Peaceable Studious chiks the maid under the Chin, and kisses her.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious
sp.p: Faith Nan, thou art a pretty wench.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: What Husband? Do you kiss my maid before my face.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: Why not Wife, as well as one of your sociable Ladies in a frollick, as you kiss me, I kiss Nan.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: So, and when Nan kisses your Barber, he must kiss me.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: Right, this is the kissing frollick, and then comes the stricking frollick, for you strike Nan, Nan gently strikes me, and I justly beat you, and end the frollicks with a â€”

div.stage: Enter the Lady Wagtail, and other Ladies of the Societie, with the Lady Amorous.

sp.speaker: Lady Wagtail.
sp.p: What? a man and his Wife dully alone together! Fie for shame.

sp.speaker: Lady Amorous.
sp.p: Lawfull love is the dullest and drouziest companion that is, for Wives are never thought fair, nor Husbands witty.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: Your Ladyship is learned in loves Societies.

sp.speaker: Lady Amorous.
sp.p: Yes that I am, for I have observed, that if there be a match'd company, every man having a woman, their conversation is dull, every mans tongue whispering in his Mistriss eare, whilst the women are mute, listening to that which is whispered unto them; but let there be but one man amongst a company of women, and then their tongues runs races, striving with each other, which shall catch that one man, as the only prize, when the weaker wits runs themselves straite out of breath.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: And must not one man run against them all.

sp.speaker: Lady Amorous.
sp.p: O yes? and many times his wit beats them all.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: Faith Lady? They must not be such strong winded wits as yours is, which is able to beat a dozen Masculine wits out of the field.

sp.speaker: Lady Amorous.
sp.p: You are pleased to give me a complement.

sp.speaker: Lady Wagtaile.
sp.p: The merry God have mercy on you? What makes you so melancholly.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: I am not well to day.

sp.speaker: Lady Wagtail.
sp.p: If you are troubled with melancholly vapours, arising from crude humours, you must take as soon as you wake after your first sleep, a draught of Wormwood-wine, then lye to sleep again, and then half an hour before you rise, drink a draught of Jelly-broth, and after you have been up an hour and half, eate a White-wine-caudle, then a little before a dinner, take a Toste and Sack, and at your meals, two or three good glasses of Clarret-wine; as for your Meats, you must eate those of light digestion, as Pheasant, Partridges, Cocks, Snipes, Chickens, young Turkies, Pea-chickens and the like; And in the After-noon, about four or five a clock, you must take Naples-bisket dip'd in Ippocrass, which helps digestion much, and revives the spirits, and makes one full of discourse, and not only to discourse, but to discourse wittily, and makes one such good company, as invites acquaintance, and ties friendship.

div.stage: The whilst the Lady Wagtail talks to the Lady Ignorance, the eyes her Husband, who seems to court the Lady Amorous.

sp.speaker: Lady Amorous.
sp.p: Faith I will tell your Wife what you say.

sp.speaker: Lady Wagtail.
sp.p: That is fowl play, and not done like one of the Society, especially when my Lady is not well.

sp.speaker: Lady Amorous.
sp.p: What? Is she sick! I lay my life she hath eate too much Branne Sturgeon, or Sammon without muskadine or Sack, or N â€¢ ats-tongues, Bakon and Anchoves, Caveare, or Lobsters, without Rhenish-wines, or Oysters, or Sausages without Clarret-wine, or hath she eaten Potatoe-pies without dates, Ringo-roots, Marrow and Chestnuts, have you not? i saith confess.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: No indeed.

sp.speaker: Lady Amorous.
sp.p: Why? I hope you have not taken a surfeit of White-meats, those childish meats, or with Water-grewel, Ponado, Barley-grevvel, those Hodge-podgely meats.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: Neither.

sp.speaker: Lady Amorous.
sp.p:
Why, then you have over-heated your self with dancing
or fretting and vexing your self at your ill fortune at Cards; or your Tayler hath spoiled some Gown, or your Coach-man was out of the way when you would go abroad; is it not so.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Lady Amorous.
sp.p: Why? Then your Husband hath crost some design, or hath angered you some other way.

div.stage: They all laugh, and speak at one time; She blushes, She blushes.

sp.speaker: Lady Wagtail.
sp.p: Faith Amorous, thou hast found it out! Sir Peaceable Studious you are to be chidden to anger your Wife; wherefore tell us how you did anger her, when you did anger her, and for what you did anger her.

sp.speaker: Sir. P. Studious.
sp.p: Dear, sweet, sine, fair Ladies! be not so cruel to me, as to lay my Wives indisposition to my charge.

sp.speaker: Lady Wagtaile.
sp.p: But we will, and we will draw up an Accusation against you, unless you confess, and ask pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: Will you accuse me without a Witness?

sp.speaker: Lady Wagtail.
sp.p: Yes, and condemne you too.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: That were unjust! if Ladies could be unjust.

sp.speaker: Lady Amorous.
sp.p: O Madam! we have a witness? her blushing is a sufficient witness to accuse him; Besides, her melancholly silence will help to condemn him.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: Pardon me Ladies, for when any of our Sex are offended, or angered, whether they have cause or not, they will rail louder than Ioves thunder.

sp.speaker: Lady Amorous.
sp.p: So will you in time.

sp.speaker: Lady Wagtail.
sp.p: Let us jumble her abroad; Come Madam! we will put you out of your dull humour.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: No Madam? Pray excuse me to day; in truth I am not well.

sp.speaker: Lady Amorous.
sp.p: No, let us let my Lady alone, but let us take her Husband, and tutour him

sp.speaker: Sir. P. Studious.
sp.p: Ladies, give me leave to praise my self, and let my self, and let me tell you? I am as apt a Scholar, as ever you met with, and as willing to learn.

sp.speaker: Lady Amorous.
sp.p: Farewell Madam, we will order Sir P. Studious, and try what disposition he is of, and how apt to be instructed.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: Pray do Madam, he promiseth well.

div.head: Scene 16:
div.stage: Enter Foster Trusty, and the Lady Orphant.

sp.speaker: LAdy Orphant.
sp.p: Now we are come into the Armie, how shall we demean our selves like poor Beggers.

sp.speaker: Foster Trusty.
sp.p:
By no means, for though you beg well, yet you will never get
what you come for with begging, for there is an old saying, that although all charity is love, yet all love is not charity.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: It were the greatest charity in the World, for him to love me; for without his love, I shall be more miserable than poverty can make me.

sp.speaker: Foster Trusty.
sp.p: But poverty is so scorned and hated, that no person is accepted which she presents; Nay, poverty is shunn'd more than the Plague.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: Why? it is not infectious.

sp.speaker: Foster Trusty.
sp.p: Yes faith, for the relieving of necessity, is the way to be impoverished.

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: But their rewards are the greater in Heaven.

sp.speaker: Foster Trusty.
sp.p: 'Tis true, but their Estates are less on earth.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: But blessings are more to be desired than wealth.

sp.speaker: Foster Trusty,
sp.p: Well? Heaven bless us, and send us such fortune, that our long journey may prove successfull, and not profitless, and because Heaven never gives blessings, unless we use a prudent industry; you shall put your self into good clothes, and I will mix my self with his followers and servants, and tell them, as I may truely, that you are my Son, for no mans Son but mine you are, was so importunate, as you would never let me rest, until I brought you to see the Lord Singularity, and they will tell him, to let him know his fame is such, as even young children adore him, taking a Pilgrimage to see him, and he out of a vain-glory will desire to see you.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: But what advantage shall I get by that.

div.stage: Enter the Lord Singularity, and many Commanders attending him.

sp.speaker: Foster Trusty.
sp.p: Peace! here is the General.

sp.speaker: Commander.
sp.p: The enemie is so beaten, as now they will give us some time to breath our selves.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: They are more out of breath than we are, but the States are generous enemies, if they give them leave to fetch their wind, and gather strength again.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: Father, stand you by, and let me speak.

div.stage: She goeth to the General, and speaks to him.

sp.speaker: Lord General.
sp.p: From whence comest thou boy?

sp.speaker: Lord Orph.
sp.p: From your native Countrey.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: Cam'st thou lately?

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: I am newly arrived.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: Pray how is my Countrey, and Countrey-men, live they still in happy peace, and flourishing with plenty.

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: There is no noise of war, or fear of famine.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: Pray Iove continue it.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: It is likely so to continue, unless their pride and luxurie be gets a factious childe, that is born with war, and fed with ruine.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: Do you know what faction is?

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: There is no man that lives, and feels it not, the very thoughts are factious in the mind, and in Rebellious passions arises warring against the soul.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: Thou canst not speak thus by experience boy, thou art too young, not yet a mans Estate.

sp.speaker: Lady Orphant.
sp.p: But children have thoughts, and said to have a rational soul, as much as those that are grown up to men; but if souls grow as bodies doth, and thoughts increases with their years, then may the wars within the mind be like to School-boys quarrels, that falls out for a toy, and for a roy are friends.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: Thou speakest like a Tutour, what boyish thoughts so ever thou hast; but tell me boy? what mad'st thee travel so great a journey.

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: For to see you.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: To see me boy!

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: Yes, to see you Sir; for the Trumpet of your praise did sound so loud, it struck my ears, broke open my heart, and let desire forth, which restless grew until I travelled hither.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: I wish I had merits to equal thy weary steps, or means for to reward them:

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: Your presence hath sufficiently rewarded me.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: Could I do thee my service boy?

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: A bounteous favour you might do me Sir?

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: What is that boy?

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: To let me serve you, Sir.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: I should be ingratefull to refuse thee, chose thy place.

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: Your Page, Sir, if you please.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: I accept of thee most willingly.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: But Sir? may not this boy be a lying, couzening, flattering dissembling, treacherous boy.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: Why Captain, there is no man that keeps many servants, but some are lyers, and some treacherous, and all flatterers; and a Master receives as much injurie from each particular, as if they were joyned in one.

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: I can bring none that will witness for my truth, or be bound for my honesty, but my own words.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: I desire none, boy, for thy tongue sounds so sweetly, and thy face looks so honestly, as I cannot but take, and trust thee.

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: Heaven bless your Excellence, and fortune prosper you, for your bounty hath been above my hopes, and equal to my wishes.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: VVhat is thy name?

sp.speaker: Lady Orph.
sp.p: Affectionata my Noble Lord.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: Then follow me Affectionata.

div.head: Scene 17.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Bashfull, and Reformer her woman.

sp.speaker: PAge.
sp.p: Madam, there was a Gentleman gave me this Letter, to deliver to your Ladyships hands.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: A Letter I pray Reformer open it, and read it, for I will not receive Letters privately.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: The superscription is for the Right Honourable, the Lady Bashfull; these present.

p.hi: Since I have had the honour to see you, I have had the unhappiness to think my self miserable, by reason I am deprived of speech, that should plead my suit, but if an affectionate soul, chasle thoughts, lawfull desires, and a fervent heart can plead without speech, let me beg your favour to accept of me for your servant; and what I want in Language, my industrious observance, and diligent service shall supply; I am a Gentleman, my breeding hath been according to my birth, and my Estate is sufficient to maintain me according to both; As for your Estate, I consider it not, for were you so poor of fortunes goods, as you had nothing to maintain you, but what your merit might challenge out of every purse; yet if you were mine, I should esteem you richer than the whole World, and I should love you, as Saints love Heaven, and adore you equal to a Dietie; for I saw so much sweetness of nature, nobleness of soul, purity of thoughts, and innocency of life, thorough your Bashfull countenance, as my soul is wedded thereunto, and my mind so restless; therefore, that unless I may have hopes to injoy you for my Wife; I shall dye,

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Now Reformer, what say you to this Letter?

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: I say it is a good honest, hearty affectionate Letter, and upon my life, it is the Gentleman I commended so; he that looked so seriously on you; and your Ladyship may remember, I said he viewed you, as if he would have looked you thorough, and you made answer, that you wished he could, that he might see you were not so simple, as your behaviour made you appear, and now your wish is absolved.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: VVhat counsel will you give me in this cause?

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: VVhy? write him a civil answer.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: VVhy should I hold corespondence with any man, either by Letter, or any other way, since I do not intend to marry.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Not marry?

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: No, not marry.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: VVhy so?

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Because I am now Mistriss of my self, and fortunes, and have a free liberty; and who that is free, if they be wise, will make themselves slaves, subjecting themselves to anothers humour, unless they were fools, or mad, and knew not how to chose the best and happiest life.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: You will change this opinion, and marry, I dare swear.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Indeed I will not swear, but I think I shall not, for I love an easie, peaceable and solitary life, which none injoys but single persons; for in marriage, the life is disturbed with noise and company, troublesome imployments, vex'd with crosses, and restless with cares; Besides, I could not indure to have Parteners to share of him, whom my affections had set a price upon, or my merit, or beauty, or wealth, or vertue had bought.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: So, I perceive you would be jealouse, if you were married.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Perchance I might have reason, but to prevent all inconveniences, and discontents, I will live a single life.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Do what likes you best, for I dare not perswade you any way, for fear my advice should not prove to the best.

sp.speaker: FOster Trusty.
sp.p: Now you are placed according to your desire, what wil you command me to do?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Dear Foster Father, although I am loth to part from you, yet by reason I shall suffer in my estate, I must intreat you to return home, for my Nurse your wife, hath not skill to manage that fortune my Father left me; for she knows not how to let Leases, to set Lands, to receive Rents, to repair Ruines, to disburst Charges, and to order those affairs as they should be ordered, which your knowledge, industry and wisdom will dispose and order for my advantage.

sp.speaker: Foster Trusty.
sp.p: But how if you be discovered.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Why, if I should, as I hope I shall not, yet the Lord Singularity is so noble a person, as he will neither use me uncivily, not cruelly.

sp.speaker: Foster Trusty.
sp.p: All that I fear is, if you should be discovered, he should use you too civilly.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: That were to use me rudely, which I am confident he will not do, and I am confident that you do believe I will receive no more civillity (if you call it so) than what honour will allow and approve of.

sp.speaker: Foster Trusty.
sp.p: But jealousie will creep into the most confident breasts sometimes, yet I dare trust you, though I fear him.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I hope there is no cause to fear him, or doubt me, wherefore dear Father, let us go and settle our affairs here, that you may return home to order those there.

div.head: Scene 19.
div.stage: Enter Sir Peaceable Studious, and the Lady Ignorance his Wife, She being undrest, her mantle about her, as being not well.

sp.speaker: SIr P. Studious.
sp.p: In truth wife, it is a great misfortune you should be sick this Term-time, when the Society is so much increast, as it is become a little Common-wealth.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: If there be so many, they may the better spare me.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: 'Tis true, they can spare your company, but how can you want their companies.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: You shall be my Intelligencer of their pastimes.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: That I will wife, but it will be but a dull recreation, only to hear a bare relation.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: As long as you partake of their present pleasures, and pleasant actions, what need you take care for me.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: Yes, but I must in Justice, for since you have cured me of a studious Lethargie, I ought to do my indeavour to divert your melancholly; and there is no such remedy as the Society; wherefore dear wife, fling off this melancholly sickness, or sick melancholly, and go amongst them; for surely your sickness is in your mind, not in your body.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: What, do you cry Wife, who hath angered you?

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: Why you.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: Who, I anger'd you I why I would not anger a woman, no, not my Wife for the whole World, If I could possible avoid it, which I fear cannot be avoided, for if I should please out of your Sex, I should be sure to displease another: â€” But that is my comfort, it is not my fault; but dear Wife, how have I offended you.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: Why did you kiss my maid before my face.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: Why did you perswade me.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: Did I perswade you to kiss my maid.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: No, but you did perswade me to be one of the Society and there is kissing, and I thought it was as well to kiss your maid before your face, as a sociable Lady before your face.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: And why do you make love to the Ladies, since I suffer none to make love to me.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: No, for if you did, I would fling you to death, to be imbraced in his cold arms; Besides, those actions that are allowable and seemly, as manly in men, are condemned in women, as immodest, and unbecoming, and dishonourable; but talking to you, I shall miss of the pleasant sports, and therefore, if you will go, come, the Coach is ready.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: No, I will not go ã€ˆâ€¦ã€‰ u.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: Then I will go without you.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: No, pray Husband go no more thither.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: How! not to go? nor to go no more, would you desire me from that which you perswaded me to; Nay, so much as I could never be quiet, disturbing my harmless studies, and happy mind, crossing my pleasing thoughts with complaining words, but I perceive you grow jealouse, and now you are acquainted, you have no more use of me, but would be glad to quit my company, that you may be more free abroad.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: No Husband, truely I will never go abroad, but will inancor my self in my own house, so you will stay at home, and be as you were before, for I see my own follies, and am ashamed of my self, that you should prove me such a fool.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: Do you think me so wise and temperate a man, as I can on a sudden quit vain pleasures, and lawfull follies.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: Yes, or else you have studied to little purpose.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: Well, for this day I will stay at home, and for the futuretime I will consider.

div.head: Scene 20.
div.stage: Enter two Servants of the Generals.

sp.speaker: I. Servant.
sp.p: This boy that came but the other day, hath got more of my Lords affection, than we that have served him this many years.

sp.speaker: 2. Servant.
sp.p: New-comers are alwaies more favoured than old waiters; for Masters regards old Servants no more, than the Imagerie in an old suit of Hanging, which are grown threed-bare with time, and out of fashion with change; Besides, new Servants are more industrious and diligent than old; but when he hath been here a little while, he will be as lazie as the rest, and then he will be as we are.

sp.speaker: I. Servant.
sp.p: I perceive my Lord delights to hear him talk, for he will listen very a tentively to him, but when we offer to speak, he bids us to be silent.

sp.speaker: 2. Servant.
sp.p: I wonder he should, for when we speak, it is with gravity, and our discourse is sententious, but his is meer squibs.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Gentlemen, my Lord would have one of you to come to him.

sp.speaker: I. Servant.
sp.p: Why, I thought you could supply all our places, for when you are with him, he seems to have no use of us.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: It shall not be for want of will, but ability, if I do not serve him in every honest office.

sp.speaker: I. Servant.
sp.p: So you will make some of us knaves.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I cannot make you knaves, unless you be willing to be knaves your selves.

sp.speaker: 2. Servant.
sp.p: What, do you call me knave?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I do not call you so.

sp.speaker: 2. Servant.
sp.p: Well, I will be revenged, if I live.

div.head: Scene 21.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Bashfull, and Reformer her woman.

sp.speaker: REformer.
sp.p: Madam, I have inquired what this Sir Serious Dumb is, and 'tis said he is one of the finest Gentlemen in this Kingdom, and that his valour hath been proved in the wars, and that he is one that is very active and dexterous in all manly exercises, as riding, fencing, vaulting, swimming, and the like, Also that he is full of inventions, and a rare Poet, and that he hath a great Estate, only that he is dumb, and hath been so this twelve years and upwards.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Reformer. What makes you so industrious to inquire after him, surely thou art in love within.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: In my conscience I liked him very well, when he was to see you.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: The truth is, he cannot weary you with words, nor anger you in his discourse, but pray do not inquire after him, nor speak of him; for people will think I have some designe of marriage.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: I shall obey you, Madam.

div.head: Scene. 22.
div.stage: Enter the Lord Singularity, and Affectionata.

sp.speaker: LOrd Singularity.
sp.p: Affectionata, Thou art one of the diligent'st boys that had.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: How can I be otherwise, Sir, since you are the Governour of my soul, that commands the Fort of my passion, and the Castle of my imaginations, which are the heart, and the head.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Do you love me so much?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: So well my Lord, as you are the archetectour of my mind, the foundation of my thoughts, and the gates of my memories, for your will is the form, your happiness the level, and your actions the treasurie.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Thy wit delights me more, than thy flattery perswades: for I cannot believe a boy can love so much; Besides, you have not served me so long, as to beget love.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I have loved you from my infancy, for as I suck'd life from my Nurses breast, so did I Love from fames, drawing your praises forth, as I did milk, which nourished my affections.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: I shall strive; boy, to require thy love.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: To requite, is to return love for love.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: By Heaven? I love thee, as a Father loves a son.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Then I am blest,

sp.speaker: 1. SOuldier.
sp.p: What is this boy that our General is so taken with.

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier,
sp.p: A poor Begger-boy!

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: Can a poor Begger-boy merit his affections?

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: He is a pretty boy, and waites very diligently.

sp.speaker: 1. Souldier.
sp.p: So doth other boys, as well as he, but I believe he is a young Pimp, and carries, and conveys Love-letters.

sp.speaker: 2. Souldier.
sp.p: Like enough to, for boys are strangely crafty in those imployments, and so industrious, as they will let no times nor opportunities slip them, but they will find waies to deliver their Letters and messages.

div.head: Scene 24.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Bashfulls Page, and Sir Serious Dumb, who gives a Note to the Page to read.

sp.speaker: PAge.
sp.p: Sir, I dare not direct you to my Lady, as you desire me in this Note, and if I should tell her, here is a Gentleman that desired to visit her, she would refuse your visit.

div.stage: Dumb gives the young Page four or five pieces of Gold.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: I will direct you to the room wherein my Lady is, but I must not be seen, nor confess I shewed you the way.

div.stage: Page, and Sir Serious Dumb Exeunt

div.head: Scene 25.
div.stage: Enter the Lord Singularity, and Affectionata.

sp.speaker: LOrd Singularity.
sp.p: Come Affectionata, sit down and entertain me with thy sweet discourse, which makes all other company troublesome, and tedious to me, thine only doth delight me.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: My Noble Lord? I wish the plat-form of my brain were a Garden of wit, and then perchance my tongue might present your Excellencies with a Posie of flowery Rhethorick, but my poor brain is barren, wanting

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Thou hast an eloquent tongue, (and a gentle soul.)

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: My Noble Lord, I have hardly learn'd my native words, much less the eloquence of Language, and as for the souls of all mankind, they are like Common-wealths, where the several vertues, and good graces are the Citizens therein, and the natural subjects thereof; but vices and follies, as the thievish Borderers, and Neighbour-enemies, which makes inrodes, factions, mutinies, intrudes and usurps Authority, and if the follies be more than the good graces, and the vices too strong for the vertues, the Monarchy of a good life falls to ruine, also it is indangered by Civil-wars amongst the passions.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: What passions indangers it most?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Anger, malice, and despair.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Were you never angry?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I am of too melancholly a nature, to be very angry.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Why? are melancholly persons never angry?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Very seldom, my Lord, for those that are naturally melancholly, doth rather grieve, than fret, they sooner wast into sighes, than fly about with fury; more tears flows thorough their eyes, than words pass thorough their lips.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Why should you be melancholly?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Alas, nature hath made me so; Besides, I find there is not much reason to joy, for what we love, perchance it loves not us, and if it doth, we cannot keep it long, for pleasures passeth like a dream; when pains doth stay, as if eternal were.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Thou art composed with such harmonie, as thy discourse is as delightfull musick, wherein the soul takes pleasure.

div.head: Scene 26.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Bashfull, Sir Serious Dumb following her, where Reformer her Woman meets them.

sp.speaker: REformer.
sp.p: Madam, now the Gentleman is here, you must use him civilly, and not strive to run away from him, wherefore pray turn, and entertain him.

div.stage: The Lady Bashfull turns to him, but is so out of countenance, and trembles so much, as she cannot speak, but stands still and mute; All the while he fixes his eyes upon her.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Pray speak to him, Madam, and not stand trembling, as if you were like to fall.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: My spirits is seized on by my bashfull and innocent fears, insomuch, as they have not strength to support my body without trembling.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Sweet Madam, try not speak to him?

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p:
Honourable Sir? give me leave to tell you, that my bashfullness
doth smother the senses and reason in my brain, and chokes the words in my throat I should utter, but pray do not think it proceeds from crimes, but an imperfection of nature, which I have strove against, but cannot as yet rectifie
sp.stage: Sir Serious Dumb Civily bows to her, and then gives Reformer his Table-book to read.

p.hi: He hath writ here, that had his tongue liberty to speak, all that he could say, would be so far below, and inferiour to what might be said in your praise, as he should not adventure to presume to speak.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: I will presume to break my brain, but I will invent some ways to be rid of his company.

div.head: Scene 27.
div.stage: Enter the General, and sits in a melancholly posture. Enters Affectionata, and stands with a sad countenance.

sp.speaker: LOrd Singularity.
sp.p: What makes thee look so sad, my boy?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: To see you sit so melancholly.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Clear up thy countenance, for its not a deadly melancholly, though it is a troublesome one.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: May I be so bold to ask the cause of it.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: The cause is, a cruel Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Have you a Mistriss, and can she be cruel?

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: O! Women are Tyrants, they daw us on to love, and then denies our suits.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Will not you think me rude, If I should question you?

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: No, for thy questions delights me more, than my Mistriss denials grieves me.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Then give me leave to ask you, whether your suit be just?

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Just, to a Lovers desires.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: What is your desire?

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: To lye with her.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: After you have married her?

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Marry her saist thou, I had rather be banish'd from that Sex for ever, than marry one, and yet I love them well.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Why have you such an adversion to marriage, being lawfull and honest.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Because I am affraid to be a Cuckold!

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Do you think there is no chaste women?

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Faith boy, I believe very few, and those that are men, knows not where to find them out, for all that are not married, professes chastity, speaks soberly, and looks modestly, but when they are martyed, they are more wild than Bachalins, far worse than Satyres, making their Husbands horns far greater than a Stags, having more branches sprouts thereon.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: And doth he never cast those horns?

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Yes, if he be a Widower, he casts his horns, only the marks remains, otherwise he bears them to his grave.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: But put the case you did know a woman that was chaste; would not you marry her?

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: That is a question not to be resolved, for no man can be resolved, whether a womam can be chaste or not.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Why do you sighe, my boy?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Because all women are false, or thought to be so, that wise men dares not trust them.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: But they are fools, that will not try, and make use of them, if they can have them; wherefore I will go, and try my Mistriss once again.

div.head: Scene. 28.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Ignorance, and her Maid.

sp.speaker: LAdy Ignorance.
sp.p: What a noise they make below, they will disturb my Husbands study; go and tell those of my Servants, that I will turn them away for their carelesness, as that they cannot place, set, or hold things sure, but let them fall to makÃ© such a noise.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I shall.

sp.speaker: Lady Ignorance.
sp.p: It shall be my study how to order my house without noise, wherefore all my Servants shall be dumb, although not deaf, and I will take none, but such as have corns on their feet, that they may tread gently, and all my Houshold-vessel shall be of wood, for wood makes not such a noise when it chance to fall, or is hit against a wall, as metal doth, which rings like bells, when it is but touched, neither will I have Houshold-vessels of Earth, for earthen-pots, pans and the like; when they fall and break, sounds as if a stonewall fell.

div.head: Scene 29.
div.stage: Enter the General, and three or four Commanders.

sp.speaker: GEneral.
sp.p: On my soul Gentlemen, the boy is an honest boy, and no wayes guilty of this you tax him for.

sp.speaker: Commanders.
sp.p: Pardon us, my Lord, for giving your Excellence notice that the States are jealouse of him for a Spie, but we do not any wayes accuse him.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: Will the States examine him, say you?

sp.speaker: Commanders.
sp.p: So we hear, my Lord.

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen, pray leave me for this time, and I will take care the boy shall be forth-coming, whensoever the State shall require him.

sp.speaker: Commanders.
sp.p: Your Lordships humble Servants â€”

sp.speaker: General.
sp.p: A Spie, it cannot be, for he is neither covetous, nor malicious, revengefull, nor irreligious, but I will try him.

div.head: Scene 30.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Bashfulls Chamber-maid, and Mrs. Reformer her Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: CHamber-maid.
sp.p: Mrs. Reformer, pray tell me who that handsome Gentleman is, which follows my Lady about?

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: He is one that is Noble, and Rich, and is in love with my Lady.

sp.speaker: Chamber-maid.
sp.p: Truly it is the strangest way of wooing, that ever was, for my Lady goeth blushing out of one room into another, and he follows her at the heels: In my conscience my Lady is ashamed to sit down, or to bid him leave her company, and surely they must needs be both very weary of walking, but sure he will leave her, when it is time to go to bed.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: It is to be hoped he will.

div.stage: Enter the Lady Bashfull, and Sir Serious Dumb following her.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Madam, you will tire your self and the Gentleman, with walking about your house, wherefore pray sit down.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: What! To have him gaze upon my face.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Why, your face is a handsome face, and the owner of it is honest, wherefore you need not be ashamed, but pray rest your self.â€”

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Pray perswade him to leave me, and then I will.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Sir, my Lady intreats you to leave her to her self.

div.stage: Sir Serious Dumb writes then, and gives Reformer his Table-book to read.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: He writes he cannot leave you, for if his body should depart, his soul will remain still with you.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: That will not put me out of countenance, because I shall not be sensible of its presence, wherefore I am content he should leave his soul, so that he will take his body away.

div.stage: He writes, and gives Reformer the Book.

sp.speaker: Reformer reads.
sp.p: He writes, that if you will give him leave once a day to see you, that he will depart, and that he will not disturb your thoughts, he will only wait upon your person for the time he lives, he cannot keep himself long from you.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: But I would be alone.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: But if he will follow you, you must indure that with patience, you cannot avoid.

div.stage: Sir Serious Dumb goeth to the Lady Bashfull, and kisseth her hand, and Ex.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: You see he is so civil, as he is unwilling to displease you.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Rather than I will be troubled thus; I will go to some other parts of the World.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: In my conscience, Madam, he will follow you, wheresoever you go.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: But I will have him shut out of my house.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Then he will lye at your gates, and so all the Town will take notice of it.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Why so, they will howsoever, by his often visits.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: But not so publick.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Affectionata. Thou must carry a Letter from me, to my Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: You will not marry her, you say.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Then pardon me, my Lord, for though I would assist your honest love by any service I can do, yet I shall never be so base an Instrument, as to produce a crime.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Come, come, thou shalt carry it, and I will give thee 500. pounds for thy service.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Excuse me, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: I will give thee a thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I shall not take it, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: I will give thee five thousand, nay ten thousand pounds.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I am not covetous, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: I will make thee Master of my whole Estate, for without the assistance, I cannot injoy my Mistriss, by reason she will trust none with our Loves, but thee.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Could you make me Master of the whole World, it could not tempt me to do an action base, for though I am poor, I am honest, and so honest, as I cannot be corrupted, or bribed there-from.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: You said you loved me?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Heaven knows I do above my life, and would do you any service that honour did allow of.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: You are more scrupulous than wise.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: There is an old saying, my Lord, that to be wise, is to be honest.

div.head: Scene 32.
div.stage: Enter Sir Peaceable Studious, and meets his Ladies maid.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: Where is your Lady?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: In her Chamber, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir P. Studious.
sp.p: Pray her to come to me?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

div.stage: Enter another Maid to the first.

sp.speaker: 1. Maid.
sp.p: Lord, Lord! What a creature my Master is become; since he fell into his musing again, he looks like a melancholy Ghost, that walks in the shades of Moon-shine, or if there be no Ghost, such as we fancie, just such a one seems her, when a week since, he was as fine a Gentleman as one should see amongst a thousand.

sp.speaker: 2. Maid.
sp.p: That was because he kiss'd you, Nan.

sp.speaker: 1. Maid.
sp.p: Faith it was but a dull clownish part, to meet a Maid that is not ill-favoured, and not make much of her, who perchance have watch'd to meet him, for which he might have clap'd her on the cheek, or have chuck'd her under the chin, or have kiss'd her, but to do or say nothing, but bid me call my Lady, was such a churlish part? Besides, it seemed neither manly, gallantly, nor civilly.

sp.speaker: 2. Maid.
sp.p: But it shewed him temperate and wise, not minding such frivilous and troublesome creatures as women are.

sp.speaker: 1. Maid.
sp.p: Prithy, it shews him to be a miserable, proud, dull fool.

sp.speaker: 2. Maid.
sp.p: Peace, some body will hear you, and then you will be turn'd away.

sp.speaker: 1. Maid.
sp.p: I care not, for it they will not turn me away, I will turn my self away, and seek another service, for I hate to live in the house with a Stoick.

div.head: Scene 33.

sp.speaker: AFfectionata.
sp.p: By your face, Sir, there seems a trouble in your mind, and I am restless until I know your griefs.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: It is a secret I dare not trust the aire with!

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I shall be more secret than the aire, for the aire is apt to divulge by retorting Ecohes back, but I shall be as silent as the Grave.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: But you may be tortured to confess the truth.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: But I will not confess the truth, if the confession may any wayes hurt, or disadvantage you; for though I will not belye truth by speaking falsely, yet I will conceal a truth, rather than betray a friend. Especially, my Lord and Master: But howsoever, since your trouble is of such concern, I shall not with to know it, for though I dare trust my self, yet perchance you dare not trust me, but if my honest fidelity can serve you any wayes, you may imploy it, and if it be to keep a secret, all the torment that nature hath made, or art invented, shall never draw it from me.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Then let me tell thee, that to conceal it, would damn thy soul.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Heaven bless me! But sure, my Lord, you cannot be guilty of such sins, that those that doth but barely hear, or know them, shall be damned.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul,
sp.p: But to conceal them, is to be an Actor.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: For Heaven sake then keep them close from me, if either they be base or wicked, for though love prompt me to inquire, hoping to give you ease in bearing part of the burthen, yet Heaven knows, I thought my love so honourable placed on such a worthy person, and guiltless soul, as I might love and serve without a scandal, or a deadly sin.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Come, you shall know it.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I'l rather stop my ears with death.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Go, thou art a false boy.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: How false a boy howsoever you think me, I have an honest soul and heart that is ready to serve you in any honest way, but since I am deceived, and couzened into love by false reports, finding the best of man-kind basely wicked, and all the World so bad, that praise nothing good, and strives to poyson vertue, I will inancor my self, and live on Antidotes of prayers, for fear of the infection.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: And I will not you pray for me?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I cannot chose, my Lord, for gratitude inforces me; First, because I have loved you, next, because I have served you; and give me leave to kiss your hand, and then there drop some tears at my departure.

div.stage: Weeping kneels down, and kisses her hand.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Rise, you must not go away until you have cleared your self from being a spie.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I fear no accusations,

div.head: THE SECOND PART OF LOVES ADVENTURES.
EPILOGUE.
div.l: NOble Spectators, you have spent this day;
Not only for to see, but judge our Play:
Our Authoress sayes, she thinks her Play is good,
If that her Play be rightly understood;
If not, 'tis none of her fault, for she writ
The Acts, the Scenes, the Language and the Wit;
Wherefore she sayes, that she is not your Debtor,
But you are hers, until you write a better;
Of even terms to be she understands
Impossible, except you clap your hands.

div.head: Scene 1.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Bashfulls Chamber-maid, and Mrs. Reformer her woman.

sp.speaker: REformer.
sp.p: This dumb Lower is the most diligent'st servant that ever was, and methinks my Lady is somewhat more confident than she was; for she will sit and read whilst he sits by.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Doth she read to him?

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: No, she reads to herself.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: There comes abundance of Gallants to visit my Lady every day, and they have all one answer, that is, she is not willing to receive visits, and they all go civilly away, unless Sir Humphry Bold and he rails horribly.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: I have received from several Gentlemen, above 20. Letters a day, and as fast as they come, she makes me burn them.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: But she reads them first.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: No, I read them to her.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: And doth she answer all those Letters?

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: She never answered one in her life, and I dare swear, she never will.

div.stage: The Lady Bashfull calls, as within another Room.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Madam!â€”

div.head: Scene 2.
div.stage: Enter the Lord Singularity, and Affectionata.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity,
sp.p: Affectionata. Hast thou forgiven me my fault of doubting of thy vertue, so much as to put it to a Tryal.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: My Noble Lord, have you forgiven my facility and wavering, faith that could so easily, and in so short a time believe you could be wicked, although you did accuse your self.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Nay Affectionata, I did not accuse my self, though I did try thee.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Then I have committed a treble fault through my mistake, which requires a treble forgiveness.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Thou art so vertuous, thou canst not commit a fault, and therefore needs no forgiveness.

div.head: Scene 3.
div.stage: Enter the Lady VVagtail, and Sir Humphry Bold.

sp.speaker: SIr Humpry Bold.
sp.p: Madam, You have been pleased to profess a friendship to me, and I shall desire you will do a friendly part for me.

sp.speaker: Lady Wagtail.
sp.p: Any thing that lyes in my power, good Sir Humphry Bold.

sp.speaker: Sir Humphry Bold.
sp.p: Then pray, Madam, speak to the Lady Bashfull in my behalf, that I may be her Husband.

sp.speaker: Lady Wagtail.
sp.p: I will Sir Humphry, but she is bashfull, yet I was there Yesterday, and she entertained me indifferently well, but seemed to be wonderfull coy; but howsoever I will do my poor indeavour, Sir Humphry.

sp.speaker: Sir Humphry Bold.
sp.p: Pray do, Madam.

div.head: Scene. 4.
div.stage: Enter Affectionata, walking in a melancholly posture; his Hat pulled over his brows, and his arms inter-folded; To himentens the Lord Singularity.

sp.speaker: LOrd Singularity
sp.p: My Affectionata, Why walks thou so melancholly?

div.stage: He pulls of his Hat to his Lord, and Bows.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: The cause is not that I lye under an aspersion, by reason I lye not under a crime; But truly, my Lord, I am troubled that I am threatened to be tormented, for I would not willingly indure pain, though I could willingly receive death; but as for the aspersions, I am no wayes concerned; for I make no question, but my honest life, my just actions, and the truth of my words, will so clear me at the last, as I shall appear as innocent to the World, as Angels doth in Heaven.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Comfort your self, for I will rather suffer death, than you shall suffer pain.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Heaven defend you, my Lord, whatsoever I suffer, Ex.

div.head: Scene 5.
div.stage: Enter the Lady VVagtail, and Mistriss Reformer.

sp.speaker: LAdy Wagtail.
sp.p: Pray Mistriss Reformer, be Sir Humphry Bold's friend to thy Lady, and I protest to thee, he shall be thy friend, as long as he and you live, and I do not see any reason your Lady should refuse him; for he is both as proper and stout a man, as any is living this day in the Land.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Indeed Madam, I dare not mention it to my Lady, for she is so adverse against marriage, as she takes those for her enemies as doth but mention it.

sp.speaker: Lady Wagtail.
sp.p: Then surely she is not a woman, for there is none of the efseminate Sex, but takes it for a disgrace to live an old maid, and rather than dye one, they will marry any man that will have them; and the very fear of not marrying, is so terrible to them, as whilst they are so young, as they are not fit to make wives, they will miserably cast away themselves to the first that makes a proffer, although they be poor, base or mean, rather than venture to try out their fortunes.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: But my Lady is not of that humour.

sp.speaker: Lady Wagtail.
sp.p: Come, come, I know thou canst perswade thy Lady if thou wouldst, and if you will, Sir Humphry Bold will give thee 500 l. to buy thee a Husband, for thou hast lived too long a maid I faith.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: I am not a maid, Madam, I am a widow.

sp.speaker: Lady Wagtail.
sp.p: What, a musty widow!

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: I know not whether I am musty, but I am a widow.

sp.speaker: Lady Wagtail.
sp.p: Let mee tell thee, that it is as great a disgrace to live a widow, as an old maid; wherefore take thee 500 l. to get thee a second Husband.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Truly I would not sell my Lady for all the World, much less, for 500 l. neither would I marry again, if I were young, and might have my choyce.

sp.speaker: Lady Wagtail.
sp.p: Lord bless me, and send me out of this house, least it should infect me; for let me tell thee, were my Husband dead to morrow, I would marry the day after his Funeral, if I could get any man to marry me, and so I would serve 20. Husbands one after another.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Your best way were to have 20. Husbands at one time, so that your Ladyship might not be a day without.

sp.speaker: Lady Wagtail.
sp.p: O fie! If women might have twenty Husbands, they would have no room for courtly Servants; but prithy help Sir Humphry Bold, and take his offer, and let me speak with the Lady my self.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: That your Ladyship cannot at this time, for my Lady is not well.

sp.speaker: Lady Wagtail.
sp.p: Then pray remember my most humble service, and tell her, I will come to morrow, and if she be sick, I will talk her well.

sp.speaker: Reformer.
sp.p: Dead you would talk her, for thou hast an endless tongue; Oh! what man is so miserable that is her Husband.

sp.speaker: 1. COmmander.
sp.p: It is reported that our Generals Page hath behaved himself so handsomly, spoke so wittily, defended his cause so prudently, declared his innocence so clearly, and carried his business so wisely, as the Venetian States have not only quitted him freely, but doth applaud him wonderfully, extolls him highly, and offers him any satisfaction for the injurie and disgrace that hath been done him; but he only desires, that the man that had accused him, which man, was one of the Generals men, should be pardoned, and not punished.

sp.speaker: 2. Commander.
sp.p: I hope our General is well pleased, that his beloved boy is not only cleared, but applauded.

sp.speaker: 1. Commander.
sp.p: O! He doth nothing but imbrace him, and kiss him, as if he were his only son, yet he did gently chide him that he asked pardon for his accusers; for said he, if all false accusers should be pardoned, no honest man would escape free form censure.

sp.speaker: 3. Commander.
sp.p: But I hear the States have given order to our General to meet the Turkes again, for it is reported by intelligences that they have recruited into a numerous body.

sp.speaker: 2. Commander.
sp.p: Faith I think the Turkes are like the tale of the Gyant, that when his head was cut off there rise two in the place.

sp.speaker: 1. Commander.
sp.p: I think they are like the vegetable that is named threefold, the more it is cut the faster it growes.

sp.speaker: 3. Commander.
sp.p: I would the Devil had them for me.

sp.speaker: 2. Commander.
sp.p: We do what we can to send them to Hell; but whether they will quit thee, I cannot tell.

div.head: Scene. 7.
div.stage: Enter the Lord General, and Affectionata.

sp.speaker: LOrd Singularity.
sp.p: My Affectionata I wonder you could suffer an accusation so patiently knowing you were accused falsly.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: The clearnesse of my innocency needed not the fury of a violent passion to defend it, neither could passion have rectified an injury.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Tis true, yet passion is apt to rise in defence of innocency, and honour.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: And many times passion (my Lord) destroye; the life in striving to maintaine the truth, and defend the innocent; but I find a passionate sorrow that your Lordship must go to indanger your life in the warrs again.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: The warrs is pastime to me, for I hate idlenesse, and no imployment pleases me better than fighting, so it be in a good cause, but you shall stay.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Why my Lord, are you weary of my service?

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Know I am carefull of thy safety, thy rest and peace, for shouldst thou not come near danger, yet the very tragical aspect will terrefie thee to death, thou art of so tender a nature, so soft and sweet a disposition.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Truly my Lord, if you leave me behind you, the very fear of your life will kill me, where if your Lordyship will let me go, love will give me courage.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Then let me tell you, you must not go, for I have adopted you my Son, and I have setled all my Estate upon thee, where, if I am killed, you shall be my Heir, for I had rather vertue should inherit my Estate than birth, yet I charge thee take my Name upon thee, as well as my Estate unto thee.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: My noble Lord, I should be prouder to bear your name, than to be Master of the whole World, but I shall never be so base to keep my self in safety, in hope of your Estate, wherefore must intreat your leave to go with you.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: I will not give you leave, but command you to the contrary, which is to stay.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: I cannot obey you in this, for love will force me to run after you.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: I will have you lash'd, if you offer to go.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Stripes cannot stay me!

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: I will have you tyed, and kept by force.

sp.speaker: fectionata.
sp.p: By Heaven, my Lord, i'l tear my flesh, and break my bones to get lose, and if I have not legs to run, i'l creep thorough the Earth like worms, for though I shall move but slowly, yet it will be a satisfaction to my soul, that I am travelling after you,

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Affectionata, You anger me very much.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Indeed my Lord, you grieve me more than I can anger you.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: What, do you crie! and yet desire to be a souldier?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: A valiant heart, my Lord, may have a weeping eye to keep it company.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: If no perswasion can stay you, you must go along with me.

div.stage: Affectionata bows, as giving his Lord thanks.

div.head: Scene 8.
div.stage: Enter the Lady VVagtail, the Lady Amorous, Sir Humphry Bold, Sir Timothy Compliment, to the Lady Bashfull, who hangs down her head, as out of countenance.

sp.speaker: LAdy Wagtail.
sp.p: Faith Lady Bashfull, we will have you abroad to Balls and publick meetings, to learn you a confident behaviour, and a bold speech; Fie! You must not be bashfull.

sp.speaker: Lady Amorous.
sp.p: Our visiting her sometimes, hath made her so, as she is not altogether so bashfull as she was.

div.stage: Enter Sir Serious Dumb, who bows first to the Lady Bashfull, then to the rest of the Company, and then goeth behind the Lady Bashfull, and stands close by Mistriss Reformer.

sp.speaker: Lady Amorous.
sp.p: Surely Sir Serious Dumb is a domestick servant here, he stands and waits as one.

div.stage: He bows with an acknowledging face.

sp.speaker: Sir Humphry Bold.
sp.p: If she wil entertain such servants as he, she is not so modest as she appears. Lady, perchance if I had come privately alone, I had been entertained with more freedom, and not have had my suit denied, and my person neglected with scorn, and he received with respect.

div.stage: Sir Serious Dumb comes and gives him a box on the eare, they both draw their swords, all the women runs away squeeking, only the Lady Bashfull stayes, and runs betwixt their swords, and parts them; Sir Timothy Compliment looks on as affraid to stir.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: For Heaven sake! fight not here, to affright me with your quarrels.

sp.speaker: Sir Humphry Bold.
sp.p: I will have his heart-bloud.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Good Sir Serious Dumb, and Sir Humphry Bold, leave off fighting.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Pray Sir Humphry Bold, give me your sword, that I may be sure you will not fight.

sp.speaker: Sir Humphry Bold.
sp.p: What, yield my sword up! I will dye first.

div.p: All speak at one time, who is kill'd, who is kill'd.
div.stage: Sir Humphry Bold presses towards Sir Serious Dumb.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Good Ladies, hold Sir Humphry Bold, and I will try to perswade Sir Serious Dumb.

sp.speaker: Lady Wagtail.
sp.p: What, you shall not stir, I am sure you will not oppose us women.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Noble Sir, to give me an assurance you will not fight, give me your sword.

div.stage: Sir Serious Dumb kisses the bilt of his sword, then gives it her.

Sir Humphry Bold gets lose from the Ladies, and goeth to assault Sir Serious Dumb; He being an armed, the Lady Bashfull seeing him, steps betwixt them, and with Sir Serious Dumb's sword, strikes at Sir Humphry Bold, and strikes his sword out of his hand.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: What, are you not ashamed to assault an unarmed man.

div.stage: Sir Humphry Bold runs to take up his sword, she also runs and sets her foot upon it.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Let the sword alone, for it is my prize; and by Heaven, if you touch it, I will run you thorough with this sword in my hand.

div.stage: Sir Humphry Bold runs, and catcheth Sir Timothy Compliments sword, and offers to make a thrust at Sir Serious Dumb, who puts the sword by, and beats it down with one hand, and with the other strikes it aside, then closes with him, and being skillfull at Wrestling, trips up his heels, then gets upon him,The women in the mean time squeeks. and having both his hands at liberty, wrings out Sir Humphry Bold's sword out of his hand, then ariseth and gives the sword to the right owner, who all the time trembled for fear, and never durst strive to part them.

sp.speaker: Sir Humphry Bold.
sp.p: Hell take me, but I will be revenged: Lady, I hope you will give me my sword again.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Never to fight against a woman, but my victorious spoils, I will deliver to this gallant Gentleman, who delivered up his life and honour into my hand, when he gave me his sword, and I indangered the loss of both by taking it, for which my gratitude hath nothing to return him but my self and fortunes, if he please to accept of that and me.

div.stage: Sir Serious Dumb bows with a respect, and kisses her hand.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Sir, I wish my person were more beautifull than it is, for your sake, and my fortune greater, with more certainty of continuance, as neither being subject to time or accident, but this certainly I will promise you, which is, my chaste and honest life; Now Sir, pray take these two swords, Gives him the two swords. this was yours, fear gave me confidence, this I won, love gave me courage.

div.stage: Sir Serious Dumb leads out his Mistriss.

sp.speaker: Sir Humphry Bold.
sp.p: I will be revenged.

div.head: Scene 9.
div.stage: Enter the Lord General, and Affectionata.

sp.speaker: LOrd Singul.
sp.p: Affectionata, I hear thou hast bought Arms, I am sure thou canst not fight.

sp.speaker: Affectionata,
sp.p: I am sure I will do my indeavour, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: Why, the very weight of thy Arms will sink thee down.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: O no, my Lord; my desire shall beat them up.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Alas, thou halt no strength to fight?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: What strength my active body wants, my vigorous spirits shall make good.

sp.speaker: Lord Singul.
sp.p: Prethee, my boy, do not adventure thy self, but stay in my Tent.

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: That would be a shame for me, and a dishonour to you, since you have adopted me your son, wherefore the World shall never say, you have bestowed your favour and your love upon a coward.

sp.speaker: Lord Singularity.
sp.p: I well perceive I have adopted a very willfull boy?

sp.speaker: Affectionata.
sp.p: Indeed, my Lord, I have no will, but what doth follow you.

div.stage: The General strokes Affectionata on the cheek.

div.head: Scene. 10.
div.stage: Enter Sir Serious Dumb, and his Mistriss the Lady Bashfull.

sp.speaker: SIr Serious Dumb.
sp.p: The time I vowed to silence is expir'd, and though my thoughts not gloriously attired with Eloquence, for Rhetorick I have none, yet civil words, sit for to wait upon a modest Lady, and to entertain an honest mind with words of truth, though plain? For 'tis not Rhetorick makes a happy life, but sweet society, that's void of strife.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Sir Rhetorick is rather for sound than sense, for words than reason.

sp.speaker: Sir Serious Dumb.
sp.p: Yet my sweet Mistriss, I wish my voice were tuned to your eare, and every word set as a pleasing note to make such musick as might delight your mind.

sp.speaker: Lady Bashfull.
sp.p: Your words slow thorough my ears, as smooth, clear, pure water from the spring of Hellicon, which doth not only refresh, but inrich my dull insipid brain.

div.head: Scene 11.
div.stage: Enter a Captain and his Corporal.

sp.speaker: COrporal.
sp.p: The Turks never received such a blow, as they have this time?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: A pox of them, they have made us sweat?

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: Why Captain, sweating will cure the Pox, and though you curse the Turks, yet it is we that live in Italy, that is diseased with them.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: The truth is, we lost more health in the Venetian service, than we gain wealth.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: Nay faith Captain, we do not only lose our health, but wast our wealth, for what booties we get from the Turks, the Courtezans gets from us.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: For that cause now I have gotten a good bootie, I will return into mine own Country, and buy aâ€”

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: A what Captain?

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: An Office in civil Government.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: But you will never be civil in your Office.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: That needs not to be, for though all Magisterial Offices bears a civil Authority, yet the Officers and Magistrates therein, are more cruel and ravenons than common souldiers.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: Verily Captain, I think common Souldiers are more mercifull and just than they.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Verely Corporal, I think you will become a Puritan Preacher.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: Why should you think so, Captain.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: First, because you have got the Pox, and that will make you Preach in their tone, which is, to speak thorough the nose; the next is, you have left the ranting Oaths that Souldier's use to swear, and use their phrases; as verily my beloved brethren, which brethrens souls, they care not for, nor thinks thereof, for though they speak to the brethren, they Preach to the sisters, which edifies wonderfully by their Doctrine, and they gain and receive as wonderfull from their female Hocks, for those Puritan Preachers have more Tithes out of the Marriage-bed, than from the Parish-stock.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: If it be so beneficial, Captain, I had rather be a Puritan Preacher, than an Atheistical States-man.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Faith Corporal, I think there is not much Religion in either, but if there be, it lies in the States-man, for he keeps Peace, the other makes War.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: If they make wars; they are our friends, for we live by the spoils of our enemies.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: 'Tis true, when as we get a victory, or else our enemies lives on the spoil of us, for though we have no goods to lose, yet we venture our lives, neither do we live on the spoil of our enemies, but only in forreign wars, for in civil wars we live by the spoil of our Friends, and the ruining of our Country.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: Then we are only obliged to Preachers for civil wars.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Faith Corporal, we are obliged to them for both; for as their faetious Doctrine causes a Rebellion by railing on the Governours and Governments, so their flattering Sermons sets a Prince on fire, who burns in hot ambition to conquer all the World.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: These latter Preachers you mention, Captain, are not Puritan Preachers, but Royal Preachers.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: You are right Corporal, for they are divided in two parts, although their Doctrine meets at one end, which is in war.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: Captain, you have discovered so fully of Preachers, that if you will give me leave, I will preach to our Company.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: Out you rogue, will you raise a war amongst our selves, causing a mutinie to cut one anothers throats?

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: Why Captain, it is the fashion and practice for Souldiers to Preach now adayes.

sp.speaker: Captain.
sp.p: That is amongst the Rebel party to keep up their faction, and to strengthen the flank thereof, but amongst the Royal party, the Preaching Ministers turn fighting Souldiers, incouraging with their good example, as by their valliant onsets, and not the Souldiers Preaching Ministers.

sp.speaker: Corporal.
sp.p: Why Captain, the Royal party needs no incouragement, the justice of their cause is sufficient.

sp.speaker: Captain.
