sp.speaker: Gold. Rich.
sp.p: Despise the Rural company, and that windy bag, change it for Balls with greatest Lords to dance, and bring the Jerkin Fiddles out of frame.

sp.speaker: Mall Mean-bred.
sp.p: Then I shall have a Mail-Pillion, and ride behind our Thomas to the dancing.

sp.speaker: Gold. Rich.
sp.p: No, you shall ride in rich gilt Coaches, Pages and Lacquies in rich Liveries, with Gentlemen well cloath'd, to wait upon you.

sp.speaker: Mall Mean-bred.
sp.p: And be a Lady; then I will be proud, and will not know Thomas any more, nor any Maid that was acquainted with me.

sp.speaker: Gold. Rich.
sp.p: You must forget all those of your Fathers house too; for I'll get a Pedigree shall fit you, and bring you Lineally descended from Great Charlemain.

sp.speaker: Mall Mean-bred.
sp.p: No, I will have it from Charls wayn my Fathers Carter; but I would so fain be a Lady, and it might be: I will be stately, laugh without a cause, and then I am witty, and jeer sometimes, and speak nonsense aloud. But this Gold will not serve for all these fine things.

sp.speaker: Gold. Rich.
sp.p: Why then we will have hundreds and thousands of pounds, until you be pleas'd, so I may but enjoy you in my Arms.

sp.speaker: Mall Mean-bred.
sp.p: No Maid alive can hold our these Assaults, Gold is the Petarr that breaks the Virgins gates, a Souldier told me so. VVell then, my Lord Title, farewel, for you are an empty name; and Sir Effeminate Lovely, go you to your Taylor, make more fine cloaths in vain.
sp.l: I'll stick to Riches, do then what you will,
The neerest way to pleasure buy it still.

sp.speaker: LAdy Ward.
sp.p: Why should Lord Courtship dislike me? Time hath not plowed wrinkles in my face, nor digged hollows in my cheeks, nor hath he set mine eyes deep in my head, nor shrunk my sinews up, nor suck'd my veins dry, nor fed upon my flesh, making my body insipid and bate; neither hath he quenched out my wit, nor decay'd my memory, nor ruin'd my understanding; but perchance Lord Courtship likes nothing but what is in perfection; and I am like a house which Time hath not fully finished, nor Education throughly furnished.

div.head: Scene 26.
div.stage: Enter Poor Virtue, and Sir Golden Riches meets her comming from Mall Mean-bred.

sp.speaker: Golden Riches.
sp.p: Sweet-heart, refuse not Riches, it will buy thee friends, pacifie thy enemies; it will guard thee from those dangers that throng upon the life of every creature.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: Heavenly Providence is the Marshal which makes way for the life to pass through the croud of dangers, and my Vertue will gain me honest friends, which will never forsake me, and my humble submission will pacifie my enemies, were they never so cruel.

sp.speaker: Gold. Rich.
sp.p: But Riches will give thee delight, and place thee in the midst of pleasures.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: No, it is a peaceable habitation, a quiet and sound sleep, and a healthful body, that gives delight and pleasure, and 'tis not riches; but riches many times destroy the life of the body, or the reason in the soul, or, at least, bring infirmities thereto through luxury; for luxury slackens the Nerves, quenches the Spirits, and drowns the Brain, and slackned Nerves make weak Bodies, quenched Spirits, timorous Minds, a drowned Brain, a watry Understanding, which causeth Sloth, Effeminacy, and Simplicity.

sp.speaker: Gold. Rich.
sp.p: How come you to know so much of the world, and yet know so few passages in it, living obscurely in a Farmers house?

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: The Astronomers can measure the distance of the Planets, and take the compass of the Globe, yet never travel to them; nor have they Embassadors from them, nor Liegers to lie therein to give Intelligence.

sp.speaker: Gold. Rich.
sp.p: How come you to be so learnedly judicious, being so young, poor, and meanly born and bred?

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p:
Why, Fire, Air, Water, and Earth, Animals, Vegetables, and Minerals, are Volumes large enough to express Nature, and make a Scholar learn to know the course of her works, and to understand many effects
produced therefrom. And as for Judgment and Wit, they are brother and sister; and although they do not alwayes, and at all times agree, yet are they alwayes the children of the Brain, being begot by Nature. Thus what Wit or Knowledge I have, may come immediatly from Nature, not from my Birth or Breeding; but howsoever, I am not what I seem.

div.head: Scene 27.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Contemplation, and the Lady Visitant.

sp.speaker: Visitant.
sp.p: What makes you look so sad?

sp.speaker: Contempl.
sp.p: Why Monsieur Amorous's visit hath been the cause of the death of one of the finest Gentlemen of this Age.

sp.speaker: Visitant.
sp.p: How, pray?

sp.speaker: Contempl.
sp.p: Why thus; my Imagination (for Imagination can Create both Masculine and Feminine Lovers) had Created a Gentleman that was handsomer and more beautiful than Leander, Adonis, or Narcissus; valianter than Tamberlain, Scanderbeg, Hannibal, Caesar, or Alexander; sweeter-natur'd than Titus, the delight of mankinde; better-spoken, and more eloquent than Tully, or Demosthenes; wittyer than Ovid, and a better Poet than Homer. This man to fall desperately in love with me, as loving my Vertues, honouring my Merits, admiring my Beauty, wondring at my Wit, doting on my Person, adoring me as an Angel, worshipping me as a Goddess; I was his Life, his Soul, his Heaven. This Lover courted my affection: with all the industry of Life, gifts of Fortune, and actions of Honour; sued for my favour, as if he had sued to Heaven for mercy; but I, as many cruel goddesses do, would neither receive his obligations, nor regard his vowes, nor pity his tears, nor hearken to his complaints, but rejected his Sute, and gave him an absolute denyal; whereupon he was resolved to dye, as believing no torments could be compared to those of my disdain; and since I would not love him living, he hoped by dying, his death might move my pity, and so beget a compassionate remembrance from me; wherupon he got secretly neer my chamber-door, and hung himself just where I must go out, which when I saw, I starred back in a great fright, but at last running forth to call for help to cut him down, in came Monsieur Amorous, which hinderance made me leave him hanging there, as being ashamed to own my cruelty; and he hath been talking, or rather prating here so long, as by this time my kind Love is dead.

sp.speaker: Visitant.
sp.p: O no, for Lovers will hang a long time before they dye; for their necks are tuff, and their hearts are large and hot.

sp.speaker: Contempl.
sp.p: Well, pray leave me alone, that I may cut him down, and give him Cordials to restore life.

sp.speaker: Visitant.
sp.p: Faith you must let him hang a little time longer; for I have undertaken to make you a sociable Lady this day; wherefore you must goe abroad to a friends house with me.

sp.speaker: Contempl.
sp.p: Who I? what do you think I will goe abroad, and leave my Lover in a twisted string? his legs hanging daugling down, his face all black and swelled, and his eyes almost started out of his head; no, no, pray goe alone by your self, and leave me to my Contemplation.

sp.speaker: Visitant.
sp.p: Well, if you will not goe, I will never see you, nor be friends with you again.

sp.speaker: Contempl.
sp.p: Pray be not angry, for I will go, if you will have me, although I shall be but a dull companion; for I shall not speak one word; for wheresoever I am, my thoughts will use all their Industry to cut the string, and take him down, and rub and chafe him against a hot fire.

sp.speaker: Visitant.
sp.p: Come, come, you shall heat your self with dancing, and let your Lover hang.

sp.speaker: Contempl.
sp.p: That I cannot; for active bodies and active brains are never at once, the one disturbs the other.

sp.speaker: Visitant.
sp.p: Then it seems you had rather have an active brain, than an active body.

sp.speaker: Contempl.
sp.p: Yes; for when the brain doth work, the understanding is inriched, and knowledge is gained thereby: whereas the body doth oft-times waste the life with too much exercise.

sp.speaker: Visitant.
sp.p: Take heed you do not distemper your brain with too much exercising your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Contempl.
sp.p: All distempers proceed from the body, and not from the minde; for the minde would be well, did not the humours and appetites of the body force it into a distemper.

sp.speaker: Visitant.
sp.p: Well, upon the condition you will goe, you shall sit still, and your wit shall be the Musick.

sp.speaker: Contempl.
sp.p: Prethee let me rest at home; for to day the strings of my wit are broken, and my tongue, like a fiddle, is out of tune: Besides, Contemplative persons are at all times dull speakers, although they are pleasant thinkers.

div.head: The Second Part of the Lady Contemplation.
The Second Part of the Lady Contemplation,
ACT I.
Scene. 1.
div.stage: Enter Sir Effeminate Lovely, and Poor Virtue.

sp.speaker: EFfeminate Lovely.
sp.p: Sweet-heart, you are a most Heavenly Creature.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: Beauty is created and placed oftner in the fancy, than in the face.

sp.speaker: Effem. Lovely.
sp.p: 'Tis said there is a Sympathy in likeness; if so, you and I should love each other, for we are both beautiful.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: But 'tis a question whether our Souls be answerable to our Persons.

sp.speaker: Effem. Lovely.
sp.p: There is no question or doubt to be made, but that loving souls live in beautiful persons.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: And do those loving soules dye, when their beauties are decayed and withered?

sp.speaker: Effem.
sp.p: The subject pleads it self, without the help of Rhetorick, for Love and Beauty lives and dies together.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: 'Tis Amorous Love that dies when Beauty is gone, not Vertuous Love; for as Amorous Love is bred, born, lives, and dies with the appetite: so Vertuous Love is Created, and shall live with the Soul forever.

sp.speaker: Effem. Lovely.
sp.p: You may call it what love you please.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: It is no love, but a disease.

div.head: Scene 2.
div.stage: Enter the Lord Courtship, and the Lady Ward.

sp.speaker: LOrd Courtship.
sp.p: Why did you leave the Lady Amorous company so uncivilly, as to go out of the room, leaving her all alone?

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: I heard your Lordship was coming, then I thought it was fit for me to withdraw; for I have heard Lovers desire to be alone.

sp.speaker: Lord Courtship.
sp.p: Do you desire to be alone with a man?

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: I am no such Lover, for I am too young as yet, but I know not what I shall or may be wrought or brought to, but time and good example may instruct and lead me into the way of amorous love.

sp.speaker: Lord Courtship.
sp.p: May it so?

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: Why not? for I am docible, and youth is apt to learn.

sp.speaker: Lord Court.
sp.p: But before I marry you, I would have you learn to know how to be an obedient wife, as to be content, and not murmure at my actions, also to please my humour, but not to imitate my practice.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: If I might advise your Lordship, I would advise you to take such a Portion out of my Estate, as you shall think just or fit, and then quit me, and choose such a one as you shall like, for I shall never please you; for though I may be apt to learn what will please my self, yet I am dull and intractable to learn obedience to anothers will, nor can I flatter their delights.

sp.speaker: Lord Court.
sp.p: I finde you have learned, and now begin to practice how to talk; for now your sober silence seems as dead and buried in the rubbish of follish words; But let me tell you, a talking wife will never please me; wherefore practise patience, and keep silence, if you would enjoy the happiness of peace.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: There can be no peace, when the mind is discontented.

div.head: Scene. 3.
div.stage: Enter Lord Title, and Poor Vertue.

sp.speaker: POor Virtue.
sp.p: Why do you follow me so much, as never to let me rest in peace and quiet alone? Is it that you think I have beauty? and is it that you are in love with? why, to cure your disease, I will deform it; or do you think I have wit to cure that Imagination? I will put my tongue to silence. I am sure it cannot be my Vertue that inflames you to an intemperance; for Vertue is an Antidote against it: But had you all the beauty in Nature squeez'd into your form, and all the wit in Nature prest into your brain, and all the prosperities of good fortune at your command, and all the power of Fate and Destiny at your disposal, you could not perswade me to yield to your unlawful desires; for know, I am honest without self-ends; my virtue, like to Time, still running forward, my chastity six'd as Eternity, without circumferent lines; besides, it is built on the foundation of Morality, and roof'd and cicl'd with the faith of Religion, and the materials thereof are Honour, which no subtil Arguments can shake the one, nor no false Doctrine can corrupt or rot the other; neither is the building subject to the fire of unlawful love, nor the tempestuous storms of torments, nor the deluge of poverty, nor the earthquakes of fear, nor the ruines of death; for so long as my Soul hath a being, my Chastity will live. But were you as poor as I, even to move pity, or so lowly and meanly born, at might bring contempt and scorn from the proud, yet if your mind and soul were endued with noble qualities, and heroical vertues, I should sooner embrace your love, than to be Mistris of the whole World; for my affection to merit hath been ingrafted into the root of my Infancy, which hath grown up with my yeares, so that the longer I live, the more it increases.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: You cannot think I would marry you, although I would lie with you.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: I cannot but think it more possible that you should marry me, than I to be dishonest.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Thou art a mean poor wench, and I nobly descended.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: What though I am poor, yet I am honest, and poverty is no crime; nor have my Ancestors left marks of infamy to shame me to the world.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Thy Ancestors? what were they but poor peasants? wherefore thou wilt dignifie thy Race, by yielding to my love.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: Heaven keep them from that dignity that must be gained by my dishonesty: no, my chastity shall raise a Monumental Tomb over their cold dead ashes.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: What pity it is Nature should put so noble a soul into a meanborn body.

div.head: Scene 4.
div.stage: Enter the Lord Courtship, and the Lady VVard.

sp.speaker: LOrd Courts.
sp.p: Pray go visit the Lady Amorous, and if her husband be absent, deliver her this letter.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: Excuse me my Lord.

sp.speaker: Lord Courts.
sp.p: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: I am no Carrier of Love-letters.

sp.speaker: Lord Courts.
sp.p: But you shall carry this.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: But I will not.

sp.speaker: Lord Courts.
sp.p: Will you not?

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: No, I will rather endure all the torments that can be invented.

sp.speaker: Lord Courts.
sp.p: And you shall; for I will torture you if you do not; for I will have you drawn up high by the two thumbs, which is a pain will force you to submit.

div.stage: The Lady Ward falls into a passion.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: Do so if you will; nay scrue me up into the middle-Region, there will I take a Thunderbolt, and strike you dead, and with such strength I'll fling it on you, as it shall press your soul down to the everlasting shades of death.

sp.speaker: Lord Courts.
sp.p: Sure you will be more merciful.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: No more than Devils are to sinful souls; there will I be your Bawd, to procure you variety of torments; for I had rather be one in Pluto's black Court, caused by my own revenge, than to be a Bawd on earth, which is a humane Devil.

sp.speaker: Lord Courts.
sp.p: You are mad.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: Might every word I speak prove like a mad dogs bite, not only to transform your shape, and turn your speech to barks and howlings, but that your soul may be no other than the souls of beasts are.

sp.speaker: Lord Courts.
sp.p: You are transformed from a silent young Maid to a raging Fury.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p:
May all the Furies that Hell inhabites, and those that live
on earth, torment your minde, as racks do torture bodies, and may the venom of all malice, spleen, and spight, be squeez'd into your soul, and poyson all content, your thoughts flame like burning oyl, and never quench, but be eternally a siery Animal; and may the fire feed onely on your self, and as it burns, your torments may increase.

sp.speaker: Lord Courts.
sp.p: She is mad, very mad, and I have only been the cause.

div.head: Scene 5.
div.stage: Enter the Lord Title, and Poor Virtue,

sp.speaker: LOrd Title.
sp.p: Fairest, will not you speak?

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: My words have betrayed my heart, as discovering the secrets therein: wherefore I will banish them, and shut the doors of my lips against them.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: What, for saying you love me. Sweet, why do you weep?

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: Tears are the best Cordials for a heart opprest with grief.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: I should hate my self, if I could think I were the cause. But pray forbear to weep.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: Pray give my grief a liberty, my tears are no disturbance, they showre down without a ratling noise, and silent fall without a murmuring voice; but you disturb me: Wherefore for pity-sake leave me, and I will pray you may enjoy as much prosperity as good fortune can present you with, and as much health as Nature can give you, and as much tranquillity as Heaven can infuse into a mortal creature.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Neither Fortune, Nature, nor Heaven can please me, or make me happy in this world without you.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: O you torment me.

div.head: Scene 6.
div.stage: Enter Sir Humphry Interruption to the Lady Contemplation.

sp.speaker: SIr Humphry Inter.
sp.p: Surely Lady Contemplation your thoughts must needs be very excellent, that they take no delight but with themselves.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: My thoughts, although they are not material, as being profitable, yet they are innocent, as being harmless.

sp.speaker: Sir Humphry Inter.
sp.p: Yet your thoughts do the world an injury, in burying your words in the grave of silence.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p:
Let me inform you, that sometimes they creep out of
their graves as Ghosts do, and as Ghosts walk in solitary places, so I speak to my solitary self, which words offend no ears, because I speak to no ears but my own; and as they have no flatterers to applaud them, so they have no censurers to condemn them.

sp.speaker: Sir Humphrey Inter.
sp.p: But you bury your life, whilst you live retir'd from company.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: O no, for otherwise my life would be buried in company; for my life never enjoys it self, but when it is alone; and for the most part, all publick societies are like a discord in Musick, every one playing several contrary parts in their actions, speaking in several contrary notes, striking on several contrary subjects, which makes a confusion; and a confused noise is like a disorder'd multitude, only the one offends the ear, as the other offends the eyes; and there can be no pleasure but in harmony, which harmony is Quantity, Quality, Symmetry, and Unity; and though quality, quantity, and symmetry are brought by the Senses, yet Unity is made in the mind. Thus Harmony lives in the minde; for without the minde, the senses could take no delight.

div.head: Scene. 7.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Ward, and Doctor Practice.

sp.speaker: DOctor Practice.
sp.p: How do you Lady?

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: Why very well Doctor, how do you?

sp.speaker: Doctor Prac.
sp.p: Why I was sent, as being believed you are mad.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: Troth Doctor that's no wonder; for all the world is mad, more or less.

sp.speaker: Doctor Prac.
sp.p: Do you finde any distemper in your head?

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: My head will ake sometimes.

sp.speaker: Doctor Pract.
sp.p: I mean a distemper in your minde.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: My minde is troubled sometimes.

sp.speaker: Doctor Pract.
sp.p: That is not well: let me feel your pulse.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: Why Doctor, can you know the temper of my mind, by the feeling of my pulse?

sp.speaker: Doctor Pract.
sp.p: There is a great Sympathy between the Minde and the Body.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: But I doubt, Doctor, your learned skill is many times deceived by the pulse; you will sooner find a mad distemper in the tongue or actions, than in the wrists.

sp.speaker: Doctor Pract.
sp.p: In troth Lady, you speak reason, which those that are mad do not do.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: O yes, Doctor, but they doe, as you cure Diseases, by chance.

div.head: Scene 8.

sp.speaker: LOrd Title.
sp.p: O Love, dissembling love, that seem'st to be the best of passions, and yet torments the soul!

div.stage: He walks in a melancholy muse.

sp.speaker: Master Inquirer.
sp.p: What makes your Lordship so melancholy, as to shun all your friends, to walk alone?

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: I am in Love.

sp.speaker: Master Inqui.
sp.p: There are many remedies for love.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: I would you could tell me one.

sp.speaker: Master Inqui.
sp.p: May I know the Lady you are in love with?

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: The Lady say you? she is a poor Lady â€¢

sp.speaker: Master Inqui.
sp.p: Your Lordship is so rich, as you may marry without a portion,

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: O I could curse my fate, and rail at my destiny.

sp.speaker: Master Inqui.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: To make me fall in love with one I am asham'd to make her known.

sp.speaker: Master Inqui.
sp.p: Is she so mean, and yet so beautiful?

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: O she hath all the Beauties and Graces that can attract a soul to love; for surely Nature sate in Councel to make her body, and the Gods sate in Councel to compose her mind.

sp.speaker: Master Inqui.
sp.p: May not I see her?

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Master Inqui.
sp.p: Where may I find her?

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Upon the next Plain, under a bush that bends much like a bower, there she most commonly sits to watch her sheep; but I will goe with you.

sp.speaker: Master Inqui.
sp.p: Your Lordship is not jealous?

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: All Lovers think their Beloved is never secure enough.

div.head: Scene 9.
div.stage: Enter Nurse Careful, as in a fright, unto the Lady VVard.

sp.speaker: Nurse Careful.
sp.p: O my Child, I am told that on a sudden you turned mad!

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: Surely Nurse your fear, or what else it may be, you seem to me to be more mad than I can find in my self to be.

sp.speaker: Nurse Caref.
sp.p: That shews you are mad.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: If I am mad, I suck'd the madness from your brest.

sp.speaker: Nurse Caref.
sp.p: I do confess, Child, I have not had those mad vagaries since I gave suck, as I had before.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: 'Tis a signe you are grown old, Nurse.

sp.speaker: Nurse Caref.
sp.p: I confess, Youth is oftner mad than Age; but dear Child tell me, art thou mad?

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: Prethee Nurse, lest thou shouldst become mad, goe sleep to settle thy thoughts, and quiet thy mind, for I remember a witty Poet, one Doctor Don, saith,
sp.l: Sleep is pains easie salve, and doth fulfil
All Offices, unless i â€¢ 't â€¢ to kill.

div.stage: Nurse Careful cries out, as in a great fright.

sp.speaker: Nurse Caref.
sp.p: O Heaven, what shall I do, what shall I do!

sp.speaker: Doctor Pract.
sp.p: What is the matter Nurse, what is the matter you shreek out so?

sp.speaker: Nurse Caref.
sp.p: O Doctor, my Child is mad, my Child is mad; for she repeats Verses.

sp.speaker: Doctor Pract.
sp.p: That's an ill signe indeed.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: Doctor, did you never repeat Latine Sentences when you have read Lectures, nor Latine Verses, when you did Dispute in Schools?

sp.speaker: Doctor Pract.
sp.p: Yes, Sweet Lady, a hundred times.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: Lord, Doctor, have you been mad a hundred times, and recovered so often!

sp.speaker: Nurse Caref.
sp.p: Those were Latine Verses, those were Latine Verses Child.

sp.speaker: Doctor Pract.
sp.p: Faith Lady you pose me.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: Then Doctor go to School again, or at least return again to the University and study again, and then practise not to be posed.

sp.speaker: Doctor Pract.
sp.p: Nurse, she is not well, she must be put to a diet.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: But why, Doctor, should you think me mad? I have done no outragious action; and if all those that speak extravagantly should be put to a diet, as being thought mad, many a fat waste would shrink in the doublet, and many a Poetical vein would be dryed up, and the flame quench'd out for want of radical oyl to prolong it; Thus Wit would be starved, for want of vapour to feed it; The truth is, a spare diet may make room in a Scholars head for old dead Authors to lie in; for the emptyer their heads are of wit, the fuller they may be fill'd with learning; for I do imagine, old dead Authors lie in a Scholars head, as they say souls do, none knows where, for a million of souls to lie in as small a compass as the point of a needle.

sp.speaker: Doctor Pract.
sp.p: Her brain is hotly distemper'd, and moves with an extraordinary quick motion, as may be perceiv'd by her strange fancy: wherefore Nurse you had best get her to bed; if you can, and I will prescribe some medicine and rules for her.

sp.speaker: Nurse Caref.
sp.p: Come sweet child, let me put thee to bed.

sp.speaker: Lady VVard.
sp.p:
I will go to bed, if you would have me, but good Nurse believe me, I am not mad; it's true, the force of my passion hath made my Reason to erre; and though my Reason hath gone astray, yet it is not lost: But consider well Nurse, and tell me what noble minde can suffer a base servitude without rebellious passions? But howsoever, since they are of this opinion, I am content to cherish it, if you approve of it; for if I seem mad,
the next of my kindred will beg the keeping of me for the sake of my Estate; and I had rather lose my Estate, and be thought mad, than lose my honour in base offices, and my free-born liberty to be inslaved to whores; and though I do not fear my honest youth can be corrupted by ill example, yet I will not have my youth a witness to wicked and base vice.

sp.speaker: Nurse Caref.
sp.p: By no means, I do not approve of these strange wayes; besides, you are a Ward to a gallant man, and may be Mariage will alter his humour; for most commonly those back-holders that are the greatest Libertines, make the best Husbands.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: 'Tis true, he is of a noble nature, valiant and generous, prudent, and just, and temperate in all delights, and free from all other vices but Incontinency, civil and obliging to all the world, but to me, and I could love him better than life, could he be constant, and only love me as he ought to do a Wife; otherwise, Death were more pleasing to me.

div.head: Scene 10.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Contemplation musing, and the Lady Visitant comes to her.

sp.speaker: LAdy Contempl.
sp.p: You were born to do me a mischief.

sp.speaker: Lady Visit.
sp.p: Why how?

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: Why you have routed an Army.

sp.speaker: Lady Visit.
sp.p: Which way?

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p:
I did imagine my self Married, my Husband being a General of an Army, who had fought many Battels, and had won many Victories, conquer'd many Nations, at last an unfortunate day of Battel being fought, my Husband being too active and venturous, making lanes of slain bodies as he went, and his horse riding thorow Rivers of blood, those Rivers rising so high, as his horse was forced to swim; but the blood growing thick to a jelly, obstructed his way, which made his horse furious, which fury added to his strength, forced a passage over a hill, or heap of slain bodies; but the horses spirits being spent with fury and labour, fell strengthless to the ground, with my Husband upon his back; and being in the midst of his Enemies Army, his Enemies seeing him fall, ran about him in great numbers, and so took him prisoner: whereupon his Souldiers soon missing him, thought he was kill'd; upon which belief, their courages grew cold, their limbs unactive, and their spirits so benumm'd, as they all seemed like to a number of stone-statues; which unactive dulness gave their Enemies the Day without any after-blows. I being in the Camp, hearing of my Husbands misfortunes, ran with a distracted fear towards the Enemies Camp; I being espy'd by some of my Husbands scatter'd Troops, was stop'd in the way, and so brought back to my Tent again; where, when I was there, some of my Husbands Officers of the Army told me, That though the Day was lost, yet there was a considerable Body left; which I no sooner heard, but my spirits took new life, and then excusing my fear, told those Commanders it was not through fear that made me run out of my Tent; for I did
not fly from my Enemies, but to them, and that I sought death, and not life; and to express my courage, I told them, That if they would give me leave, I would take my Husbands Office, and lead the Army: They told me, that if the rest of the Commanders would agree to it, they were well contented: So when all the Commanders met together, I spake thus unto them.

Noble Friends, and valiant Souldiers, you may think it a vain ambition for me to desire to lead your Army, especially against so potent an Enemy, and being a woman, which female Sex are usually unexperienced in Mar â€¢â€¢
al Affairs, as also by nature fearful, which fears may ruine an Army, by giving wrong direction, causing a confusion through distraction; and truly an Army were not to be trusted unto a woman; management and ordering, if that Records had not given us Precedents, which is, that Woman have led Armies, have fought valiantly themselves, and have had good success, and not so much by fortunes favour, as by their own wise Conduct: And to shew that Pallas is a friend unto her own Sex, is, that in all History, there are very few women than can be found, that have lost Battels in the field of Wars, but many that have won Battels; and in all publick Affairs it is to be observed, the Gods do generally assist our Sex, whereby to shew their own power, and to abate the haughty pride of men. But to induce you more; for men trust not so much unto the Gods, as to their own strength, is, that you are present in all Councels and Actions, to assist and direct me; besides, I am Wife unto your General, who was and is an expert Souldier, and a valiant man, although he now had ill fortune; but ill fortune neither lessens valour nor experience, but rather increases them. This gallant and wise man, my Husband and your General, his Discourses have been my Tutors, and his Example hath and shall be my Guide; and if you dare trust me, I dare venture; otherwise I shall stay in my Tent, and pray for your good success. After I had left off speaking, an old Commander which had served long in the Wars, and was much esteemed, answered me as thus.

Noble Lady, although your youth doth disswade us, yet your beauty and wit doth encourage us; for what man, although he were possest with fear itself, can run away when a fair Lady sights? for beauty triumphs in all hearts, and commands the whole world: wherefore that man that shall or will deny to follow your Command, is of a bastard-kind, although a lawful Issue. With that all the rest of the Commanders cry'd or call'd out, that none was so fit to Lead and Command them as I. Thus being chosen, I call'd a general Muster of my Souldiers, and then gave order that some of the broken Regiments should be mended and made up with other broken Regiments, also I made new Officers in the room of those that were slain or taken prisoners, and after, I surveyed my Artillery and Ammunition; which done, I drew my Army into a Body, and after I had given Orders and Directions for the Souldiers to march towards the Enemies Camp, which when the Enemy heard of a new Army coming towards them, they drew out the Body of their Army in Battel Array: But I shunn'd to fight so soon as appeared, by reason my Army was tyred with marching; wherefore I gave order to Intrench: Besides, I thought it might give my souldiers more courage, when accustomed to the fight and neighbourhood of the Enemies: But withall, I made some of them give intelligence to the Enemy that a woman led the Army, by which they might despise us, and so become
more negligent, by which negligence we might have an advantage: In the mean time I sent to Treat of a Peace, and to have my Husband set at liberty; but the Enemy was so averse to a peace, as they returned me both jesting and scornful Answers: So when I saw no peace could be made, I drew out my Army into Battel Array; which when the Enemy perceiv'd, they did the like; but it will be too tedious at this time to tell the Form and Figures I put my Army into, as also what Commanders led, or who ommanded the Horse, or who commanded the Foot that day; only let me tell you, I led the Van my self, and was Accoutred after this manner: I had a Masculine Suit, and over that a cloth of silver Coat, made close to my waste, which reached to the ankles of my legs; and those Arms I wore being all gilt, were Back, Brest, Gorget, Pot and Gantlet, all being made light according as my strength would bear: In my hand I carried my Sword; for being not accustomed, I could not wear a sword by my side, as men do, but whensoever rested, I tyed it to my Saddle-bow, and on my Head-piece I wore a great Plume of Feathers: As for my Horse, he was cole-black, only a white star on his fore-head, and three white feet; my Saddle was crimson Velvet, but so imbroidred with silver and gold, as the ground could not be seen: But when I was mounted, I spoke as following unto the common souldiers.

Worthy Friends, and laborous, and valiant Souldiers, you may justly wonder to see a Woman thus Accoutred like a man, and being one of the tender female Sex to be arm'd as a souldier, and in a posture to fight a Battel: Also you may fear the successe of my Command, by reason I am young, and unexperienced, as also unpractised in the Wars: But fear not, the gods are with me, and will assist me, and have promised to give you victory by my Conduct; for they will conduct me: But the Gods suffer'd the other Battel to be lost, because many Victories had made you proud, and conceited of your selves, and your own valours, trusting more to your own strength, than to their favours or powers, whereupon the Gods destroy'd many of you; but since they have taken pity of you, drawn to it by your humility: whereupon the Gods have commanded me to Lead and Conduct you; and they have also commanded me to tell you, That if you trust in them, and fight couragiously, that you shall have Victory, and rich Spoils; for I heard the common people, of which common souldiers were of, were apt to be superstitious, and to believe in any new reports, as also to believe in Miracles, Prophecies, and the like, and withall, very covetous; all which, made me feign my self to be commanded immediately from the Gods, and to be sent as from the Gods to command them, and to declare such promises to them; for all the common souldiers sight for Spoils, not for Honour.

sp.speaker: Lady Visitant.
sp.p: O but it is not good to dissemble.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: Pardon me; for without policy (which is deceit) there can be neither government in peace or war: wherefore it is a vertue in a States-man, or a Commander, to be a dissembler, although it be a vice in any other man; but you have put me out as you always do, and therefore I will tell you no more.

sp.speaker: Lady Visitant.
sp.p: Nay, pray make an end.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: I will not; but I could have told you how I kill'd the General of the Enemy with my own hand, and how I releas'd my Husband, and of such gallant Acts as you never heard the like of.

sp.speaker: Lady Visitant.
sp.p: O pray tel me.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: Which if I do, let me never contemplate more, which would be worse than death to me, by reason it is the onely pleasure of my life.

sp.speaker: POor Vertue.
sp.p: O Love, though thou art bred within the Soul, yet by the Senses thou art begotten, or else by some Opinions; for Virtue is but the Tutor, or Guide, for to instruct or lead thee in a perfect way â€¢ bur though I lead Love right, yet may it meet Opposers.

div.head: Scene 12.
div.stage: Enter the Lord Courtship, and Doctor Practice.

sp.speaker: LOrd Courts.
sp.p: How do you find my Ward?

sp.speaker: Doctor Pract.
sp.p: Truly she is somewhat distemper'd; for her wit is very quick.

sp.speaker: Lord Courts.
sp.p: That's it; for she being naturally of a dull disposition, and of a milde humour, and her brain slow of conceits, as also unpractis'd in speaking, should of a sudden fall into high raptures.

sp.speaker: Doctor Pract.
sp.p: You say true, my Lord; and it is to be fear'd this distemper will increase.

sp.speaker: Lord Courts.
sp.p: Pray Doctor have a regard and care to her distemper; for I would not willingly have a Wife that is more mad than natural women are.

div.head: Scene 13.
div.stage: Enter Lord Title, and Master Inquirer.

sp.speaker: LOrd Title.
sp.p: She is not here.

div.stage: Enter Poor Virtue, with a sheephook in her hand.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: O yonder she comes.

sp.speaker: Master Inqui.
sp.p:
She hath a garb not like a Farmers Maid, but rather one
that's nobly born, and her garments, though mean, sit nearly on her body.
Fair Shepherdess, it is a melancholy life you lead.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: It is a course of life suits best to my condition.

sp.speaker: Master Inqui.
sp.p: You may change this condition if you please.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: I had rather lie honoured in death, than by dishonour raised to glorious state of life.

sp.speaker: Master Inqui.
sp.p: But here you live like a creature not produced by mankind, amongst beasts, having no conversation by discourse.

sp.speaker: Poor Vir.
sp.p: Want of Speech makes not beasts beasts, but want of Reason, & want of Reason makes a man a beast; and speech rather disturbs than benefits the life, when silence and pure thoughts make men like Angels, whereas speech sometimes expresses men like Devils, blaspheming Heaven and God, fomenting factions amongst their kind, betraying trust & friendship, cozening innocency, slattering vice, reproaching virtue, and with distractions strives to pull down honour from its feat; where silence refines the thoughts, elevates the fancy, quickens wit, strengthens judgment, allays anger, sweetens melancholy, and collects the Reason.

sp.speaker: Master Inqui.
sp.p: Thou art a wonder, and for this one Speech I doe adores thee.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: I should be sorry so worthy a person, and so noble a Gentleman as you seem to be, should adore my Speech, when it might be chance that did produce it, and not wit or judgment.

sp.speaker: Master Inqui.
sp.p: Thy speech is like to Orpheus Harp, it charms all ears that hear it.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: I wish my Speech were like a Loadstone, to draw the iron hearts of men to pity and compassion, to charity and devotion.

div.stage: Poor Virtue offers to be gone.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Pray stay and choose me for your Love, and let me go along with you.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: An Amorous Lovers, as I believe your Lordship is, never walks in sober pace, nor hath a constant and assur'd minde; for Amorous Lovers run with might and main, as if desires were catch'd with haste.

div.stage: Poor Virtue goes out, Lord Title follows her.

sp.speaker: Master Inqui.
sp.p: I perceive Farmers breed pretty Maids, and honest, as well as Lambs and Doves, and witty and well-behav'd Maids, as well as Courts and Cities do. O that I were unmatied, that I might wed this Sweet, Fair Country-maid!

div.stage: Enter Mall Mean-bred, with a pail in her hand.

sp.speaker: Master Inqui.
sp.p: But stay, here comes another by my troth, a very pretty Lass, but yet her garments sit not so neat, nor becoming, nor is her behaviour so graceful as the other Maids was. Sweet Mistris!

sp.speaker: Mall Mean-bred.
sp.p: Pray keep your jeers to your self, I am no Mistris.

sp.speaker: Master Inqui.
sp.p: You may be my Mistris, if you please, and I will be your servant.

sp.speaker: Mall Mean-bred.
sp.p: What to do?

sp.speaker: Master Inqui.
sp.p: What you please.

sp.speaker: Mall Mean-bred.
sp.p: I am seldome pleased, and an idle fellow will anger me more.

sp.speaker: Master Inqui.
sp.p: I will be very industrious, if you please to set me to work.

div.stage: Enter Maudlin Huswife her Mother, she falls a beating her.

sp.speaker: Maudlin.
sp.p: You idle slut, do you stand loytering here, when it is more than time the Cows were milk'd?

sp.speaker: Mall Mean-bred.
sp.p: Go milk them your self with a murrain, since you are so light-finger'd.

sp.speaker: Maudlin.
sp.p: I will milk your sides first.

div.stage: The Mother goeth to beat her again, Mall Mean-bred her daughter runs away from her mother, she follows her, running to catch her.

sp.speaker: Master Inqui.
sp.p: I marry Sir, this is right as a Farmers daughter should be; but in my Conscience the other Maid that was here before her is a bastard, begot by some Gentleman.

div.head: Scene 14.
div.stage: Enter Sir John Argument, and the Lady Conversation.

sp.speaker: LAdy Conversa.
sp.p: Let me tell you, Sir Iohn Argument, Love delivers up the whole Soul to the thing beloved; and the truth is, none but one soul can love another.

sp.speaker: Argum.
sp.p: But Justice, Madam, must be the rule of Love; wherefore those souls which Love must give the bodies leave to joyn.

sp.speaker: Conversat.
sp.p: O no; pure souls may converse without gross bodies.

sp.speaker: Argument.
sp.p: Were it not for the Senses, Madam, souls could have no acquaintance, and without an acquaintance, there can be no reciprocal affection; and will you make the Senses, which are the souls chief confidence, to be strangers or enemies?

sp.speaker: Conversat.
sp.p: I would have them converse, but not interrupt.

sp.speaker: Argum.
sp.p: The bodies must have mutual friendship and correspondency with each other, or otherwise they may dissemble, or betray the souls; or abuse the trust, loose appetites or wandring senses or contrary humours; and what can interrupt Love more than the disagreement of bodies?

sp.speaker: Conversat.
sp.p: The Senses and Appetites of the Body, are but as subject to the Soul.

sp.speaker: Argument.
sp.p: But 'tis impossible for Forein Princes, as I will compare two loving souls unto, can live in peace and mutual amity, if their subjects disagree.

sp.speaker: Conversat.
sp.p: O Mistris Troublesome, you are welcome; for you shall end the dispute between Sir Iohn Argument and I.

sp.speaker: Troublesome.
sp.p: If you cannot decide the Dispute your selves, I shall never do it. But what is the Dispute Madam?

sp.speaker: Conversat.
sp.p: Whether there can be a perfect friendship of Souls without a reciprocal and mutual conversation and conjunctions of Bodies?

sp.speaker: Troublesome.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I think it would be a very faint friendship betwixt the Souls, without the Bodies.

sp.speaker: Conversat.
sp.p: I perceive Sir Iohn Argument and you would never make Platonick Lovers.

sp.speaker: Troublesome.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I think Platonick is a word without sense.

sp.speaker: Argument.
sp.p: You say right, Mistris Troublesome, it is an insensible love.

sp.speaker: Conversat.
sp.p: It is the Soul of Love.

sp.speaker: Troublesome.
sp.p: What's that, Madam, a Ghost, or Spirit?

sp.speaker: Conversat.
sp.p: Indeed it hath no material body.

sp.speaker: Argument.
sp.p: No, for it is an incorporal thing.

sp.speaker: Troublesome.
sp.p: What is an incorporal thing, Sir Iohn?

sp.speaker: Argument.
sp.p: Why, nothing.

sp.speaker: Troublesome.
sp.p: Pray leave this discourse, or else you will talk nonsense.

sp.speaker: Argument.
sp.p: That's usual in Conversation.

sp.speaker: Conversat.
sp.p: Setting aside this discourse at Mistris Troublesomes request, Pray tell me how the Lady Contemplation doth?

sp.speaker: Troublesome.
sp.p: Faith Madam, by the course of her life one might think she were an incorporal thing.

sp.speaker: Conversat.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Troublesome.
sp.p: Because she makes but little use of her Body, living always within her Minde.

sp.speaker: Conversat.
sp.p: Then her Body stands but as a Cypher amongst the Figures of her thoughts.

sp.speaker: Troublesome.
sp.p: Just so, by my Troth.

sp.speaker: Conversat.
sp.p: Pray bring me acquainted with the Lady Contemplation.

sp.speaker: Troublesome.
sp.p: If it be possible, I will; but the Lady Visitant can do it better than I.

sp.speaker: Conversat.
sp.p: I am resolv'd I will visit her.

div.head: Scene 15.
div.stage: Enter the Lord Courtship, and the Lady Ward.

sp.speaker: LOrd Courtship.
sp.p: What, is your passion over?

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p:
My passion will strive to maintain my honour, and you may take my life; but as long as I live, my passion will fight in the quarrel. But what man of honour will make a Bawd of her he intends to make his Wife? and what man of honour will be cruel to those that are weak, helplesse, and shiftlesse? and what man of honour will be uncivil to the meanest of our Sex? It is more noble to flatter us, than to quarrel with us;
but that I have heard you are valiant, I should think you were a base coward, and such a one that would quarrel in a Brothel-house, rather than fight in a Battel: But I perceive you are one that loves Pleasure more than Honour, and Life more than Fame; and I hate to be in that mans company, or to make a Husband, whose courage lies in Volupmousness, and his life in Infamy: I will sooner marry Death, than such a man.

sp.speaker: Lord Courts.
sp.p: Her words have shot through my soul, and have made a sensible wound therein. How wisely she did speak! how beautiful appear'd! Her minde is full of honour, and the actions of her life are built upon noble principles; so young, so wise, so fair, so chaste, and I to use her so basely as I have done! O how I hate my self for doing so unworthily!

div.head: Scene 16.
div.stage: Enter Sir Effeminate Lovely, and Poor Virtue.

sp.speaker: EFfemin. Lovely.
sp.p: The more ground is troden on, the easier the path to walk in.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: It seems so, that you visit me so often.

sp.speaker: Effem. Lovely.
sp.p: Why, thou art such sweet company, and behav'st thy self so prettily, as I cannot choose but visit thee.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: I would, if I could, behave my self so to the world, as my indiscretion might not defame me.

sp.speaker: Effem. Lovely.
sp.p: Why do you think of a Fame?

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: VVhy not? since fame many times arises from poor Cottages, as well as from great Palaces; witness the Country labouring-man, that was taken from the plough, and made an Emperour, as being thought sittest to rule, both for Justice and VVisedome, and he was more famous than those that were born of an Heroick Line, and were of Royal dignity; and David a shepherd, became a King. 'Tis Merit that deserves a fame, not Birth; and sometimes Merit hath its desert, though but seldome.

sp.speaker: Effem. Lovely.
sp.p: Thy discourse would tempt any man.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: Mistake not my discourse, it hath no such devilish design; for to tempt, is to pervert: 'Tis true, my Nature takes delight to delight and please others, and not to crosse or displease any, yet not to tempt, or to delude with counterfeit demeanors, or fair insinuating words, smooth speech, or oiled tongue, to draw from Virtues side, but to perswade and plead in Virtues cause.

sp.speaker: Effem. Lovely.
sp.p: Thy very looks would gain a cause, before thy tongue could plead.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: Alas! mans countenance is like the Sea, which ebbs and flows as passion moves the minde.

sp.speaker: Effem. Lovely.
sp.p: I am sure Love moves my minde, and makes it in a fiery heat.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: If it be noble Love, it is like the Sun, which runs about to give both light and heat to all the world, that else would sit in darknesse, and be both cold and steril; so doth a noble minde run with industry to help those in distresse, his bounty heats, his counsel and advice gives light.

sp.speaker: Effem. Lovely.
sp.p: I love you so much, Sweet-heart, that since you will not be my Mistris, you shall be my VVife.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: Indeed I will not.

sp.speaker: Effem. Lovely.
sp.p: VVill you refuse me?

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Effem. Lovely.
sp.p: VVherefore?

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: Because I know, though you may use me well at first, after a time you'l be divorc'd.

sp.speaker: Effem. Lovely.
sp.p: I will never part from thee.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: O yes but you will, for youth and beauty most commonly are inconstant; for vain ambition, and flattering praises, corrupt that mind that lives therein, and is pleased therewith.

sp.speaker: Effem. Lovely.
sp.p: Well, I will become a new man, and cast off all vanity, and study Moral Philosophy, to gain this Maid; for then perchance she will love me.

div.head: Scene 17.
div.stage: Enter Lady Conversation, and Sir Vain Complement.

sp.speaker: LAdy Conversat.
sp.p: Complements are the worst sort of Conversation, for they are not sociable; besides, Truth holds no intelligence nor correspondence with them.

sp.speaker: Sir Vain Compl.
sp.p: Truth is no Complement as flattery, and I speak nothing but what truth hath dictated to my tongue.

sp.speaker: Lady Conversat.
sp.p: Those praises you gave me were writ by speech, in so fine a style of Eloquence, with such flourishing Letters of words, as I cannot believe but that custome of self-conceited wit or passion, hath given the Scribe, which is the Tongue, a bribe to slatter me.

div.stage: Enter the Lady Contemplation, and Mistris Troublesome, to the Lady Conversation, and Sir Vain Complement.

sp.speaker: Lady Conversat.
sp.p: This is a wonder to see you, Lady Contemplation, abroad, I doubt it doth Prognosticate some change of Fortune, pray Iove it be good.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: All the ill will fall on me, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mistris Troubles.
sp.p:
Nay, faith Madam, she accounts company a worse fortune than the ruine of a Kingdome, and you cannot conceive with what difficulty I have got her abroad; for at first I did perswade her with all the
Rhetorick I had, and pleaded with as powerful arguments as I could finde, any promised more than I was able to perform, and nothing of this could get her forth, until I told her I would bring your Ladyship to visit her, and that forced her out; for she said, she would rather trouble you, than you should trouble her.

sp.speaker: Lady Conversat.
sp.p: Faith, Contemplation, thou art only sit to keep beasts company; for what difference is there betwixt beasts and men, but Conversation.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: Indeed beasts want that folly of idle Conversation, and the error of speaking, as much as the vanity of dressing, and the custome of dissembling; for they spend their time more prudently, quietly, easily, honestly, so more happily; and if it were for no other reason than speaking, I had rather be a beast, than of mankinde.

sp.speaker: Lady Conversat.
sp.p: O fie, O fie, you are a beastly Lady.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: No, Madam, beasts have no false Titles of Honour, their honour lives in their natures, not in their names.

sp.speaker: Lady Conversat.
sp.p: Who that may choose, or have their liberty, would spend their time in idle thoughts?

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: All that are wise, and would be happy; for should not we think that man were mad, that leaves a peaceful habitation, and thrusts himself in forein broyls? or should not we think a King were most unjust, that makes his peaceful and obedient subjects slaves to strange Princes? The Mind's a Common-wealth, and the Thoughts are the Citizens therein, and Reason rules as King, or ought to doe: But there is no reason we should vex our Thoughts with outward things, or make them slaves unto the world.

sp.speaker: Lady Conversat.
sp.p: But thoughts would want imployment, were it not for the world, and idlenesse were worse than slavish toyls.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: The thoughts, without the worlds materials, can Create millions of worlds, only with the help of Imagination.

sp.speaker: Lady Conversat.
sp.p: Then your Minde and the World are meer strangers.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: I say not so; for though the World draws not my Minde to wander up and down, yet my Minde draws the World to it, then pensils out each several part and piece, and hangs that Landskip in my Brain, on which my thoughts do view with Judgments eyes. Thus the world is in my Minde; although my Minde is not in the world.

sp.speaker: Lady Conversat.
sp.p: Then you inchant the world?

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: I had rather inchant the world, than the world should inchant me.

sp.speaker: Lady Conversat.
sp.p: If the Minde be a Common-wealth, as you said even now it was, Pray tell me of what degree the Passions are of?

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: They are the Nobles thereof, and Magistrates therein; each several Passion still governs in its turn and office.

sp.speaker: Lady Conversat.
sp.p: And what are the Appetites?

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: The Appetites are none of the Mind's Citizens, but they are an unruly Rout that dwell in the Senses, which are the Suburbs of the Body: Indeed the Appetites are the Out-Lawries, and doe oft-times much hurt with their disorders, insomuch as they, many times, disturb the mindes tranquillity, and peace. But, Madam, lest the appetite of talking should disturb the Mind, I shall kiss your Ladyships hand, and leave you to those that are more delightful and pleasanter company than I am.

sp.speaker: Mistris Trouble.
sp.p: Lady Conversation, I perceive you and Sir Vain Complement are grown dull with the Lady Contemplations company.

sp.speaker: Lady Conversat.
sp.p: Mercury defend me from her; for I would not keep her company for Ioves Mansion.

sp.speaker: Vain Compl.
sp.p: And Cupid defend me from her; for I would not be bound to Court her for the Favours Venus gives to Mars.

sp.speaker: Conversat.
sp.p: Lord what a dull piece of gravity she is!

sp.speaker: Vain Compl.
sp.p: She looks as if she convers'd with none but Ghosts and Spirits, walking in Moon-shine, and solitary and dismal places.

sp.speaker: Conversat.
sp.p: Let us talk of her no more; for I am so far from keeping her acquaintance, as I hate to hear her nam'd.

div.head: Scene 18.
div.stage: Enter the Lord Courtship, and the Lady Ward.

sp.speaker: LOrd Courtship.
sp.p: My Sweet, Fair Maid, I cannot hope thy Pardon, for my crimes are not only great, but many; for I have not only us'd you unkindly, uncivilly, ungentlemanly, which are vices and crimes that Cankerfret the Fame of Honour, and burie all noble qualities; but I have used you barbarously, cruelly, and inhumanly, which are sins sufficient to annihilate all the Masculine Race; and surely, if there be that we call Justice in Nature, it will, unless thy virtue redeem them, and save them with thy pity: wherefore, for the sake of the generality, though not for my particular, pardon me. Thus will you become a Deity to your whole Sex and ours.

sp.speaker: Lady Ward.
sp.p: I am sure your Lordship is a particular punishment to me, which Heaven send me quit of.

div.stage: She goes out, he follows her.

div.head: Scene. 19.
div.stage: Enter Sir Fancie Poet, and the Lady Contemplation.

sp.speaker: SIr Fan. Poet.
sp.p: Lady, you smother your thoughts, and stifle your conception in the close Closet of Study.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: No Sir, I only keep them warm, being tender and weak.

sp.speaker: Sir Fan. Poet.
sp.p: They will grow stronger in the Air of Conversation; but when continually kept close in the Chamber of Contemplation, they will be apt to fall into many several diseases, as melancholy Opinions, and extravagant Fancies, which may over-heat the minde, and sire the thoughts: wherefore Lady let me give you Counsel.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: What Counsel would you give me? as a Lawyer, or Phycian?

sp.speaker: Sir Fan. Poet.
sp.p: As a Physician.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: For the Body, or the Minde?

sp.speaker: Sir Fan. Poet.
sp.p: For the Minde.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: The Physicians for the Minde are Divine:

sp.speaker: Sir Fan. Poet.
sp.p: No, the best physicians for the Minde are Poets.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: How will you prove that?

sp.speaker: Sir Fan. Poet.
sp.p: By Example and Skill; for when the Minde is raging mad; Poets, with gentle perswasions, in smooth numbers, and soft musick, cure it; and when the Mind is despairing, Poets draw hopes into numbers, which beats out the doubtful Foe: And for Example.

David with his Poetical Inspirations, and Harpsical harmonious Musick, allay'd the ill Spirit, and raging passion of Saul; for Poets take from the sweet Spring of Nature, an Oil of Love, and from Heaven, the Balsom of Mercy, and pour them through golden numbers, and pipes of wit, into the fester'd wounds of despair, when oft-times Divines, in stead of suppling Oil, pour in corroding Vitriol, and in stead of healing Balsoms, pour in burning Sulphure, which are terrifying threats, and fearful menaces: wherefore Lady, let me advise you as a Poetical Physician, to keep your minde cool, and your thoughts in equal temper; wherefore in order thereto, when the minde is wrapt in the mantle of Imagination, if it finds it self very hot therewith, let it lay that mantle by, and bathe it self in the fresh, clear, pure Rivers of Discourse.

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: By your favour, Sir, for the most part, the Mind becomes hotter with the motion of the tongue, than the mantle of Imagination; for when the tongue hath liberty, it runs wildly about, and draggs the minde after it; and rather than I will have my minded dragg'd and hurried about by my unruly tongue, which will neither endure the bit of Reason, nor the bridle of Discretion, but runs beyond all sense, I will tye up my tongue with the cords of silence, in the stable of the mouth, and pull down the Port-cullis of the teeth before it, and shut the doors of my lips upon it. Thus shall it be treble lock'd, and kept with the Key of Judgment, and the Authority of Prudence.

div.head: Scene 20.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Conversation, and a Grave Matron.

sp.speaker: LAdy Conversat.
sp.p: Did you hear him say he had layn with me?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Yes, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Conversat.
sp.p: O the wicked, base vain-glory of men, to bely the pure chastity of a woman! But surely he did not plainly express so much in clear words, as by nods, winks, shrugs, dark sentences, or broken discourses?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: He said plainly, he had layn with you in an unlawful manner.

sp.speaker: Lady Conversat.
sp.p: Fates assist me in revenge; for it is no dishonour to be reveng'd of a base person, that hath maliciously slander'd me, or vain-gloriously injur'd me.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Revenge is against the Laws of Honour, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Conversat.
sp.p:
It may be against the Tenets of some particular Religion,
or religious Opinions. But a noble revenge is the ground or foundation of Heroick Honour.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: But what do you call a Noble Revenge?

sp.speaker: Lady Conversat.
sp.p: First, to be an open Enemy, as to declare the enmity; next, to declare their endeavour to prosecute to the utmost of their power, either their Enemies Estate, Liberty, and Life; whereas a base Revenger is to dissemble, in professing they have forgotten and forgiven their injury, and pardon'd their Enemy, yet under-hand and disguisedly endeavour to do their Enemy a mischief. Not but an honourable Revenger may choose their time for executing their revenge; but they must declare they will be revenged before they execute their revenge, and let their Enemies stand upon their Guard.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: But a revengeful woman is not good.

sp.speaker: Lady Conversat.
sp.p: Why not, as well as a revengeful man? For why may not a woman revenge her scandaliz'd honour as well as a man? Is there any reason why it should be a dishonour for a man to pass by a disgrace, and for a woman to revenge her disgrace? Is it not as great a blemish to the honour of a woman, to be said to be unchaste, as for a man to be said to be a Coward? And shall a woman only sit and weep over her lost honour, whilest a man fights to regain his? And shall it be thought no dishonour for a man to pistol, or at least bastonade another man for an injury, or an affront receiv'd, and a fault for a woman to do, or cause to be done the like? Must women only sit down with foolish patience, and endure wrong, when men may execute revenge with fury? These were both injustice, and an unjust act of Education to our Sex; as also it would be an unjust sentence, not only from men, but from the Gods, since neither Gods nor men will suffer injury, wrong, or dishonour, without revenge: But if Gods, Men, and Education should be so unjust to our Sex, yet there is no Reason in Nature we should be so unjust to our selves: But for my part, as I am constant to an honest friend, and can easily forgive an honourable Enemy, so I can never forgive a malicious Foe, nor forget a vain-glorious bragging fool, or false slandring knave, but will persecute them to the utmost of my power, and the weight of my revenge should be according to the pressure of my injury, or dishonour.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: But let me tell you, Madam, those that brag are seldome believ'd, and there is none that believe these vain bragging Ranters; for it's well known, that all Ranters are idle deboyst persons, and do usually belye the most Honourable and Chaste Ladies, for which all worthy persons hate them, and account them so base, as they will shun their companies; no man of honour will come near them, unless it be to beat them. But if you appear to the world as concerned, you may raise those doubts which would never have been raised, had you took no notice thereof.

sp.speaker: Lady Conversat.
sp.p: Indeed Disputes raise doubts; wherefore I will not bring it into a Dispute, but take your Counsel, and take no notice of it.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: You will do vvisely, Lady.

div.head: Scene 21.
div.stage: Enter Sir Golden Riches to Poor Virtue.

sp.speaker: SIr Gold. Rich.
sp.p: I vvish my tongue as smooth as oil, to make my vvords as soft as Air, that they may spread about your heart, there intermixd with your affection.

sp.speaker: Poor Virtue.
sp.p: Words cannot win my love, no more than wealth, nor is my heart subject to those infections.

sp.speaker: Sir Gold. Rich.
sp.p: I will build thee Palaces of burnish'd gold, where thou shalt be worshipd whilest thou livest, and when thou diest, I will erect a Monument more famous than Mausolus's was.

sp.speaker: Poor Verrtue.
sp.p: My Virtue shall build me a Monument far richer, and more lasting; for the materials with which it shall be built, shall be try'd Chastity, as pure Gold, and Innocency, as Marble white, and Constancy, as undissolving Diamonds, and Modesty, as Rubies red, Love shall the Altar be, and Piety, as Incense sweet, ascend to Heaven, Truth, as the Oil, shall feed the Lamp of Memory, whereby the flame of Fame shall never goe out.

sp.speaker: Sir Gold. Rich.
sp.p: And is She gone? are Riches of no force? Then I wil bury my self within the bowels of the Earth, so deep, that men shall never reach me, nor Light shall find me out.

div.head: Scene 22.
div.stage: Enter Mistris Messenger, and the Lady Amorous's woman, and Lord Courtship.

sp.speaker: MIstris Messenger.
sp.p: My Lord, my Lady, the Lady Amourous, remembers her Service to you, and sent me to tell you her Husband is gone out of Town, and She desires to have the happiness of your company.

sp.speaker: Lord Courtship.
sp.p: Pray present my Service in the humblest manner to your Lady, and pray her to excuse me; for though I cannot say I am sick, yet I am far from being well.

sp.speaker: Mistris Messen.
sp.p: I shall, my Lord.

div.head: Scene 23.
div.stage: Enter the Lord Title, and then enters a Servant to him.

sp.speaker: SErvant.
sp.p: My Lord, there is an old man without desires to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Direct him hither.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Old man, what have you to say to me?

sp.speaker: Old Humanity.
sp.p: I am come to desire your Lordship not to persecute a poor young Maid, one that is friendless, and your Lordship is powerful, and therefore dangerous.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: What poor Maid do you mean?

sp.speaker: Old Human.
sp.p: A Maid call'd Poor Virtue.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Do you know her?

sp.speaker: Old Human.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Are you her Father?

sp.speaker: Old Human.
sp.p: No, I am her servant, and have been maintain'd by her Noble Family these threescore years, and upwards.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Ha, her Noble Family! what, or who is She?

sp.speaker: Old Humanity.
sp.p: She is a Lady, born from a Noble Stock, and hath been choisely bred, but ruin'd by misfortunes, which makes her poorly serve.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Alas he weeps! Who were her Parents?

sp.speaker: Old Human.
sp.p: The Lord Morality, and the Lady Piety.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Sure it cannot be: But why should I doubt? her Beauty, Wit, and sweet Demeanour, declares her Noble Pedigree: The Lord Morality was a Famous man, and was a great Commander, and wise in making Lawes, and prudent for the Common Good: He was a Staff and Prop unto the Common-wealth, til Civil Wars did throw it down, where he fell under it. But honest friend, how shall I know this for a truth?

sp.speaker: Old Human.
sp.p: Did not your Lordship hear he had a Child?

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Yes that I did, an only Daughter.

sp.speaker: Old Human.
sp.p: This is She I mention, and if Times mend, will have her Fathers Estate, as being her Fathers Heir; but to prove it, and her Birth, I will bring all those servants that liv'd with her, and with her Father, and all his Tenants, that will witness the truth.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: When I consider, and bring her and her Actions to my minde, I cannot doubt the truth, and for the news, thou shalt be my Adopted Father, and my Bosome-friend; I'll be a staff for thy Old Age to lean upon, my shoulders shall give strength unto thy feeble limbs, and on my neck shalt lay thy restless head,

sp.speaker: Old Human.
sp.p: Heaven bless you, and I shall serve you as my Old Age will give me leave.

div.stage: Exit Lord Title, leading him forth.

div.head: Scene 24.
div.stage: Enter Lord Courtship, and the Lady VVard.

sp.speaker: LOrd Courts.
sp.p: Thou Celestial Creature, do not believe that I am so presumptuous to ask thy love, I only beg thy pardon, that when my body lies in the silent grave, you give my restless soul a pass, and leave to walk amongst sad Lovers in dark and gloomy shades; and though I cannot weep to shew my penitence, yet I can bleed.
Here, take this Instrument of Death, for only by your hands I wish to die.
sp.l: Give me as many Wounds as Pores in skin,
That I may bleed sufficient for my sin.

sp.speaker: Lady VVard.
sp.p: It seems strange to me, that you, a wise man, or at least accounted so, should fall into such extreams, as one while to hate me to death, and now to profess to love me beyond life!

sp.speaker: Lord Courts.
sp.p: My Debaucheries blinded my Judgment, nor did I know thy worth, or my own errour, until thy wise wit gave the light to my dark understanding, and you have drawn my bad life, and all my unworthy actions therein, so naturally in your discourse, as now I view them, I do hate my self as much as you have cause to hate me.

sp.speaker: Lady VVard.
sp.p: I only hate your Crimes, but for those excellent Qualities, and true Virtues that dwell in your Soul, I love and honour; and if you think me worthy to make me your Wife, and will love me according as my honest life will deserve your affections, I shall be proud of the Honour, and thank Fortune or Heaven for the Gift.

sp.speaker: Lord Courts.
sp.p: Sure you cannot love me, and the World would condemn you if you should, and all your Sex will hate you.

sp.speaker: Lady VVard.
sp.p: The World many times condemns even Justice her self, and women, for the most part, hate that they should love and honour.

sp.speaker: Lord Courts.
sp.p: But can you love me?

sp.speaker: Lady VVard.
sp.p: I can, and do love you.

sp.speaker: Lord Courts.
sp.p: How happy am I, to enjoy a world of Beauty, Wit, Virtue, and sweet Graces.

div.head: Scen. 25.
div.stage: Enter the Lord Title, and Roger Farmer, and Maudlin Huswife his Wife.

sp.speaker: LOrd Title.
sp.p:
Honest Roger and Maudlin,
This Scene was written by the Lord Marquiss of Newcastle. I present you with a kind Good-morrow.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Present me? Bless your Lordship, I should present you with a couple of Capons.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: 'Tis a salutation when you salute; but how do you then?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Very well, I thank your Honour: How do you?

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Well, enough of Complements, I am come with a Petition to you.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: What is that, is't please your Honour?

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: A Sute.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Byrlaken I have need of one, for I have but poor and bare cloathing on.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: No, Roger, it is a request and desire I have you should grant.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Grant, or to Farm let, no Sir, I will not part with my Lease.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Roger, you understand me not, therefore let me speak with Maudlin your Wife.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: There she is Sir, spare her not, for she is good metal I'll warrant your Honour; wipe your lips Maudlin, and answer him every time that he moves thee, and give him as good as he brings: Maudlin, were he twenty Lords, hold up your head, Maudlin, be not hollow.

sp.speaker: Maudlin.
sp.p: I'll warrant you Husband, I'll satisfie him.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Honest Maudlin.

sp.speaker: Maudlin.
sp.p: That's more than your Lordship knows.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Why then Maudlin.

sp.speaker: Maudlin.
sp.p: That's my name indeed.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: You have a maid here in your house.

sp.speaker: Maudlin.
sp.p: I hope so forsooth; but I will not answer for no Virgin in this wicked world.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Well said Maudlin; Nay your Honour will get nothing of my Maudlin, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Well, this supposed Maid is Poor Virtue, that's her name, I desire you will let her live with me, this Poor Virtue.

sp.speaker: Maudlin.
sp.p: God bless you Honour from her, it is not fit for a Lord, and a great Noble-man to meddle with Virtue, your Honour should not foul your fingers with her: Besides, she will never stay in a great mans house, neither is it fit she should; and your Honours servants will hate her like the Devil, for she will please no body as she should do, a very peevish, ill-natur'd girle forsooth she is.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Why how doth she agree then with you?

sp.speaker: Maudlin.
sp.p:
Alas forsooth, if it please your Honour, Virtue may live in a Cottage, when she will be whipt out of a Court, or a great Lords Palace; they may talk of her, but they will never give her leave to live and board with them: It may be they give their Chaplain leave to talk of her a Sundays, or so forsooth, but talk's but talk, for they forget her the six days after,
and never mind her; for indeed she is a very peevish girle, and not fit for Gentlefolks company, that's the truth of it, hardly for poor folks.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: VVhy you agree well with her?

sp.speaker: Maudlin.
sp.p: Nay by the faith of my body do I not; for I can hardly goe to Market, and be merry, as I use to be, and all long of her peevishnesse: nay I cannot goe to order one of our busie Thrashers, but she troubles me; or to speak with the Carter, but she whip, in presently, or discourse with the Plough-man about his plough-share, how he should order it for my advantage, but she troubles me; or about our Husbandman, how and where he should sow his Seed, but she vexes me still: Such a life, the Gods help me, as I am e'en weary of my self. Speak Roger, is it not true?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: True Maudlin as steel, I never was merry since she vvas in my house, the May-pole is dovvn since she came.

sp.speaker: Maudlin.
sp.p: I Roger that 'tis, the more the pity.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: And the Towns Green is a Meadow, and the poor Big-pipers cheeks are fallen into a Consumption, hardly wind to speak vvithall; the Morris-dancers bells are silenc'd, and their crosse garters held superstitious, idolatrous, and profane; the May-Lord and his Lady depos'd, and the Hobby-horse is forgotten; nay the Whitson-Lord and Lady are banish'd, Merry Wakes abolish'd, and the poor Ale-wives beggar'd,

sp.speaker: Maudlin.
sp.p: I, I, and all since this melancholy girle Virtue came into our house.
I cannot choose but cry.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Thou art true Maudlin then.

sp.speaker: Maudlin.
sp.p: Yes, with small beer, that's the calamity of it; therefore blesse every good subject from so melancholy a thing as this girle Virtue is: But we have a Daughter, and it please your Honours worship, that will give you good content, and please most of your Houshold; for she is a lusty Wench, though I say't that should not say't: Did you but see her swim like a Tench on our Town-green, incircling the May-pole, and at the end of a Horn-pipe, when she is to be kiss'd, how modestly the wryes her head away, but so as to be civil; nay she hath been well Educated, my own natural Daughter, for indeed Roger, I was with Child with her before you maried me.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Peace Maudlin, all Truths are not to be spoken of; for should that be, many a Worshipful Person would be very angry; but our Vicar made all well betwixt thee and me, Maudlin: But I beseech your Honour take my Daughter, for you will find her another manner of woman than Virtue is, for she is not like her ifaith, nor any thing that belongs to her, she is better blest than so.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: No, I will have Poor Virtue, or none.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Faith if you have Virtue, you are sure to have her poor, for I never knew any of her Family rich, the Gods do not blesse them, I think, in this world; but if you will have her, take her, shall he not, Maudlin?

sp.speaker: Maudlin.
sp.p:
Yes, Husband, and the house is well rid of her, and let us bless our selves for it; for now we shall be like our Neighbours again, we will not abate them an hair, the best in the Parish shall not live merryer than we will now for all Sports: Why, Vanity and Sin, Husband, is the Liberty of the Subject, and the seven Deadly Sins are the Fundamental Laws of the Kingdome, from the greatest to the least, if poor folks might have their right. Well, your Honour shall have her, but you will be as weary of her as we have been, the Gods bless your Honour, but alas you do not know what this
Girle Virtue is, Lords have no guess at her.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Well Maudlin, let me have her, I desire no more.

sp.speaker: Maudlin.
sp.p: Nor we neither, if it pleases your Honour, and so the Gods give you good of her.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Let me speak to his Honour, Maudlin.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: Do so Roger.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: I give yourdship many thanks.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: For ridding our house of this troublesome Girl.

sp.speaker: Lord Title,
sp.p: And I thank you for it too.

p.hi: VVhen thanks on all sides happen, we are eas'd.

sp.speaker: Lord Title.
sp.p: And I with your Poor Virtue am well pleas'd.

div.stage: As they were going forth, Maudlin speaks.

sp.speaker: Maudlin.
sp.p: Mark the end of it, Roger.

sp.speaker: Roger.
sp.p: Yes Maudlin, the End Crowns the Work.

div.stage: Here ends my Lord Marquiss's Scene.

div.head: Scene. 26.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Visitant to the Lady Contemplation, who was musing to her self.

sp.speaker: LAdy Visit.
sp.p: What always musing? Shall I never find thee in a sociable humour?

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p: I would you had come sooner, or stayd longer away.

sp.speaker: Lady Visit.
sp.p: Why prethee?

sp.speaker: Lady Contempl.
sp.p:
I will tell you: A while since, there came the Muses to visit me, being all either mad, or drunk, for they toss'd and tumbl'd me, and rumbl'd me about, from one to the other, as I thought they would a divided me amongst them: At last came in the Sciences to visit me, with sober Faces, grave Countenances, stayd and formal Behaviours, and after they had Saluted me, they began to talk very seriously to me, their Discourse being Rational, Probable, Wise, Learned, and Experienc'd; but all the while the Muses would not let me alone, one pull'd me to Dance, another to Sing, another to play on Musick, others to recite Verses, speak Speeches, and Act parts of Plays, and the like â€¢ Whereupon I gravely turned the incorporal head of my rational Soul, nodding it to them to be quiet, and let me alone, but still they playd with me: At last my Thoughts, which are the language of the Soul, spoke to them, and pray'd them to forbear, until such time as the Sciences were gone; but they would not be quiet, nor silent, doe
what I could, but would interrupt the Sciences in the midst of their Discourse, with their idle Rimes, light Fancies, and odd Numbers, insomuch as the Sciences departed: Whereupon the Muses did rejoyce, and skip, and run about, as if they had been wilde: And in this jocund humour, in came the Arts, even a whole Common-wealth; for there were not only Politick Arts, Civil and Combining Arts, Profitable and necessary Arts, Military Arts, and Ceremonious Arts; but there were Superstitious Arts, Idolatrous Arts, false, factious, and mischievous Arts, destructive and wicked Arts, base and mean Art, foolish, childish, vain, superfluous and unprofitable Arts: Upon all these Arts the Muses made good sport; for at some they flung jests, scorns, and scoffs, and some they stripp'd naked, but to others they were cruel, for some they stayd their skins off, and others they made very Skeletons of, dissecting them to the very bones;
