sp.speaker: INquisitive.
sp.p: One witty word, or saying from a fool, is, for the most part remembred, and often repeated, when from a Wit it would be hardly taken notice of.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: There is reason for that: for wit is more remarkable from fools, than those that have natural wits.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Monsieur Satyrical, I am come with a Message from a company of fair young Ladies; the Message is this: They desire that you would do them the favour to come to them, to judge of a Poem which they have made amongst themselves.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Women make Poems? burn them, burn them; let them make bone-lace, let them make bone-lace.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: You are an unjust Judge, to condemn their Poems to the fire, before you have examin'd them.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: The best tryal of a Ladies wit is the fire; besides, the fire will supply that want of Poetical heat which should make Poems, which heat womens brains cannot suffer.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: You are mistaken Sir, and mis-inform'd: for we women have as hot brains as any of the Masculine Sex of you all have.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I grant your Sex have an unnatural heat, which makes them all mad.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I think the Ladies were mad when they sent me for you.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: No doubt of it, and you are mad for coming.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Your words will make me mad before I go away, although I came well-temper'd hither: beshrew me my very bones do quiver in my flesh to hear you.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: If thy bones quiver so much as to shake, they will soon powder into dust: for Age hath almost dissolv'd thee into ashes already, and Time hath eaten off thy flesh, as Crows do carrion.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Out upon thee Satyr, a beastly man you are by my Troth, and so I will deliver you to the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: You shall not deliver me to the Ladies, I will deliver my self to Death first.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Thou art so bad, Death will refuse thee: but I will do your Errand I'll warrant you, I'll set a mark upon you that shall disgrace you.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Thou canst not set a fouler mark than thy self upon me, therefore come not near me.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Worse and worse, worse and worse. O that I were so young and fair, as my Beauty might get me a Champion to revenge my quarrel! But I will go back to the Ladies, they are fair and young enough, as being in the Spring of Beauty, although I am in my Autumnal years.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Thou art in the midst of the Winter of thine Age, and the Snow of Time is fallen on thy head, and lies upon thy hair.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: They that will not live untill they are old, the Proverb sayes, They must be hang'd when they are young, and I hope it is your Destiny.

div.head: Scene 24.
div.stage: Enter Liberty, and Wanton, and Surfet.

sp.speaker: LIberty.
sp.p: I am come to tell you, Wanton and Surset, that my Lady is gone to receive the Visit of Monsieur Tranquillities Peace, who is come to see her, and old Matron Temperance is gone to wait upon her; wherefore you may go, for there is none left with the five Senses but Excess.

div.stage: They run out, then enters the Five Senses in Antick Dresses, to distinguish them, but they behave themselves as mad-merry, dancing about in Couples, as Hearing with Wantonness, Idle with Scent, and Excess with Sigh, and Surfet with Taste, and Touch dances alone by her self, and when they have danced, they go out.

div.head: Scene 25.
div.stage: Enter Bon' Esprit, Superbe, Faction, Portrait, Ambition.

sp.speaker: FAction.
sp.p: I wonder Mother Matron should stay so long.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: I cannot guess at the reason.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: She might have deliver'd her Message twice in this time.

div.stage: Enter Mother Matron; All the Ladies speak at once.

sp.speaker: Ladies
sp.p: Mother Matron, Welcome, welcome, welcome: What Newes? what Newes?

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: What says Monsieur Satyrical?

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Will he come?

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Or will he not come? pray speak.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Are you dumb, Mother Matron?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Pray Ladies give me some time to temper my passion; for if a house be set on fire, there is required sometime to quench it.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: But some fires cannot be quenched.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Indeed my fire of Anger is something of the nature of the unquenchable fire of Hell, which indeavours to afflict the Soul, as well as to torment the Body.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Iove bless us, Mother Matron! Are you inflamed with Hellfire?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: How should I be otherwise, when I have been tormented with a Devil?

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Jupiter keep us! What have you done, and with whom have you been?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Marry I have been with a cloven-tongu'd Satyr, who is worse, far worse, than a cloven-footed Devil.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Is all this rage against Monsieur Satyrical?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Yes marry is it, and all too little, by reason it cannot hurt him.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: How hath he offended you?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: As he hath offended you all, railed against you, most horribly railed against you: He says you are all mad, and hath condemned your Poems to the fire, and your imployment to the making of bone-lace.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Why these sayings of his do not offend me.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Nor me.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Nor me.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Nor me.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: But if he had said you had been old, and ill-favour'd, carrion for Crows, dust and ashes for the grave, as he said to me, then you would have been as angry as I.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: No truly, I should have only laughed at it.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: By your favour, I should have been as angry as Mother Matron, if I had been as old as she; so I should have been concerned in the behalf of my Age.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Marry come up, are you turned Lady Satyrical, to upbraid me with my Age? Is this my reward for my jaunting and trotting up and down with your idle Message to more idle persons, men that are meer Jackstraws, flouting companions, railing detractors, such as are good for nothing but to put people together by the cars?

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: By the Effects it proves so, for you and I are very neer falling out: But I thought you would have given me thanks for what I said, as taking your part, and not inveterates your spleen.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Can you expect I should give you thanks for calling me old? Can the report of Age be acceptable to the Effeminate Sex? But Lady, let me tell you, if you live you will be as old as I, and yet desire to be thought young: For although you were threescore, yet you would be very angry, nay in a furious rage, and take those to be your mortal Enemies that should reckon you to be above one and twenty, for you will think your self as beautiful as one of fifteen.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: I do not think so, although I believe our Sex have good opinions of themselves, even to the last gasp; yet not so partial, as to imagine themselves as one of fifteen at threescore.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: It is proved by all Experience, that all Mankind is self-conceited, especially the Effeminate Sex; and self-conceit doth cast a fair shadow on a foul face, and fills up the wrinkles of Time with the paint of Imagination.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: But the Eyes must be blind with Age, or else they would see the wrinkles Time hath made, in the despight of the paint of Imagination.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p:
By your favour, Self-conceit doth cause the Eyes of Sense to be like false glasses, that cast a youthful gloss, and a fair light, on a wither'd skin: For though the deep lines in the face cannot be smoothed, yet the lines, or species, in, or of the sight, may be drawn by self-conceit so small as not to be perceived: And were it not for the Eyes of Self-conceit, and the Paint of Imagination, as Mother Matron says, which preserves a good Opinion
of our selves, even to the time of our Death, wherein all remembrance is buried, we should grow mad, as we grow old, for the losse of our Youth and Beauty.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I by my faith you would grow mad, did not Conceit keep you in your right wits.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: The truth is, our Sex grow melancholy, when our Beauty decayes.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: I grow melancholy at the talking of it.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Let us speak of some other subject that is more pleasing than Age, Ruine, and Death.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Let us talk of Monsieur Satyrical again.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: He is a worse subject to talk of than Death.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: As bad as he is, you shall carry another Message to him.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I will sooner carry a Message to Pluto; for in my Conscience he will use me more civilly, and will send you a more respectful Answer than Monsieur Satyrical.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Indeed I have heard that the Devil would flatter; but I never heard that a Satyrical Poet would flatter.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: But a Satyrical Poet will lye, and so will the Devil; and therefore talk no more of them, but leave them together.

div.head: Scene 26.

sp.speaker: PLeasure.
sp.p: O Temperance, I am discredited for ever, the Ladies the Senses are all sick: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: You must send for some Doctors.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: What Doctors shall I send for?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Why Old Father Time, he hath practiced long, and hath great Experience; then there is Rest and Sleep, two very good & safe Doctors.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Send Ease presently to fetch them, bid her make haste.

div.stage: Enter the five Senses, as being very sick, yet Touch seems not so sick as melancholy: They all pass silently over the Stage.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Temperance, are the Doctors come?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Yes, and gone again.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: And what have they prescribed?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Abstinence.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: And will that cure them?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: They say it will prove a perfect cure: Probatum est.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: The next act I do, shall be to turn away Wanton, Idle, Excess, and Surfet.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: You will hardly get them out of your Service, although you should beat them out.

div.head: Scene 27.
div.stage: Enter Madamoiselle Ambition, and her Waiting-woman.

sp.speaker: VVOman.
sp.p: Madam, me thinks Monsieur Vain-glorious is a very proper man, and would be a fit Match for your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p:
Let me tell you, I will never marry a man whose Soul hath Vacuum; but that man I would marry, should have a soul filled with Natures best Extractions; his Head the Cabinet of Natures wisest Counsels, and curiousest Fancies; his Heart the Treasury of Natures purest, currentest, and Heroick Virtue: For if ever I marry, I will have a Husband that is able to govern Kingdoms, to Marshal Armies, to Fight Battels, and Conquer Nations; and not a self-conceited Fool, or fantastical Gallant, such as speaks ta â€¢
ing Words, wears slanting Cloaths, walks with a proud Garb, looks with a disdainful Countenance, Courts Mistrisses, loves Flatteries, hates Superiors, and scorns Inferiors, keeps a greater Retinue than his Revenue will maintain, who like moths, eat through the cloth of his Estate, and he like another â€¢â€¢ , plays so long in his Vain-glorious Flame, until he is consumed therein, spanding with an open purse, and prodigal vanity, and yet receives with a covetous hand: So Vanity flies and flutters about in the heat of Prosperity, and dies in the Winter of Adversity. No, I will have a Husband, if ever I have any, whose Minde is settled like the Centre, which can neither rise nor fall with good or bad Fortune; and not a little Soul in a narrow Heart, and witless Brain.

div.head: Scene 28.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Satyrical, and another Gentleman.

sp.speaker: GEntlem.
sp.p: Sir, I desire you will pardon me; but I am commanded to bring you here a Challenge.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Are you the Second, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gentlem.
sp.p: No Sir.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Are you a Pimp, Sir?

sp.speaker: Gentlem.
sp.p: I scorn your base words, for I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Many a Gentleman scorns base words, but not base Actions.

sp.speaker: Gentlem.
sp.p: I scorn both base words, and base Actions.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: It doth not seem so by the Challenge you have brought.

sp.speaker: Gentlem.
sp.p: Why, what is the Challenge?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: The Challenge is from a Woman, and I will read it to you.

body.l: I Challenge you, and am resolv'd to fight,
Not in the Field of Mars, as Champion Knight,
Nor in the Court of Venus will I be,
But to the Lists of Mercury Challenge thee:
Where all the Muses will Spectators sit,
To Iudge which is the great'st Victor of Wit.
The Weapons which we fight with must be Words,
For I a woman am, not us'd to Swords:
Custome and Education leaves us bare
To Natures Arms, the Arms of Death we fear.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: These two last Lines make you a Pimp, Sir.

sp.speaker: Gentlem.
sp.p: I must be contended, for there is no Revenge to be taken against Ladies: But Mother Matron had been a more properer Messenger than I for this Challenge.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I shall send my Answer by a more inferiour person than you are, and so shall take my leave for this time.

sp.speaker: Gentlem.
sp.p: Your Servant.

div.head: Scene 29.
div.stage: Enter Madamoiselle Bon' Esprit, Portrait, Faction, Ambition, Superbe.

sp.speaker: FAction.
sp.p: All Poets and Musicians are mad, more or less: for Madness is caused by a distemper of the Brain, like as the Pulse, which beats quicker than the natural motion.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: You mistake madness; for madness is not caused by the quickness of motion, but by the irregularity of the motion: And as for Poetical and Musical Motions, although they are quick, yet they keep Time, Time and Order, when those Motions that cause madness do not: But the quick-moving brains of Poets are caused by their lively & elevated Spirits, which are Active and Industrious, always creating for delight or profit, as Verses, Fancies, Scenes, Sonnets, or inventing Arts: And if you account these Ingenious and Divine Spirits to be mad, I shall desire to be mad too, as they are.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: But some Spirits are so quick, that they out run all Invention.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p:
Those are neither the spirits of Poets nor Musicians; not but that Poets and Musicians may be mad as other men, but their madness is not
caused by the Poetical and Harmonical spirits, but some other defects of the brain, or distemper of the spirits; but there are many mad, that are so far from Poetical Fancies, or Musical skill, or Inventions, as they can neither conceive the one, or learn the other, or understand either; but Musick and Poetry have oft-times cured madness, and certainly are the best and most excellent Physicians for that disease: For though madness is but one and the same disease, as madness, yet the Causes and Effects are divers.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: A Feaver in the Brain causeth madness.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: It rather causeth madness to have outragion: Effects; but a cold brain may be mad: But it is neither heat nor cold that causeth madness, but the irregularity of the Spirits.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: But heat and cold may cause the irregularity of the Spirits: for as cold Livers make the Veins like standing ponds, which putrifies the blood for want of motion; so very cold Brains may be like Snow or Ice, to obstruct or bind the Spirits, hindring the regular motions.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: You say right, and that is a stupid madness: And as a hot Liver may boyl and inflame the blood, so hot Brains may inflame the Spirits, causing Combustious Motions, as Thundring, which is a raging madnesse.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Who is raging-mad?

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: A despairing Lover.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Hang him in his Mistris Frowns, or strangle him in the Cords of her Cruelty.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Would you be served so?

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Yes, when I am a mad Lover: For I had rather die than be in love with a hard-hearted Mistris; for of the two I had rather imbrace death than Court her, in which Courtship I should be Transform'd, or Metamorphos'd into many several things: As I should be a River of Lovers Tears, a Ventidock of Lovers Sighs, an Aquaduct of Lovers Griefs, and a Chilling grotto of Lovers Fears; and rather than I would endure these Transformations, I would be well contended to be annihilated.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: O fie, had you rather be nothing than a Lover?

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: I had rather be nothing, than a thing worse than nothing.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Well, I hope to see you a desperate Lover at one time or other.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: I hope not, for I have no cause to fear: for my Mind cannot be perswaded by my Fancy, or forced by my Appetites, nor betrayed by my Senses; for Reason governs my Brain, Temperance rules my Appetites, Prudence guards my Senses, and Fortitude keeps the possession and Fort of my Heart.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Love will unthrone Reason, corrupt Temperance, bribe Prudence, and bear Fortitude out of the Fort of your Heart.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: For fear of that I will leave you, Ladies.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: News; News, Monsieur Satyrical hath vouchsaf'd to return you an Answer to your Challenge.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Who brought it?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: A scrubbed fellow in a thred-bare cloak, the rest of the Ladies say. Read it, read it, Madamoiselle Bon' Esprit.
sp.l: Lady, you Challeng'd me in Arms to fight,
Appoint the place, the best time is at night
For Natural Duellers; yet I submit,
And shall obey to what hour you think fit:
I am content my Health for to engage,
And venture Life to satisfie your rage.
I am no Coward, I am not afraid
To fight a Duel with a young fair Maid,
Although old Mother Matron she should be
Your Second, for the Iudge what she doth see.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: He makes me the scurvy burthen of his more scurvy Verse, and scurrilous Answer: But I hope this Answer of his to your Challenge, will inveterate your spleen as much as his upbraiding my Age did mine.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: I have not such reason to be so concern'd as you are; for I am honest, though you are old.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: May the Infamy of Vice wither the Blossoms of Youth, as Age doth the Flowers of Beauty, that there may be an equal return of Reproach.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Indeed there is some Reciprocalness in Vice and Age.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: No, Vice and Youth are Reciprocal.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: But I see no Reciprocalnesse betwixt Love and Monsieur Satyrical.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: I make no doubt but to bring Monsieur Satyrical into Cupid's snare.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: You may sooner bring your self into Vulcan's Net.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Well, mark the end and success.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Nay, rather we shall mark the endless folly.

div.head: Scene 30.
div.stage: Enter Madamoiselle Pleasure, and Monsieur Vain-glorious.

sp.speaker: VAin-glorious.
sp.p: Lady Pleasure, you are the swetest young Lady in the World, and the only delight in life.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: O Sir, you give a Wooers sentence, and self-love hath bribed your Judgment: for most speak partially, according to their Affections, and not according to Truth.

sp.speaker: Vain-glor.
sp.p: Truth is a prating, preaching, tatling, twatling Gossip, and tells many times that which would be better conceal'd.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Truth is the Eye of Knowledge, which brings men out of Ignorance: It is the Scale of Justice, the Sword of Execution, the Reward of Merit: It is the Bond of Propriety, and the Seal of Honesty.

sp.speaker: Vain-glor.
sp.p: Truth is a Tyrant, condemning more than she saves.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: She condemns none but Fools, Knaves, Cowards, Irreligious, Licentious, and Vain-glorious persons, to be unworthy, base, false, and wicked.

sp.speaker: Vain-glorious.
sp.p: She condemns Pleasure; for truly there is no such thing as Pleasure.

sp.speaker: SAtyrical.
sp.p:
I must marry, or bury succession in my Grave; but it's dangerous, very dangerous. O Nature, Nature, hadst thou no other way to Create a man, unless thou mad'st a woman! But if thou wert forc'd by the Fates to make that Sex, yet thou hadst liberty to make her of a constant Mind; but thou art inconstant thy self, as being of female kind: But since I must marry, Discretion shall make the Choise, which will choose Virtue before Wealth, Wit before Beauty, Breeding before Birth; if she hath Virtue, she will be Chaste; if she hath Wit, she will be Conversable, if she hath good Breeding, she will be modest and well-behav'd. But where is that woman that is virtuously Chaste, wittily Conversable, and Modestly-behav'd? If any woman be thus, as I would have her, it is Madamoiselle Bon' Esprit, she seems to have a Noble Soul by her Honourable Actions, which women, for the most part, are so far from, as they seem, for the most part, to have no souls at all, by their mean and petty actions: Also she hath a Supernatural Wit, I mean supernatural, as being a woman; and her Wit is not only Ingenious, but Judicious, by which she will set a value on subjects of Merit and Worth, and despise those that are base; when fools know not how to prize the best, but chuse that is bad, not knowing what is good, so walk in Errours ways, which leads unto dishonour; but she, having Wit and Honour, knows the benefit of Honesty so well, as she will be Chaste for her own sake, were it not for her Husbands. But I most satyrically have translated her sweet and harmless mirth, which was presented in her Elevated Verse into a wanton Interpretation. Diana, thou Goddess of Chastity, pardon me! But stay thoughts, whither wander you? let me examine you before you pass any farther, as whether or no you are not led by the bow-string of Cupid, or the girdle of Venus, into the foul paths of vain desires, and del â€¢
ding beauty, to the labyrinth of destruction, there to be kept and incaptivated by the intanglements and subtill windings, and turnings, and various passages of Amorous Love? But a strict Examination requires Time, and a just
Judge decides not a Cause without Debate; therefore I will have another Contemplation of Consideration, before I address my Sute, or make known my Desires.

div.head: Scene 32.
div.stage: Enter Madamoiselle Ambition, and Monsieur Vain glorious.

sp.speaker: VAin-glor.
sp.p: Madam, why should you refuse me?

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Because I cannot love.

sp.speaker: Vain-glor.
sp.p: Not love me? why I am Valiant, Wise, Witty, Honest, Generous, and Handsome: And where will you find a man where all these Excellencies do meet in one?

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Now you have bragg'd of your self, I will plainly prove to you, that you are neither perfectly Valiant, nor Wise, nor Witty, nor Generous, nor truly Honest.

sp.speaker: Vain-glor.
sp.p: You cannot.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: I can: And first for Valour. Have you gone to the Wars, and fought? why, millions do the like, and a poor Common Souldier will venture for sixpence on that which a vain Cavalier will hardly do to gain an immortal Fame: Or peradventure you have fought Duels, why every Drunkard will do as much, who in their drink they not reason to consider Valour, which is only to fight for the sake of Honour; but most commonly Duels are fought through Anger, or Fear, or Scorn, or Revenge, or the like, which is not true valour, but they fight rather like beasts than men, as with Force, Fury, or Appetite, caused by natural Antipathies, or through the heat of the blood, or desires or dislikes of the Senses: whereas true Valour is just, temperate, patient, prudent, and is the Heroick part, or Virtue of the Soul: And to be valiant, is to fight for the right of Truth, and the defence of Innocency, without Partiality, Covetousness, or Ambition: Also to prove your self Valiant, have you received misfortunes with patience, and suffred torments with fortitude? Have you forgiven your Enemies, or spared a bloody Execution for humanities sake, or releas'd rich prisoners without Ransome, and poor without slavery? Have you heard your self slanderd with Patience, justify'd your wrongs with Temperance, fought your Enemies without Anger, maintained your Honour without Vain-glory, then you are Valiant.

And for Wisedome, what do you call Wisedome? to speak Hebrew, Greek, and Latine, and not understand them? or to understand them, and cannot speak them? Or to cite dead Authors? Or to repeat their Learned Opinions? Or to make Sophisterian Disputes? Or to speak Latine Sentences? Or to tell stories out of Histories? Or to write several Hands? Or to spell with true Orthography? Or to talk of the Sciences, but study none? Or to talk of Morality, but practice none? This you may call Learned, but not Wisedome. But to be Wise, Have you settled a Kingdome in peace, and put it in order, when it was imbrovled with Civil Wars, or insnared with confused and intangled Laws? Or have you appeased a mutinous and half-starv'd Army? Have you led an Army with Order, pitchd a Field with Art,
fought a Battel with Prudence, or have made a safe and honourable Retreat? Or have you been so provident, as to relieve Famine with fore-stor'd provisions? Or to prevent misfortunes with fore-sight? Or have you distinguished a Cause clearly, or given an upright Judgment? Or have you delivered judicious Counsel, and given seasonable and suitable Admonitions? Have you composed a Common-wealth, or made profitable Laws to uphold a Common-wealth? Have you defended a Common-wealth from Enemies, or purged a Common-wealth from Factions? Have you made Officers worthy of Imployments, Magistrates able to Govern, Souldiers skilful to Command? Have you sitly matched men and business, and offices with men? Have you imploy'd the idle, and given light to the ignorant? Have you discharged a Common-wealth of Superfluity, or superfluous Commodities, and brought in those which are more useful, such as they have wanted? Have you Manured a barren Country, or inrich'd a poor Kingdome? Have you made honest Associats, faithful Agreements, and safe Traffiques? Then you may think your self Wise, and be silent; for the Actions will proclame it.

Also what do you call Wit? Imitating Extravagancies like a Jackanapes, or a Buffoon, to extort the Countenance with making wry faces? Or with much laughter to shew the teeth, which perchance are all rotten in the head? Or foolishly to divulge the infirmities of particular persons in an open Assembly? Or putting Innocency or Youth out of Countenance? Or to disturb the Serious with idle Sports? Or disorder the Wise with foolish and rude Jests? Or do you all Wit affected Dresses, affected Garbs, affected Countenances, or vain-straind Complements, or uselesse Words, or senslesse Speeches, or crosse Answers, or impertinent Questions? But for your Wit, Hath your Fame flown beyond Euripides, Homer, or Ovid, your Descriptions beyond Horace, or your Verse beyond Virgil? Have you Oratory to equal the Orators of Athens, Lacedemonians, or Rome? or have you devised any Ingenious Inventions, or produced any profitable Arts, or found out any new Sciences? Then you are Witty.

Likewise what do you call Honesty? to live luxuriously to your self, not medling, nor intermingling your self and home-Affairs with the publick Affairs of the World? To keep open House at Christmass? To give your scraps to the poor? To pay Wages duly, Debts justly, Taxes quietly? To kisse your Maids privatly? And although all this is good and commendable, but the kissing of your Maids, yet it is not enough to make a perfect honest man: But to be perfectly honest, Have you temperd your unfatiable Appetite with Abstinency, moderated your violated passions with Reason, governed your unruly actions with Prudence? Have you not exacted unjustly, judged partially, accused falsly, betrayed treacherously, kept wrongfully, took forcibly? but have you advanced Virtues, defended the Innocent? Have you witnessed for Truth, pleaded for Right, and stood for the defenceless? Then you are perfectly Honest.

Also what do you call Generosity? To give a present to a lewd Mistris? To bribe a corrupted Judge? Or fee a subtil Lawyer? Or feast the vain Courtiers? Or maintain Sycophants and Flatterers? Or Bail a just Arrest? Or to be bound for the Deboist? Or to give Ladies Collations? Or to lend or give idle drunken fellows money? Or to give when you think to hear of it again? This is Prodigality, not Generosity. But to be Generous, Have you set your prisoner free, Ransomed the Captives, or bought off the chains
of the Gally-slaves? Have you maintained young Orphans, or helped poor Widows? Have you cheered the Aged, nourished the Hungry, succoured the Infirm, relieved the Distressed, comforted the Sorrowful, and guided the Ignorant? Or have you upholden an Antient Family from sinking? Then you are Generous.

As for your Person, the more Handsome and Beautiful you are, the more Effeminate you seem. But to conclude, That man that hath a narrow Heart, and a mean Soul, that only seeks his own delights, which all vain-glorious persons do, I will not marry: For Noble Ambition hath a heart, whose veins with bounty flow, and wears her life only for Honours use and Virtues need.

div.head: Scene 33.
div.stage: Enter Grave Temperance, Superbe, Bon' Esprit, Faction, Portrait.

sp.speaker: TEmperance.
sp.p: There is no behaviour so inconvenient, or so unfitting a woman, especially a young beautiful Lady, as to be familiar: for that gives way and liberty for men to be rude and uncivil.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Why how would you have a young Lady to behave her self?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Modestly, reservedly, and civilly, which behaviour will keep men in order, and at a distance.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: To seem very modest, is to appear simple; to be much reserved, is to be formal, which is only fit for State-Ladies; to be very civil, is to be too humble, and appears mean, and only fit for Country wives.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: No Lady, for those that give no respect, will receive none; but those that are civil to others, others will be civil to them: for they will be ashamed to be rude to those that are civil: And as for Gravity, it puts Boldness out of countenance, and Modesty quenches unlawful desires, converting the beholders to Purity, Love, and Esteem.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: There is no behaviour like to the French Mode, to be careless and free, to discourse in Raillery.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: To be careless, is to be rude; to be free, is to be wanton; to raillery, is to reproach under the protection of wit, it is a reproachful Wit, and a wit of Reproach.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: All wit is commendable.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: No Lady, a Jesters wit is not fit for a grave Judge, or a great Prince, he may keep a Fool, or make a Fool to make him merry, and to laugh at their Jests and Gestures, but not to be a Buffoon or Jester himself.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p:
Let me advise and counsel you, Temperance, which is, to condemn
no kind of Wit, but especially a Mode-Wit, lest you should be accounted a foolish Judge.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Let me tell you, they will be the greatest Fools that judge the Judge.

sp.speaker: SAtyrical.
sp.p: I am resolv'd, yet being a Criminal, how to address my Sute, I am in doubt: To ask pardon for my faults, were to make my faults seem greater than they are; to excuse them, were to make my judgment seem weaker than I think it is; to justifie them, were to condemn her. Well, I will neither ask pardon, nor make excuse, nor yet justifie them; but in plain language declare my pure Affections, honest Desires, and honourable Requests; if she believes the first, approves the third, and consents to the second, I hope to be happy, if not, I must be content: for it is a folly to mourn, when it brings no remedy.

div.head: Scene 35.
div.stage: Enter Bon' Esprit, Portrait, Faction, Ambition, Superbe, Mother Matron,

sp.speaker: FAction.
sp.p: The Lady Variety, now she is a Widow, she tricks and dresses up her self in her Mourning, and is more fond of the company of men, than we that are Maids.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: 'Tis a sign she knows by Experience that the Masculine Sex are better, and more pleasurable company than any of her own Sex, which Maids do not know, by reason they are for the most part restrain'd.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Why should you find fault with Widows, when maried Wives indeavour by all the Arts they can to get the company of men, and do strive by inticements to allure them to Courtships, as much as Widows or Maids to lawful and honest Mariage?

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: One would think that maried women, by their neglect and disrespect to their Husbands, they loved not the company of men.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: They may love the company of men, though not the company of one man, as their Husbands.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Come, come, Ladies, Maids are always spiteful to Maried Women, because they be preferred in Mariage before them, and are jealous of Widows, for fear that they should get their Servants and Suters from them.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p:
I should sooner be jealous of a Widow, than spightful to a Maried Wife: for most Wives are in a condition to be pity'd rather than envy'd;
but Widows have such a magnetick power, as one Widow will draw away the Servants and Suters from a dozen Maids.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Indeed Widows are very prevalent; for a poor widow shall have more Suters, and better Choice, than a rich Maid, and an ill-favour'd Widow, than a handsome Maid, an old Widow, than a young Virgin.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: I wonder at it.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Why should you wonder at it? since they know the humours, weaknesses, and strengths of men, better than Maids do, by which they know how to work and draw them to their bent and design.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: No, that's not the Cause.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: What's the Cause then?

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Why men think VVidows wiser than Maids, as being more known and experienc'd.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Indeed they have more knowledge than Maids, or else they have very ill luck.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: VVhy, Maids are more desirous to marry VVidowers than Batchelours.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: VVhat is the reason of that?

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: I know not, except it be the former reason.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: No, no, it is because it is said that VVidowers love their second wives better than the first.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: And what their third wife?

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: I suppose Love increaseth with the number.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: But women, 'tis said, love their first husband better than the second.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: That's only an excuse to marry a third, and so a fourth Husband.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Indeed Death and Hymen are great friends to VVidows and VVidowers: for if once a woman buries her husband, or a man his wife, they never leave marying and burying, until they have had five or six husband and wives.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: If it were always so, I would I had been maried, and had buried my husband; O what a Gossipping life should I have had! Gossipping at my husbands Funerals, and Gossipping at my Maried Nuptials, besides the pleasure of being woo'd.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: But you would have more trouble and vexation in the time between your Mariage-day and your Husbands Death, than pleasure betwixt your Husbands Death and Mariage-day.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: O no: for I suppose if Death be a friend, he will take away every Husband as soon as that time is past they call Hony-moneth.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: Ladies, I will tell you News.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: What News?

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: The young Widow, the Lady Variety, hath the Small Pox.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: That's no Newes; for all sorts of Diseases are too frequent to be News; If they were, it would be happy for all animal creatures, if diseases were strangers.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: But it is News that she should have them.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p:
It is in respect of a new face, or otherwise not: for all mankind
in these parts of the World have that disease at one time or other, if they live to't.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: Truly I pity her.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: I hope she is not in such a condition to be pitied: for pity is a kin to scorn, as near as Cousin-germans, for reproach and shame are brother and sister, and scorn is the son of reproach, and pity is the daughter of shame: But although the Small Pox may set marks of deformity, they set none of dishonour; they only mark the Body, not the Soul; and that is only to be accounted shame, and to be asham'd of, as the infirmities of the Soul, for which they may be pitied.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: That deserves scorn.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Baseness only deserves scorn, and not infirmities, loss, or misfortunes; but there is a difference betwixt infirmities, losse, misfortunes, baseness, and wickedness. Infirmities proceed directly from Nature, Losse from Possession, Misfortunes from Interpositions, Baseness from that creature called Man, and Wickedness from Devils: The first is caused by the carelesness of Nature, the second by the lack of Power, the third by the necessity of Fate, the fourth by the corruption of Man, the last by the perswasion and temptation of the Devil. The first, second, and third are not to be avoided, the fourth not to be practised, the fifth not to be followed nor fostered. The first is to be pitied, the second to be grieved for, the third to be lamented for, the fourth to be scorned, and the fifth to be hated and abhorred. Thus we may grieve for the loss of her Beauty, but not pity her, having no natural defect in the Soul, which is the Understanding, and the Rational part.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: But Sickness is a natural defect.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: No, Sickness is no more a natural defect, than Time, or Death, Life, or Growth: for they are only Natural Effects, but not Natural Defects.

div.head: Scene 36.
div.stage: Enter Madamoiselle Pleasure, Wanton, Surfet, Idle, Excess, her Maids: They all weep.

sp.speaker: ALl speak.
sp.p: Pray turn us not out of your Service for one fault.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Why you are the ground wherein all Mischief is sown, and whereon all Vice grows; besides, you are the only Bawds for Adultery.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: No indeed, the chief Bawds to Adultery, are publick Meetings of all kinds, either Divine, Customary, Triumphant, or Recreative: Also Bravery, whether Ceremonious Gallantry, or Magnificency: Likewise Beauty, Wit, Diligence, Observance, and rich Presents: besides Jealousie and Covetousness.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: No, Wanton, it is your glancing Eyes, simpering Countenance, and toyish Tricks.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p:
Truly Madam, Idle and I are fitter to make Wenches than Bawds,
'tis your Ladyship that is the Lady of Pleasure, which perswades more to Adultery than we poor harmless creatures.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Go get you out of my house, for I will not keep such bold rude Wenches as you are.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Pray Madam pardon them for this time.

div.head: Scene 37.
div.stage: Enter Madamoiselle Ambition, Superbe, Faction, Pleasure, Portrait, Monsieur Heroick, Monsieur Tranquillities Peace, Monsieur Frisk, Monsieur Censure, Monsieur Inquisitive.

sp.speaker: PLeasure.
sp.p: How shall we pass our time to day?

sp.speaker: Tranquill. Peace.
sp.p: For us men we cannot pass our time better, or more pleasanter, than in the company of fair young Ladies.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: To avoid tedious Complements and Discourses to particular cars, or the confusion of many Tongues speaking at once, let us sit and discourse in Dialogues.

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: Agreed; but shall we discourse in Rhime or in Prose?

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: In Rhimes by any means: for Rhimes many times hide and obscure that Nonsence that would be discover'd in Prose.

sp.speaker: Vain-glor.
sp.p: Then it seems Rhime is a Veil to cover the face of Nonsense.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: They are so: for one can never discover an ill Poem, until the Rhimes be dissolved into Prose, which shews whether there be Sense, Reason, Wit, or Fancy in them.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: But to be turned into Prose, the Poems will lose the Elegance of the Style, and the Eloquence of the Language.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Why, if a man should lose his Hat and Feather, and be stript of a fine and gay Suit of Cloaths, he would neither have the less brain nor blood, nor soul, nor body, beauty nor shape; and though gay and glorious Apparel may allure the Eyes of a young Lady, or a Novice Gentleman, or may draw the ignorant vulgar to Admiration, and so to an Esteem and Respect; yet those that have clear Understandings, solid Judgments, quick Wits, and knowing Wisedoms, will be so far from admiring the man for the sake of his gay Cloaths, or esteeming him for his glorious Attire, as they will be apt to condemn him as a vain man.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: Then you reject the cloathing of Poems in fine Language.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: No; but I despise those Poems that have nothing but Language and Rhimes.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Then it is a folly to write in Verse, if Rhymes be not accounted of.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Verse is to be accounted of for the sake of Numbers, which is harmonious; yet neither Harmonious Numbers, nor Chyming Rhymes, nor Gay Rhetorick, is Reason, Wit, nor Fancy, which is the Ground, Body, or Soul of a good Poem.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Yet no Poem is esteem'd, but condemn'd, that is not in gay and new-fashion'd cloathing.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p:
Then Chaucers Poems, which are in plain and old-fashion'd
garments, which is Language, is to be despised, and his Wit condemned; but certainly Chaucers Witty Poems, and Lively Descriptions, in despig â€¢ of their Old Language, as they have lasted in great Esteem and Admiration these three hundred years, so they may do Eternally amongst the Wise â€¢â€¢ every Age.

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: Gentlemen, leave off your Disputes, for the Ladies will be too hard for us: for they are always Conquerors in peace and war, both in the Schools and in the Fields, in the City and in the Court.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Pray leave off this particular Dispute, and let us discourse in general.

sp.speaker: Tranquill. Peace.
sp.p: Agreed.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Begin.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: Who shall begin?

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: I will begin; for a womans Tongue hath priviledge and preheminency in the first place.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Old brains are like to barren ground,

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Or like a wilderness forlorn,

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Or like crack'd bells that have no sound,

sp.speaker: Tranquill. Peace.
sp.p: Or like a child Abortive born:

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: For Time the fire of Wit puts out,

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: And sills the brain with vapour cold,

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: And quenches Fancy without doubt,

sp.speaker: Vain-glor.
sp.p: For Wit is feeble when 'tis old.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Wit neither fails, weakens, decays, nor dies,

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: Though bred and born, as other creatures are,

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Only the Brain, the Womb wherein it lies:

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: But when 'tis born, Fame nurses it with care,

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: And to Eternity doth it prefer.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Wit makes the brain sick when it breeding is,

sp.speaker: Tranquill.
sp.p: And painful throws before, and at its birth;

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: But when 'tis born, if good, a Comfort 'tis,

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: The Parent Poetry creates with mirth,

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: He joys to see his Issue fairly spring,

sp.speaker: Vain-glor.
sp.p: And hopes with time in numbers may increase,

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: And being multiply'd may honours bring,

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: As a posterity that never cease.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Wit, the Issue, and Off-spring of the Soul,

sp.speaker: Censure
sp.p: From which the Nature sublimely is Divine,

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Dimensions hath, and parts, yet in the whole,

sp.speaker: Tranquill.
sp.p: United is, of breaches there's no sign.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Wit, like the Soul is, which no body hath,

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: No latitude, yet hath a perfect form,

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Yet flies all sev'ral ways, yet keeps a path,

sp.speaker: Vain-glor.
sp.p: A path of Sense, which never turns therefrom.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: But wondrous strange, and monstrous is Wit,

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: That all contrarieties in it do dwell:

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: For it all Shapes, Imployments, Humours fit,

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Like Beasts, Men, Gods, or terrible Devils in Hell.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: O fie, O fie, this discourse is like dancing the Hay, or dancing a Scotch Gig, which will put you out of breath strait.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: You would have us discourse in the measure of a Spanish Pavin.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: No, but the measure of a French Galliard would do very well.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: For my part, Lady, I like Gigs best, and therefore, if you please, begin another Gig.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: The Spring is drest in buds and blossoms sweet:

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: The Summer laughs until her Cheeks look red,

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: The plenteous Autumn warm under our feet.

sp.speaker: Tranquill. Peace.
sp.p: The Winter shaking cold, is almost dead.

sp.speaker: All speak.
sp.p: Go on with the twelve Moneths.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Fierce furious March comes in with bended brows,

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: Commanding storms and tempests to arise,

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Beating the trees and clouds, as if it meant

sp.speaker: Vain-glory.
sp.p: To make them subject to his tyrannies.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Then follows April, weeping for her buds,

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: For fear rude March had all her young destroy'd;

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: But when she thought her tears might rise to floods,

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: With Sun-beams dry'd her Eyes, his heat her joy'd.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Then wanton May came full of Amorous Sports,

sp.speaker: Tranquill. Peace.
sp.p: Decking her self with gawdy Colours gay,

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: And entertaining Lovers of all sorts,

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: In pleasure she doth pass her time a way.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Then enters Iune with fair and full fat face,

sp.speaker: Vain-glor.
sp.p: Her Eyes are bright and clear as the Noon-Sun,

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: And in her carriage hath a Majestick grace,

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: In Equinoctial pace she walks, not run.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: But Iuly's sultry hot, Ambitious proud,

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: And in a fiery Chariot she doth ride,

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: When angry is, she thundring speaks aloud,

sp.speaker: Tranquill. Peace.
sp.p: Shoots Lightning through the clouds on every side.

div.stage: Enter Monsieur Sensuality, and breaks off their Dialogue-Discourse.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Iove bless us! what Designs have you Ladies and Gentlemen that you sit so gravely together in Councel.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Our chief Design is Wit.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: A witty Design: But really, what are you doing?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: They are idly Rhyming.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Hang idle Rhyming, give me Reason.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Although our Rhymes are not good, yet they are not foul, by reason they are made on fair and pure Subjects.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Why, what are the Subjects they are made on?

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: They are made of the several Seasons and Moneths of the Year.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: By your favour, Lady, there be some of the Seasons and Months very foul.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: But we have Rhym'd of none but the fair Months as yet.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Then let me advise you to stop your Poetical Vein: for if you go farther, you will meet with foul weather and rain.

sp.speaker: They all speak.
sp.p: Out, out of our company.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Do you come here to rail at our Rhymes, and yet Rhyme your self, and worse than any of the company?

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: I only Rhyme to make my self Free of the Company, though not of the Wits.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: So you will call us fools by and by.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: No faith, your Rhymes have named you already, and so prevented me.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Why this is worse and worse.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Let us seek a revenge.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: What revenge shall we take?

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: We will tye him to an Asses head.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: No, we will tye him to a Foxes tail.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Ladies tye me to what you please, so you do not tye me to a Horn.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Yes, to Altheas Horn, the Horn of plenty.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: 'Tis a sign Althea is a Woman, that she gives her gifts in a Horn; but I had rather starve, than receive plenty in such a thing.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Let us transform him as Acteon did.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: And follow him as his hounds did.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Young Ladies, be not so wilde and fierce, to be the hounds your selves to follow in pursuit.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: No, no, we will be as Diana, that transformed him.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Then you must be liable to the same Censure, which is, to be thought cruel.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: The more Cruel our Sex is, the more Chaste we are thought to be.

div.head: EPILOGUE
div.l: OUr Auth'ress bids me tell you She thought fit
For to divide this Fair CABAL of WIT.
For one Play 'twas too long, which was her sorrow,
The other half, if come, you'l see to morrow.
You'l thank her then, dividing it to make
You rise with Appetites, no Surfets take.
WIT'S Surfet's dangerous: Take the Fruition
Of new-born Fancies without Repetition.
But hold your hands, as you are men to day,
And as our Friends to morrow Clap our Play.
div.byline: The Marquiss of Newcastle writ this Epilogue.

list.head: The Actors Names.
list.item: Grave Temperance, Governess to Madamoiselle Pleasure.
Wanton, Excess, Ease, Idle, Surfet, waiting-maids to Madamoiselle Pleasure.

div.head: The Second Part of the Play called WITS CABAL.
ACT I.
Scene 1.
div.stage: Enter Madamoiselle Ambition, Faction, Pleasure, Superbe, Portrait, and Mother Matron enters as meeting them.

sp.speaker: MAtron.
sp.p: O Ladies, there is the rarest Beauty come to the City, out of the Countrey, that ever was seen, she surpasseth Hellen of Troy, or AEneas Mother Queen Venus.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: If she surpasseth their Appetites, as you say she doth their Beauties, she may chance to fire this City with flames of Love, or cause a War to destroy it.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Have you seen her, Mother Matron?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: No, but a friend of mine hath seen her.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Perchance your friend's a fool, and knows not how to judge.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Indeed my friend's a woman, and women have none of the best judgments.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: But there is more probability that she hath a surpassing beauty if a woman praise her, than if a man had praised her: for men have a partial love to the Effeminate Sex, which multiplies their beauties to their sight, and makes a candle in the night seem like a Blazing Star.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: In truth and Love is dark: for 'tis said he is blind.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: But Envy is quick-sighted, and therefore I am afraid the Lady you speak of is surpassing, since those of her own Sex can find no blemish or imperfection to cloud her from a praise.

sp.speaker: Busie.
sp.p: Ladies, I am come to give you intelligence of a rare Beauty that is come to this City.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Her Fame hath out-run your Intelligence, Sir; but have you seen her?

sp.speaker: Busie.
sp.p: No Lady, not I.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: Ladies, there is a rare Beauty come to this Town to increase the number of your Cabal.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Our Cabal is of Wit, not of Beauty.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: It's a Cabal of both, Lady.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Have you seen her?

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: No Lady, but I have heard of her Beauty.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Ladies, there is such a Beauty come to Town, that now or never you will be out-shin'd.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Iupiter bless us, and grant that she may not ingross to her self all Mankind, and so leave all the rest of her Sex destitute and forlorn!

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: It is to be hoped she will humble you, as to bring you to be more complyant to us men than you have been.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Have you seen her, Monsieur Sensuality?

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: No not I.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Why then she is a Miracle, that every one hears of, but no body seeth.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: May she continue a Miracle still: for I had rather that she should only be heard of, than be visibly seen.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: But I will do my indeavour to see her.

sp.speaker: Busie.
sp.p: So will I.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: I long to see her as much as the men do.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: So do I.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: And I.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: But how shall we compass the sight of her?

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Faith let's go to a Play, I'll warrant you she'll be there.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: If she be, we shall only see her Mask, not her Face: for at the common Play-houses all the Effeminate Sex sit mask'd and muffl'd.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Why then let us go to that Church which is most frequented, as where some Famous Preachers preach; and certainly, if she be such a Beauty, she will be there: Besides, there our Sex sit to the full View, to Attract the Eyes of the Gods.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: No, no, Lady, they sit to the full View, to tempt the Appetites of men: for they think not on the Gods, nor care the Gods should think of them.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Fie, fie, Mother Matron, you will make Women damnable creatures, if they could be made so by your Description: But Women go to Church to present their prayers of Request, and praises of Thanksgiving, and not to shew themselves to men, nor to tempt their Appetites, as you say.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Come, come, Ladies, search your own Consciences, and you will find I have spoke the truth: for if you only went to present your prayers to the Gods, you would go as humble petitioners, or sorrowful penitents, cloathed in sackcloth, and ashes on your head; and not attir'd in gold and silver, painted, patch'd, and curl'd, unless you think the Gods are like to men, to be delighted and enamour'd with Vanity, Beauty, and Bravery: for you make the Church a Masking-room, rather than a place of Devotion.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: No, we rather strive to make it like Heaven, which is glorious and splendrous; and the Heavenly Society is said to be beautiful.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Yes, such a Heaven, where Maskers are instead of Saints.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p:
Why, Angels are describ'd by Painters to have fine-colour'd
wings, and by Preachers, to hold fine gold branches in their hands, and the Heavens are described to us to be most gloriously adorn'd, with Diamonds, Rubies, Pearl, Emeralds, Gold, and Crystal, which shows the Gods delight in braveries: Wherefore we, to delight the Gods, make our selves fine and gay.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: No, no, Ladies, you strive not to delight the Gods, but to be Ador'd and Worship'd as Goddesses by the Masculine Sex, whom you would have to be your Saints.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: I know not whether we desire to be Goddesses, or not; But I am sure, if women be as irreligious as you make them to be, they will prove Devils.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: And Mother Matron here will prove the chief She-Devil amongst our Sex.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: No, no, Lady, I'm devour, for I say my prayers every night and every morning.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: May be so you do, and all the time you are saying your prayers, you are thinking of your snarl'd Periwig, or how you shall trim up your old Gown that was given you by some of our Cabal.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Faith I must confess I have had some such thoughts when I have been at my prayers, God forgive me for't.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: And for all you exclame against young Beauties, for there is your spight now your beauty is gone; yet I have observed, that when you are at Church, you will cast your eyes about, and mop and mew, and simpering, bridlde in your Chin, in hopes to catch some beardless boy; and when you look up on the Preachers face, if he be a young Lecturer, it is not out of Attention, of what he preaches, but in hopes to perswade him to marry you, as thinking he would imagine you would make a good Vertuous Religious woman, sit to make a Parsons Wife.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: No faith, I will never be a Parsons Wife: for Preachers are given so much to Contemplation, as they seldom speak but in the pulpit; but if they do, it will be of subjects I understand not, as of such subjects as they have read out of dead Authors.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Why then you will have the more liberty to speak your self, if your Husband speak but seldom.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: That's true; but those which love to speak much, are like drunkards, which is, they love company: for Questions and Answers are like drinking and pledging, and Arguing is like drinking Healths, and quarrels and friendships, and friendships and quarrels proceed from the one as often as from the other.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Then it seems you are both kind and quarrelsome, both in your talk and drink: for you speak very experienc'd of both.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: So much experience I have, living long in the World, as to know that drink makes one talk, and talking makes one dry.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Well, leaving this dry discourse, Mother Matron, you must find out some way or means whereby we may be acquainted with the rare Beauty which every one talks of,

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I will do my indeavour, and imploy the wisedom of my brain to compass it.

div.head: Scene 2.
div.stage: Enter Madamoiselle Bon' Esprit, and her Maid enters soon after.

sp.speaker: MAid.
sp.p: Madam, there is Monsieur Satyrical come to visit you.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Cupid and Venus possess him, and Pallas guard me. Conduct him hither.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Monsieur Satyrical, you appear like a Comet to our Sex.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: If all your Sex had been like you, I should have been as conversant as one of the Planets.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: I hope you have not that Influence on our Sex, as the Planets have on Earthly Creatures.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I wish I had, for then I might cast such an Influence of Love, as might cause you to love me.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: But you are like the Planet of Saturn, and not of Venus: for you frown, when Venus smiles.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I shall not do so when you smile.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: You will when I quarrel with you.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I hope you will not quarrel with me; but if you do, I will receive your anger, as subjects receive the punishments of Laws, obediently, although it ruins me.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: I will make you Judge of the Cause, as of the Laws. Have I not reason to quarrel with you, when I Challeng'd you to an Honourable Fight, and you return'd my Challenge back with scorn and slight?

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Whatsoever my Answer was, I confess I am conquer'd, and yield my self your prisoner, to dispose of me as you please: But if you will, take a Ransome of current Love, which I have brought you in the Chest of my Heart, wherein it is so fast lock'd, that nothing but your Acceptance can open it.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: If it be capable of being taken forth, I may leave your heart empty.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.l: Your Virtue will still furnish it with more,
Your pure Chastity increase the store.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.l: Your Wit is very apt to take your part,
To keep your own, yet strives to steal my heart:
But if you do not use it nobly well,
It will complain to Gods, the truth will tell.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.l: May I be curs'd, my Wit be quenched out,
If I give you a cause my Love so doubt,
Or I your. Virtues highly not admire,
Preferring them before a loose desire,
May all the Gods their vengeance on me cast,
And may their punishments for ever last.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.l: I was in jest at first; but since I find
Your Love so honest, and your words so kind,
I cannot doubt, nor yet my self deny
The union Friendship in firm bonds to tye
Of everlasting love; and if I break,
May Gods be deaf when I in pray'rs do speak.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Madam, the Poetical Duel hath ended in Friendship, and if you please, in Mariage.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: I consent; but do not prize me the less for being soon won for I loved you before you asked my Love; and being ask'd, I could not deny you.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I value your love as Saints do Heaven, and prize it as highly as Gods their power; and for my crimes committed against you and your Sex, I offer up my heart on the Altar of Repentance, as a sacrifice to you my Goddess for an Atonement of your Anger.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: I accept of thy Offering, and shall receive it as a Trophy of my Victory.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I am your slave.

div.head: Scene 3.
div.stage: Enter Superbe, Ambition, Faction, Pleasure, and Portrait.

sp.speaker: AMbition.
sp.p: It is said that Women are the greatest Conquerors, because they conquer conquering men, and make them become slaves: For it is said, that Women have conquer'd the wisest man, as Solomon, the wittiest man, as David, the strongest man, as Sampson, the fairest man, as Paris of Troy, the valiantest man, as Achilles, the subtilest man, as Ulysses, the power-fullest men, as Alexander and Caesar.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: By your favour, Women never made a Conquest of the two latter, and therefore cannot be said to be absolute Conquerors: for none are absolute Conquerors but those that conquer power, that is, those that get absolute dominion over all the World, which Alexander and Caesar are said to have done by their Valour and Conduct; and never any Woman or Women conquer'd those men, as to get them to yield up their power for a womans sake, which shews they were not rul'd by women, although they lov'd women; by which it is to be proved, that women never made an absolute Conquest of men, because they could never conquer absolutely those two absolute Conquerors and Masters of the World.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: But Livia Conquer'd Augustus Caesar, and Ruled his Power; and he was as absolute a Master of the Worlds Power, as Iulius Caesar and Alexander.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: He was rather to be said the Possessor of the Worlds power, than the absolute Conqueror of the Worlds power.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: It is as good to be a Conqueress of the possessor of power, as to conquer the Conqueror of power.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: It is as good for the Benefit, but not so much for the Honour of it.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: But Alexander nor Caesar lived not so long a time, as to be Conquer'd by women: for women must have time and opportunity for to gain the Conquest in, as well as men have.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: If Alexander and Caesar must have been old before they possibly could have been conquer'd, it proves that women do rather conquer Age, than power weakens the strength; and the truth is, women conquer nothing but the vices, weaknesses, and defects of men: As they can conquer an unexperienc'd Youth, and doting Age, ignorant Breeding, effeminate Natures, wavering Minds, facile Dispositions, soft Passions, wanton Thoughts, unruly Appetites, and the luxurious Lives of men; but they cannot conquer mens fix'd Resolutions, their heroick Valours, their high Ambitions, their magnificent Generosities, their glorious Honours, or their conquering or over-ruling Powers: Nor can women conquer their moral Vertues, as their Prudence, Fortitude, Justice, and Temperance. But put the case a man had the power of the whole World, and could quit that power for the enjoyment of any particular woman, or women, yet he quits not that power for the womans sake, but for his minds-sake, his pleasure-sake, as to satisfie his Fancy, Passion, or Appetites: And what Conpuest soever Women make on Men, if any Conquest they do make, is more by the favour of Nature, than the Gods.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Well, I wish I may be the Conqueress of one man, let the favour proceed from which it will.

div.head: Scene 4.

sp.speaker: EAse.
sp.p: There hath been such a Skirmish, or rather a Battel.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: How, and betwixt whom?

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: Why, betwixt Grave Temperance and Mother Matron.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: What was the cause of their falling out.

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: Why Mother Matron had a spic'd pot of Ale in her hand, so she set it to her mouth, and drank a hearty draught of it, and finding it very good and refreshing, drank another draught. By my faith, said she, this is a cheerly cup indeed, and a comfortable drink, and with that drank another draught, and so long-winded she was, as she drank up all the Ale therein: Whereupon, Grave Temperance rebuked her for drinking so much, saying, that though a little, as one draught, or so, might refresh the Spirits, yet a great quantity would make her drunk: Whereupon Mother Matron, who could not then suffer a reproof, in anger she flung the pot, which was still in her hand, at Grave Temperance's head.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: It was a sign she had drank all the good liquor out, or otherwise she would not have throvvn the pot avvay.

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: It was a sign she was drunk, or else she would not have done so outragious an act, as to have broke Grave Temperances head.

div.stage: Enter Mother Matron as half drunk, and scolding.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p:
Reprove me! teach me! Have not I liv'd long enough in the World to be able to govern my self, but Temperance must govern me? Am I a Child? am I a Novice, that I must be governed by Temperance? No,
no, let her go to Nunneries, and let her be the Lady Prioress to govern Nuns, for yfaith she shall not Prior me.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: Not Frier you, do you say?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: No nor Nunn me neither: for I will be neither Fryerd, nor Nunn'd.

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: Why what will you be?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Why what should I be, but as I am, a wise, sober, and discreet Governess to a company of young Ladies? Ladies that love the World better than Heaven, and hate a Nunnery worse than Death; and by my Faith they have reason, for liberty is the joy of life, and the World is the place of sensual pleasures, and sensual pleasures are substantial, and in being, when the pleasures aftee death are uncertain; but if they were certain, yet I had rather have a draught of Ale in this World, than a draught of Nectar in the next.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: This Ale hath heat her into a Poetical height.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: What do you say, into a pots head?

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: No, I say your head is a pot, filled with the fume of Ale.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: What have you to do with my head?

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: What had you to do with Grave Temperances head?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I would Temperances grave head were in your throat, and then there would be two fools heads one within another.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: Come, let's leave her, or she will talk her self into a fit of madnesse.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: A couple of Gill-flirts, to heat me thus.

div.head: Scene 5.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Satyrical, and Madamoiselle Bon' Esprit.

sp.speaker: SAtyrical.
sp.p: Dear Mistris, have you freely pardon'd and forgiven me my faults?

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: But will you not reprove me for them hereafter?

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: In a pardon all faults ought to be forgiven, if not forgotten, and no repetitions ought to be made of the same: for a clear pardon, and a free forgiveness, blots out all offences, or should do so. But you imagine your offences greater than they are, and by your doubts, I to be of less good nature than I am.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: There are none that have offended what they love, but fears, and hopes, and doubts, sight Duels in their Minds.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Banish those doubts, and let the hopes remain to build a confident belief to keep out jealousie, otherwise it will take possession, and destroy, at least disturb affection.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Not my affection to you.

div.head: Scene 6.

sp.speaker: FAction.
sp.p: For Heavens sake let's go see Mother Matron: for 'tis said she's mad-drunk.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: If she be mad-drunk, she's rather to be shunn'd than sought after.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Why, do not we give money to see mad people in Bedlam? and we may see her for nothing.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Those people are not madly drunk, nor drunkly mad: for they, poor creatures, drink nothing but water.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Perchance if they did drink strong drink, it might make them soberly in their right wits.

div.stage: Enter Mother Matron as partly drunk.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Where is Monsieur Frisk? O that Monsieur Frisk were here!

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: What would you have with Monsieur Frisk?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I would challenge Monsieur Frisk.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: What, to sight?

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Yes, in Cupids Wars.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: By Venus I swear, thou hast been Cashier'd from Cupids Wars this thirty years.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Come, come, Ladies, for all your frumps, you are forced to make me General, to lead up the Train, and Generalissimo, to set the Battalia, so that though I am too old to be a common Souldier, I am young enough to be a Commander.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Thou art at this time but a drunken Commander.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: If I am drunk, I am but as a Commander ought to be, or as a Commander usually is.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Pray do not accuse Mother Matron: for though her Brain may be a little disturb'd, yet her Reason is sober, and governs her Tongue orderly.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: O sweet Monsieur Frisk!

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: If her Reason governs her Tongue, I do not perceive it governs her Humour.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Her Humour, say you, you mean her Appetites.

div.head: Scene 7.
div.stage: Enter Madamoiselle Pleasure, and Monsieur Tranquillitous Peace.

sp.speaker: PLeasure.
sp.p: Passions are begot betwixt the Soul and the Body, the Reason and the Sense; and the Habitation of the Passions is the Heart, which is in the midst of man, as betwixt the Rational part, the Head, and the Sensual Part.

sp.speaker: Tranquill.
sp.p: What part is that, Madam?

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: The bestial part.

sp.speaker: Tranquill.
sp.p: What part is the bestial part? for I cannot perceive but beasts and men are alike in most parts.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: I am not a Lectural Reader of parts.

sp.speaker: Tranquill.
sp.p: One would think you were by your former Discourse.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Why, I may mention parts, without Preaching on parts.

sp.speaker: Tranquill.
sp.p: But if Women would Preach of the parts of the Body, and leave Preaching of the Spirit and Soul, it would be better for themselves, their Husbands, Friends, and Neighbours, than it is: And if men would do the like, it would be better for themselves, their wives, and neighbours: But they preach altogether of the Soul, and yet know not what the Soul is.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: How would you have them preach of the Body?

sp.speaker: Tranquill.
sp.p: First, as for themselves, if they would consider: for they must consider before they Preach, which is, to Teach: If they would consider, I say, how frail the parts of Mankind are, how tender and weak every part of the body is, how apt they are to sickness & diseases, how they are subject more to pain than to pleasure, how difficult it is to keep the body from harm, how soon the body withers, decays, and dies: If Mankind did consider this of the body, they would study what was the guard, and the preservation of every part of the body; in which study they would find Temperance the only preservation of parts, and life of pleasure: for in Excess pleasure dies, and pains possess the body. Thus we can destroy the body sooner by Excess, and preserve it longer by Temperance, than otherwise it would be.

Secondly, for those that are maried, temperance keeps both man and wise chaste, patient, and healthful, because gluttony, debauchery, and intemperate anger, hurts the body, and destroys the body. Thus temperance keeps the place of Wedlock: for a Wife being patient, the Husband lives peaceably, being chaste, he lives honourably, being healthful, he lives comfortably; and the Husband, being temperate, he will neither be a Glutton, a Drunkard, an Adulterer, nor Gamester: for gaming hurts the body, with vexing at the losses, and sitting still, which hinders the Exercise of the body, or keeping unseasonable hours, which is pernicious to the health of the Body, as to the quiet of the Mind, and waste of their Estates. Thus a man and wife lives free from jealousies and fear of poverty

Thirdly, for their Neighbours: If they be temperate, they will neither be covetous, quarrelsome, nor envious, which will keep them from doing injury or wrong, and will cause them to be friendly and kind: for if they covet not their neighbours goods, they will not strive to possess their neighbours right; if they be not envious, they will be sociable, and helpful to each other, as good neighbours ought to be: thus they will not vex each other with Lawsutes, and quarrelling Disputes, nor Adulteries, and the like: And if men live peaceably, it is good for the Common-wealth, as being free from faction and tumult: Besides, Peace and Love are the ground whereon all the Commands of the Gods are built on.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: You may preach temperance, but few will follow your Doctrine.

sp.speaker: Tranquill.
sp.p: Yes, Pleasure will: for without temperance there can be no lasting pleasure.

sp.speaker: EAse.
sp.p: Yonder's Mother Matron so metamorphos'd, as at first I did not know her.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: How metamorphos'd is she?

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: Most strangely attir'd for her Age, and as strangely behav'd.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: How, for Iupiters sake?

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: Why she hath a green Sattin gown on, but it is of an ill-chosen green, for it is of the colour of goos-dung, and an Orange-yellow Feather on her head.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: I hope she is not jealous.

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: Then is she beset with many several colour'd Ribbons, as Hair-colour, Watchet, Blush-colour, and White.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: What, to express her Despair, Constancy, Modesty, and Innocence?

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: I think she may despair, but for her constancy, I doubt it, and for modesty, I dare swear she never had any; but if she had, it was so long since, as she hath quite forgot it; as for her innocence, I will leave it to the Examination or Accusation of her own Conscience.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: But how is her behaviour?

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: Why she simpers, and draws the deep lines in her face into closes, and her wrinckles are the quick-set hedges; then she turns her Eyes aside in coy glances, and her Body is in a perpetual motion, turning and winding, and wreathing about, from object to object, and her Gate is jetting, and sometimes towards a dancing pace; besides, she is toying and playing with every thing, like a Girl of fifteen, and now and then she will sing quavering, as a Note or two betwixt a word or two, after the French and Courtly Mode.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: Surely she is mad.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: Who's mad?

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: No otherwise than all Amorous Lovers use to be.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: Why is she an Amorous Lover?

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: Yes, a most desperate one.

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: Who is she so amourously affected with?

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: With Monsieur Frisk.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: Why he is not above one and twenty years of Age.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: That's the reason she's in love with him: for it is his youth, and his dancing, she amourously affects him for, for she swears that the very first time she saw him dance, Cupid did wound her, and shot his golden Arrows from the heels of Monsieur Frisk.

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: Why she is threescore and ten, at least.

sp.speaker: VVanton.
sp.p: That's all one: for Cupid wounds Age as well as youth.

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: But I had thought that an old womans heart had been so hard Love could not have enter'd.

sp.speaker: VVanton.
sp.p: Old Mother Matron proves it otherwise: for her Heart is as tender as the youngest Heart of us all.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: While I am young I will be a Lover, because I will not be a Fool when I am old.

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: That's the way to be a Fool whilst you are young, and a Lover when you are old.

sp.speaker: VVanton.
sp.p: No, that is to be a Curtezan whilst she is young, and a Bawd when she is old.

sp.speaker: Idle.
sp.p: Nay faith, when I can no longer traffique for my self, I will never trade for any other.

sp.speaker: VVanton.
sp.p: Covetousness will tempt your reverent Age.

div.head: Scene 9.
div.stage: Enter Ambition, Pleasure, Faction, Portrait, Bon' Esprit, Superbe, Wanton, Ease, Excess.

sp.speaker: PLeasure.
sp.p: How shall we entertain our time?

sp.speaker: Portrait.
