sp.p: Let us sit and chuse Husbands.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: What, in the Ashes?

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: No, in our Speeches.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Content.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Begin; but let your Maids, Lady Pleasure, sit and chuse Husbands with us.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p:
If I were to chuse a Husband, I would chuse a man that was honourably born, nobly bred, wisely taught, civilly behav'd; also I would have him to speak rationally, wittily, and eloquently; to act prudently, valiantly, justly, and temperately; to live freely, magnificently, and peaceably. I
would have him honourably born, because I would not have him a Boor by Nature, which is surly â€¢ rude, grumbling, and miserable: I would have him nobly bred, because I would not have him a Shark, a Cheat, or a Sycophant: I would have him wisely taught, because I would not have him an ignorant fool, nor a pedantical fool: I would have him civilly-behav'd, to please my Eyes: I would have him to speak rational, witty, and eloquent, to please my Ears: I would have him valiant, to defend his Country, to guard his Family, and to maintain his Honour: I would have him prudent, to foresee misfortunes, and to provide for the future, that I may never want for the present: I would have him temperate, lest Excess should ruine his Fortune, Health, or Esteem: I would have him just, because others should be just to him; to live freely, as not to be inslaved; to live magnificently, for to be respected; to live peaceably, to avoid brawl â€¢ ries. And such a man as this, will be kind to his Wife, loving to his Children, bountiful to his Servants, courteous to his Friends, civil to Strangers, faithful to his Trust, and just to his Promise.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: If I were to choose a Husband, I would choose a man that were Rich, honour'd with Titles, and were Powerful. I would have him Rich, because I would have him live plentifully, to feed luxuriously, to be adorn'd gloriously: I would have him to have Titles of Honour, because I would take place of my Neighbours, to have the chief place at a Feast, and to have the first and choisest meats offer'd me: I would have him Powerful, to oppose my Opposers, to insult over my Enemies, and to neglect my Friends; which, if I be poor and helpless, they will do me: Thus I shall be honour'd by my Superiours, crouch'd to by Inferiours, flatter'd by Sycophants, brag'd of by my Friends, obey'd by my Servants, respected by my Acquaintance, envy'd by my Neighbours, sought to by my Enemies. Thus I might advance my Friends, punish my Enemies, tread down my Superiours, inslave my Inferiours, insult over my Foes, and inthrone my self.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: If I were to choose a Husband, I would choose a man whom all other men are slaves to, and he mine. And what can I desire more than to be absolute?

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: If I were to choose, I would choose a man for a Husband that were an honest and plain-dealing man, patient and wise, that I might neither be deceiv'd by his falshood, nor troubl'd with his quarrels, nor vex'd with his follies.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: If I were to choose a Husband, I would choose a subtil crafty Knave, that can cheat an honest Fool, with which cheats I can entertain my time, like those that go to see Juglers play tricks.

sp.speaker: VVanton.
sp.p: If I were to choose a Husband, I would choose a man that were blind, deaf, and dumb, that he might neither trouble me with his impertinent Questions, nor see my indiscreet Actions, nor hear my foolish Discourses: Thus I may say what I will, and never be crost, do what I will, and never be hinder'd, go where I will, and never be watch'd, come when I will, and never be examin'd, entertain whom I will, and never be rebuk'd. Thus I may Govern as I will, Spend as I will, Spare as I will, without Controlment.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: If I were to choose a Husband, I would choose a man that were industrious, thrifty, and thriving: for the pleasure is not so much to enjoy, as getting, like those that are hungry, have more pleasure in eating their meat, than when their stomacks are full.

sp.speaker: Excess.
sp.p: If I were to choose a Husband, I would choose a man that were a busie Fool, which would continually bring me fresh, although false News: for his busie mind, which fills his Head with Projects, which Projects will feed my excessive Ambition, with his high Designs, although improbable, and set my thoughts at work with his several Atchievments, although there is no leading-path therein: But howsoever, this will furnish my Imagination, imploy my Thoughts, please my Curiosity, and entertain my time with Varieties, wherein, and wherewith, I may pass my life with fine Phantasms, or like a fine Dream.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: It is a sign you love sleep excessively well, so as you would have your life pass as a dream.

sp.speaker: Excess.
sp.p: Why, Madam, sleeping is the lifes Elizium, and our dreams the pastime therein, and our beds are our living graves, to the greatest part of our life, and most are best pleased therein: for it gives rest to our wearied and tired limbs, it revives the weak and fainting spirits, it eases the sick and pained, it pacifies the grieved, it humours the melancholy, it cherishes age, it nourishes youth, it begets warmth, it cools heat, it restores health, it prolongs life, and keeps the mind in peace.

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: I will not choose, but vvish and pray, which is, if ever I marry, I pray Jove that I may out-live my Husband.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: O sie, Women pray that their Husbands may out-live them?

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: If they do, in my Conscience they dissemble, but howsoever I will never pray so: for I perceive when men are Widowers, they are more hasty to marry again than Batchellors are, and the last love blots out the first, and I should be sorry to be blotted out.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: But if men do marry after they have buried their first Wife, yet perchance they will not love their second Wife so well as the first.

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: I know not that, but yet to the outward view I perceive a man seems to forget his first Wife in the presence of his second Wife.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: By your favour, a second Wife puts a Husband in remembrance of his first Wife, either for goodness or badness.

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: For my part, I would not be kept in remembrance by one in my room; but howsoever, I shall love my self better than I'm sure I shall love my Husband, and therefore I desire to live long: for I had rather live and have him in remembrance, than die and to forget him; and I had rather remember than be remember'd.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: O Temperance, I heard say that you have seen the rare Beauty, Madamoiselle la Belle.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: And is she so handsome as she is reported to be?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Truly she is a pretty young Lady.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Is she only a pretty Lady?

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Why she is young, and those that are very young, are only pretty; but those that are at full growth are beautiful and handsome, and those in their Autumnal years are Lovely, and those that are old are ill-favour'd.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: No, no, those Women that have been once handsom, never grow ill-favour'd.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Well, setting aside old women, what say you to the young Lady?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: I say she is handsomer at a distance than neer-hand.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: That's well, for then her praises will be only at a distance.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: No by'r Lady, she hath Beauty enough to be praised to her face.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: I had rather appear handsomer at a distance than at a near view, than seem worse at a distance, and handsomer at a near view.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: By reason there is no Woman but is seen more by strangers than acquaintance; besides, whole streets of people view Ladies as they passe through in their Coaches, when perchance not above half a dozen neighbours and acquaintance see them near hand.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: So you may have many Admirers, but few Lovers.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Faith the rarest Beauties that ever were, the more they were known and seen, the less Esteem'd and Admir'd they were: for an unacquainted face appears, or at least pleaseth better, although but an indifferent Beauty, than a common face, although it excels with Beauty.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Did you not hear Madamoiselle la Belle speak?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: No faith, she may be dumb for any thing I know.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: How is she behav'd?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: After the Country Mode.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: What manner of Woman is her Mother?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: A Country Lady.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Faith if Madamoiselle la Belle hath neither Wit nor Behaviour, her Beauty will be dim'd for the want of either: for Wit and Behaviour are the Polishers of Beauty, otherwise Beauty is but like a Diamond unfil'd, or unpolish'd, or like gold untry'd, or unresin'd.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Nay Ladies, she may have a great Wit for all that I know: for she did not express either simplicity or ignorance, whilst I was in her company she spake not one word.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Let us examine no more, but let us go see her, and then discourse with her.

div.head: Scene 10.
div.stage: Enter Mother Matrons Maid, and Monsieur Frisk.

sp.speaker: FRisk.
sp.p: Pretty Maid, would you speak with me?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Yes, and if't please your Worship.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: From whom come you?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: From my Mistris.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Who is your Mistris?

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: What Message hath Mother Matron sent to me?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: She hath sent your Worship a Letter, and desires your Worship to send her an Answer.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Go and stay within, and I will give you an Answer.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: This Letter is concerning some of the young Ladies that are in Love with me.
Blessed Letter, that art the Messenger of Love, the Presenter of Youth, Beauty and Wit, and the Inviter to Pleasure.

div.stage: He opens the Letter, and reads it aloud, as to himself.

body.head: The Letter.
body.p: O Dear Monsieur Frisk, since I last saw you, and heard you speak so wisely, as that you would wait upon the Ladies, and proffer so kindly, as to proffer me a kiss, meeting you in the Lane called Loves Folly. O that Lane, that fortunate or unfortunate Lane! for as my wishes succeed, the Lane proves good or bad: for since that time of meeting, I have loved you, or rather, I may say, I have been in Love with you, or rather, I may say, I have Fancy'd you beyond all other young Gentlemen, and I hope you will return the like to me: For though I am not in my blooming Beauty, yet I am not quite decay'd, but there remains some fresh colour, wherewith a young Gentleman may take delight; and let me tell you, the Autumn is more pleasant than the Spring, for the Spring is raw and cold, the Autumn is warm and comfortable: wherefore let me perswade you, sweet Monsieur Frisk, to chuse the Autumnal fruits, and reject the Springing buds, which are incipid and tasteless: Ripe fruit's are better than green, and VVinter-fruits more lasting than the fruits of the Summer: Staid Gravity is more happy to live with, than wilde Inconstancy; the wisedome of Age is more profitable than the follies of Youth; not that I say I'm old, nor pray think me not so, but that I am as wise as Age can make me, and VVisedome is not a portion that is given to every one, yet what wisedome I have, I will impart to you, sweet Monsieur Frisk, you shall be the Receiver; the Treasurer, and the Disposer; also with my wisedome I give my heart, with my heart I give you my person, which wisedom, heart, and person, is not to be despised: for by my wisedome you will receive Counsel, with my heart Love, and with my person that Beauty Time hath left me, who like a cheating knave, hath rob'd me of some, but yet there is enough left, dear Monsieur Frisk, to delight your view: for although I am not like Hellen of Greece, yet I am like Hellen, when she was Hellen of Troy, for then, by my faith, she was in her Autumnal years, as I am, which was about fifty, or by'r Lady, somewhat more, and then she was as dear to her Paris, witness Troy, and as much desired of her of....witness the Greeks, as when she was but fifteen. Wherefore, dear Frisk, let me be thy Hellen, and be thou my Paris, and let our Loves be as bright as the fire of Troy, but not so consuming; but if thou deny'll me, I shall consume in mine own flames, and be buried in mine own ashes, which will fly in the face of thy cruelty, to revenge me thy

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p:
A pox of her luxurious Appetite, to be Amorous at fourscore, one might have thought, nay sworn, that Cupids fire had been put out with Times Extinguisher; but I perceive by Mother Matron, that time hath no power over that Appetite, but I am forty time hath made her such a creature, as not to be capable of curses, for she is her self a curse beyond all I could give her; but if she were capable, I would bury her under a mountain of curses, for
raising up my hopes to the height of young beautiful Ladies by the outside of the Letter, and then frustrating my expectation by the inside, causing me to fall from the bower of bliss, into the grave of life, the habitation of death; from a young Beauty, to an old doting Woman: Oh, I will tear this letter that hath deceived me; but stay, I will keep this letter to make sport amongst the young Ladies, which sport may perchance insinuate me into some favour with the young Ladies: for as idle and ridiculous pastime, or means as this is, hath got many times good success amongst Ladies: wherefore I will, for their sport-sake, jestingly Court Mother Matron, and in the mean time of the Progress, write her a letter.

div.head: Scene 11.
div.stage: Enter Madamoiselle Ambition, and Monsieur Inquisitive.

sp.speaker: INquisitive.
sp.p: I hear, Madamoiselle Ambition, you are to marry Monsieur Vain-glorious.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: No, for I am too honest to marry one man, and love, admire, and esteem another man beyond him; but when I marry, I will marry such a one as I prize, honour, love, and admire above all other men, or else I will never marry.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: What man could you esteeem, honour, and love most?

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: He that I thought had the noblest Soul, and had done the most worthyest Actions.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: But put the case that man that were as you would have him, were so ingag'd as you could not enjoy him in lawful mariage?

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: I could lawfully enjoy him, although I could not lawfully marry him.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: As in Contemplation, for I could enjoy his Soul no otherwise, if I were maried to him: for if I were maried, I could but contemplate of his Merits, please my self with the thoughts of his Virtues, honour his generous Nature, and praise his Heroick Actions: And these I can do as much, although I should live at distance from him, nor never be his Wife: for the mariage of Bodies, is no enjoyment of Souls.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: This would only be an opinion of delight, but no true enjoyment of pleasure: for though an Opinion may affright the Soul, yet the Opinion cannot pleasure the Body. But say an Opinion could delight the Soul without the Senses, yet the pleasures of the Senses are to be preferred before the delight of the Soul: for the truth is, that the spirits of life take more delight in sensual pleasures, than in the Souls imagination: for life lives in the Senses, not in the Soul: for were there no Senses, there would be no Life.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: By your favour, there is life in the Soul, when Death hath extinguish'd the Senses.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: That's more than you know, you believe it only upon report; but who hath had the trial or experience of the truth of it? So that the report is upon an unknown ground, and your belief is built upon an unsure Foundation.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: What belief is for my advantage, I will strive and indeavour to strengthen it, on what foundation soever it's built upon.

div.head: Scene 12.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Frisk, and Mother Matrons Maid.

sp.speaker: FRisk.
sp.p: You will pardon me, pretty Maid, for causing you to stay so long, for an Answer of your Mistris's Letter.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: There requires no pardon Sir, for I have been very well entertain'd by your man, I thank him.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: I perceive my man hath had better fortune than his Master, for he hath had youth to entertain; but I hope if you receive the mans entertainment so thankfully, you will not refuse the Masters.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: My Mistris would be jealous of your Worship, if you should entertain me.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Why, doth your Mistris love me so much?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: So much, as she cannot sleep quietly for dreaming of you; nor lets me sleep: for she wakes me every night to tell me her dreams.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: What dreams she?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: One dream was, she dream'd that she was Diana, and you Acteon.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: What, to set horns on my head?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: No, my Mistris said, that she in her dream did more as a Godess ought to have done, than Diana did: for she was generous in her dream, and not cruel, for instead of horning you, she invited you into her Bath.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: I hope you were one of her Nymphs.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Another time she dream'd you were Mercury, and she Herce; and another, that she was Venus, and you Adonis; but the last night she awaked out of a fearful dream.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: What dream was that?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: She dream'd that she was Queen Dido, and you the Prince AEneas, and when you were ship'd and gone away, she stab'd her self.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: If she were Dido, I should prove AEneas.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: On my Conscience she fetch'd as many sighs when she awak'd, and made as many pitious complaints and lamentations, as if her dream had been true, and she really bad been Queen Dido, insomuch as I was afraid that she would have killed he self indeed, and was running forth the Chamber to call in company to hinder her, but that she commanded me to stay, saying, that it was but the passion of her dream, for she hoped that you would prove a more constant and faithful Lover, than to leave her to despair.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p:
The next time she is in the same passion, tell her I will be like
AEneas, meet her in Hell: In the mean time carry her this Letter.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Lord, Lord, she will be a joy'd woman, to receive a letter from you, and I shall be a welcome Messenger unto her, and the letter will be worth a new gown to me.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: I wish it may be a gown of price to thee.

div.head: Scene 13.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Satyrical, and Madamoiselle Bon' Esprit.

sp.speaker: BOn' Esprit.
sp.p: How shall I pacifie my companions, or qualifie their spleens? who will be in a furious rage, when they perceive and know my real love to you: for they made me as their hook to the line of their Angle, and hope to catch you like a Gudgion.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: All that Angle do not catch; yet you have drawn me forth of the salt Satyrical Sea.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: But their desire is, that you should lie gasping on the shore of Love.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Would they be so cruel, as not to throw me into a fresh River?

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: No: for they joy in the thought of your torments, and their general prayers are to Cupid, imploring him to wound you with a golden-headed Arrow, and she you love, with an Arrow headed with lead: As for their particular prayers, they are after this manner.
One prays you may sigh your self into Air, and the Air so infectious, as it may plague all the Satyrical of your Sex.
Another prayeth you may weep tears of Vitriol, and that the sharpness of those tears may corrode your soul.

Another prays that your passion of love may be so hot, as it may torment you, as Hell-fire doth the damned; but Mother Matron, besides saying Amen to all their prayers, makes her prayers thus, That she for whose sake you must endure all these torments, may be the oldest, and most ill-favour'd deform'd woman that ever Nature, Accident, and Time made.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: She would have me in Love with her self, it seems by her prayer.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: If she did hear you, she would die for want of Revenge.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: But Mistris, what prayer made you for me?

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Not a cursing prayer: for though Mother Matron would have carried me up to the top of the Hill of Rage, and instead of a prayer for you, there to have made curses against you, yet she could neither force me up the one, nor perswade me to the other: for I told her I would give a blessing instead of a curse, and for fear of that, she left persisting.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I perceive I had been in danger, had not you sav'd me, and like a merciful Godess kept me from their fury; but I'm afraid, that for my sake they will curse you now.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: No doubt of it; but the best of't is, that their cursing prayers, or prayers of curses, go no farther than their lips.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p:
For all their furious rage, self-conceit perswades me, that if I
had addrest my self as a Suter to any one of them, they would have been more merciful than to have deny'd my sute.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: I can think no otherwise: for I shall judge them by my self.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Pray let's go, and invite them to our Wedding.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: By no means: for they will take that as ill, as if you did indid invite them to a poyson'd Banquet: But if I may adv â€¢ se, it is not to tell them our Design, but let them find it out themselves.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I shall agree to your Counsel.

div.head: Scene 14.
div.stage: Enter Mother Matron, and her Maid.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Come, come, I have watch'd and long'd for your Return above two hours, I may say above two years, for so the time did seem to me. O Venus, thou Fair and Amorous Godess, send me a comfortable Answer, if't be thy will!

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I have brought you a Letter from Monsieur Frisk; but for my part I know not what comfort he hath sent you.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: O Cupid, O Cupid, be my friend!

div.stage: She opens the Letter and reads it aloud.

body.head: The Letter.
body.p: THough Time hath made you sit for Heaven, having worn out your body, a substance for Love to work upon, converting or translating it all into Soul, an incorporeal shadow, which none but the Gods can imploy to any use; yet since you Esteem and Love me as a God, to resign up that incorporality, I can do no less than return you thanks, although I never did merit such a gift: But my sins, I confess are many, and deserve great punishments, yet I hope the Gods will be more merciful, than to leave me void of reason, or to suffer Nature to make me to have extravagant appetites, or Heaven to leave me to extravagant appetites; but howsoever, as occasions fall out, I shall shew reverence to your Motherly Gravitie, and in the mean time rest

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I know not by this Letter whether he will be my Lover, or not; yet I will kiss it for his sake.
O sweet Letter, thou happy Paper, that hast receiv'd the pressure of this hand! What did he say when he gave you this letter to bring me?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: He talk'd of Pluto, and of Hell.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: How, of Hell!

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Yes, but it was concerning AEneas and Dido.

div.stage: Mother Matron fetches a great sigh.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I hope he will not make me such an Example as Queen Dido, nor himself so false a Lover as AEneas; but if he should, I will cry out, O thou my cruel AEneas hast slain me!

div.head: Scene 15.
div.stage: Enter Superbe, Portrait, Faction, and Pleasure.

sp.speaker: FAction.
sp.p: Now I have seen Madamoiselle la Belle, I perceive Fame gives more praise than Nature Beauty.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: To some she doth.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Nay faith, for the most part, to all.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: O Ladies, there is the greatest loss befallen me, that ever befell man!

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: What loss?

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Why Madamoiselle la Belle is gone.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: How gone? Is she maried, or dead?

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Faith she's as bad as dead to me, and worse than if she were maried: for if she were a Wife, there would be some hopes; but her careful Father hath carry'd her away into the Country, being jealous of the much company that came to visit her.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: It seems he knew she was apt to be catch'd, that he durst not trust her: But how came you to receive a greater loss than the rest of the Masculine Visiters?

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Because I had greater hopes than I perceive the rest had.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Why, had you a design to get her for a Wife?

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: No faith, mine was a better design, which was to get her for a Mistris.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: But it was likely she would never have been your Mistris.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: It was likely she would have been my Mistris: for she was fair and foolish, kind and toyish, and had an inviting Eye.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Why you may follow her into the Country.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: No, the City is so well stored, as I shall not need to put my self to that trouble, as to journey after her.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: O Love! thou tormenter of soft hearts, or a melter of hard ones, soften the hard heart of Monsieur Frisk, and ease my soft and tender heart, inflame his spirits to love, and refresh mine with his kindness: O Venus, perswade thy Son in my behalf, and consider me by thy self! Ha, ho!

div.head: Scene 17.
div.stage: Enter Temparance, Faction, Portrait, Pleasure, Ambition, and Superbe.

sp.speaker: TEmperance.
sp.p: I would never have an extraordinary Beauty seen but once, and that should be in a publick Assembly.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: It is a sign, Temperance, your beauty is past: for would you have an extraordinary Beauty to be buried in oblivion?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: No: for I would have all the World see, if it could be shewn to the whole World; but I would have it shewn but once, and no more.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Because what is common, is never highly priz'd, but rather despis'd, or at least neglected by continuance: for that which is at first admir'd as a wonder, when it comes to be as domestick, is not regarded: for it is an old saying, That the greatest wonder lasts but nine days.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: But there is such a sympathy betwixt beauty and sight, that as long as beauty doth last, sight will take delight to look thereon; and the Design, End, or Fruition of Beauty, is to be gaz'd upon: for from the sight it receives Praise, Love, and Desire, and by reflection sets all hearts on fire.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: O that I had such a Beauty as would burn every Masculine heart into cinders!

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Why are you so cruel, Lady, to wish such a wish to the Masculine Sex?

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: My wish proceeds out of love to my self, and mercy to men. First, out of love to my self: for as I am a woman, I naturally desire Beauty, and there is no woman that had not rather have beauty, although attended with an unfortunate life, than be ill-savour'd, to enjoy prosperity.
The last wish is out of mercy to men: for their hearts are so false and foul, as no way but burning can purifie them.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: That were the way to try their constancy.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p:
For my part, if it were in my power to choose, I would rather have Wit than Beauty: for Wit pleaseth the Ear, both longer and more, than Beauty pleaseth the Sight, and the sound of the one, spreads farther
than the sight of the other: Besides, Wit recreate â€¢ the Mind, and entertains the Reason, Beauty only the Sense, and but one sense, as the sight, when Wit is a companion not only to the sense of Hearing, but the soul of Understanding; and it is not only a delightful Companion, but a subtil Observer, an ingenious Inventer, an excellent Artificer, a politick Counsellour, a powerful Commander, a prudent Ruler, and a divine Creator; it observes all natures works; it invents all useful Arts, it frames all Common-wealths, it guides the Senses, rules the Appetites, commands the Passions, counsels the Thoughts, regulates the Opinions, creates the Conceptions, Imaginations, and Fancies; it builds Potiecal Castles, and makes Gardens of Rhetorick, and makes the sound Harmonical, playing with words, as on musical Instruments: Besides, Wit continues to old Age, when Beauty vades in a year or two.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Come, come, Temperance, if you were young, you would prefer Beauty before a Wit, by which you might get more pleasure by the one, than profit by the other: But all our Sex, when they grow in years, desire to be thought Wits, when they can no longer be thought Beauties, which makes them dispute for Wit, and dispraise Beauty, by undervaluing it.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Madamoiselle Bon' Esprit, you are welcom: for we long to hear the success of your design, since we have heard that Monsieur Satyrical hath been to visit you, hath he not?

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: But have you catch'd him?

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Sure enough.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Then strangle him with Cupids bow-string.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Hang him, that's not punishment enough.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: No; but when he's a confirm'd Lover, report he's mad.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: We shall not need to report that: for when he is a confirm'd Lover, he will do such ridiculous actions, and behave himself so extravagantly vain, and so constrainly foolish, and speak such non-sense, in striving to speak beyond the power of words, insomuch as all that hear and see him, will swear he's mad.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: They will swear nothing but the truth; for all Lovers are mad, more or less. But Madamoiselle Bon' Esprit, are you sure you have him in Cupids snare?

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: I do verily believe I have him in Loves bonds.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: O how I joy, to think how we shall triumph!

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: What shall our Triumphant-Chariot be?

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Scorns, scorns, set on the wheels of laughter, drawn by a company of lame, sore, scurvy words.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Will you have your Triumphant-Chariot drawn by a company of foolish words? that will be as bad, and as much disgrace, as lean-jaded horses in a brave gilded Coach.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: No, no, sprightly jests were better.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: They may chance to run you out of the field of Civility, at least out of the right ways of Wit.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Let them run where they will, so they carry his reproach with them.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Will you carry this reproach along with you, and leave him behind you?

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: We will carry his reproach about the World.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: While you bear the burthen, he will rest at home in ease and peace in his mind.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Good Lord, what makes you thus to contradict our Designs?

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: I do not contradict your Designs, but shew you the Errour of your Conduct.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Why then conduct us better.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: So I shall, if you will give me leave: for I shall conduct you through the fair ways: of peace, and not through the foul ways of malice, which are myery and deep with revenge, in which you may stick, or be thrown in disgrace; but I will carry you through the sweet Meadows of good Nature, wherein runs clear Rivulets of Charity, in which you may bathe your selves under the fruitful trees of good works, and take the fresh Air of Applause, and be cool'd with the soft winds of Praise. Thus wash'd, cleans'd, and refresh'd, you will be fit to enter into the Palace of Fame.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Heyday, where will your Tongue carry us?

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: As high as it can, even to the House of Fame, which stands on the highest pinacle of Heaven.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Let me examine you, Are you not carry'd by love to the top of Parnassus Hill?

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: By Iupiter, she that went to catch Love, is catch'd by Love her self.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Venus forbid: for that would be such a disgrace, as we shall be never able to pull off, or rub out.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: What you cannot rub out, or pull off, you must be content to wear with patience.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: I suspect her.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: I confess I doubt her.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: I fear your doubts.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: I am confident we have lost her, striving to catch him.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Let us follow her, and examine her.

div.head: Scene 18.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Sensuality, and Monsieur Censure.

sp.speaker: SEnsuality.
sp.p: I hear that thou intend'st to be a marry'd man shortly.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Yes faith, I am going to put my neck into the nooze.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Nay, if you nooze it, hang it; for the nooze of mariage is ten times worse than the halter of death.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: I am not of your Opinion.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Why then thou art not of a wise opinion: for in Death there is no trouble, and in Mariage no quiet.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: A single life is melancholy, being solitary.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: So I perceive rather than you'l want company, thou wilt associate thy self with cares and vexations.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: No, I will associate my self with Wife and Children.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Well, let me tell you, if that thou marriest, a hundred to one but thou wilt be a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: I hope not.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: How canst thou have hopes, when that the Gods are Cuckolds? wherefore 'tis impossible mortal men should escape.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: All the Gods are not so, it is but only limping Vulcan that is one.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Pardon me: for if their divine Wives make them not Cuckolds, yet their humane Wives do.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: But the Gods marry not humane creatures.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: But humane creatures marry the Gods, and that is all one: for in all Religions there are Nuns are the Gods humane wives; and did not Cataline Cuckold the Gods, when he lay with a Vestal Nun? And many more are mentioned in Story, and you may well believe all are not Recorded.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Well, if the Gods be Cuckolds, I may have the less cause to murmur, if I should be one: for it is an honour to be like the God.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: VVell, I wish as thy friend, that thou mayst flourish in that Honour.

div.head: Scene 19.
div.stage: Enter Ambition, Faction, Pleasure, Portrait, Superbe, Temperance, as following Madamoiselle Bon' Esprit.

sp.speaker: PLeasure.
sp.p: VVe do not like your dark Answers: for Truth is clear.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Confess, have you deceived us, or not?

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: I have not deceived you: for you did intrust me to draw him to Love, and to be in love as a Lover, and I have discharged your trust, and have brought your designs to pass.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: But our designs were not that he should be beloved of you, but hated of all our Sex.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Why then you did spread your designs beyond your reach: for do you think you have the power of Fate, to rule, govern, and dispose of the passions of Mankind as you please, when alas you are so powerless, as you cannot rule, govern, and dispose of your own passions, and so ignorant, that you know not your own destinies, nor how, nor to what your passions will lead you to: Besides, you injoyn'd not my passions, you did not forbid me to love him, but only imploy'd my Wit to make him a Lover, and so I have.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: And you have prov'd your self a Fool, in becoming a Lover.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Losers may have leave to speak any thing, and therefore I will not quarrel with you.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: We are not losers by the loss of you.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: But we are, for with the loss of her, we have lost our sweet revenge: for by her we thought to have catch'd him like a Woodcock in a Net, and then to have cut off his wings of Fancy, and to have pull'd out his feathers of Pride, or else to have intic'd him like a fool with a rattle, and then to have toss'd him on Satyrical Tongues, as in a blanket of shame: But now, instead of a blanket of shame, he will lie in the Arms of Beauty, and instead of being toss'd with satyrical tongues, he will be flatter'd with kisses, for which we may curse the Fates.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: But it is strange to me, that she can love such a railing ill-natur'd man as Monsieur Satyrical.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: I wonder she doth not blush at her choise! Are you not out of countenance, to be in love with such a man, that is the worst of men?

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: Confess, do not you repent?

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: So far am I from repenting, as I love him so well, as he seems to me to be such a person, as to be so much above the rest of Mankind, as he ought to be ador'd, worship'd, kneel'd down and pray'd to, as to a Deity; and the beginning of those prayers offer'd to him should be, O thou worthyest, meritoriousest, and hest of men!

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: She's mad, she's stark mad: wherefore let us binde her with chains, and whip her with cords, to bring her to her wits again.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Oh Sir, you are a person born to relieve the distressed, and comfort the afflicted: for you are come in a timely hour, to release me from a company of Furies that threaten me.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: These Ladies appear too fair to be the daughters of Night, who are said to be the Furies. But Ladies, I hope you will pardon me for taking away so pleasing a companion from you as my Mistris is; but by her I shall be made Master of a world of happiness, and I shall not only enjoy a world, but a Heavenly Paradise, wherein all Goodness, Virtues, Beauties, and sweet Graces are planted: And what man would not challenge or claim Heaven, if Heaven could be gain'd by claiming; wherefore I challenge and claim this Lady, as being mine to enjoy.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: If you had challeng'd or claim'd any other Lady, in my conscience you would have been refused.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I desire no more than what I have.

div.stage: Exit Satyrical, and his Mistris Bon' Esprit.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: I could cry with anger.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Ladies, take my counsel, which is, to be friends with Madam Bon' Esprit, and Monsieur Satyrical, otherwise they will laugh at you to see what fools they have made you.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: She gives us good advice; wherefore let us follow it, and be friends.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: I may be seemingly friends, but never really friends.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Why seeming friendship passes and traffiques as well in the world, as those that are real.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: You say well: wherefore let us seem to be friends.

div.head: Scene 20.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Frisk, and Mother Matrons Maid.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: My fair Maid, what Message have you brought me now?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: My Mistris remembers her loving love unto you, and bids me tell you, that she takes it wondrous unkindly that you shew'd the young Ladies the Letter, and that she heard you mock'd and jeer'd at her.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Tell her I did but as all Lovers use to do, vaunt of their Mistris's love, and boast of their Mistris's favours.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: She doth not like your boasting; but howsoever, to shew and express her constant love and affectionate heart, she hath sent you two hundred pounds to buy you a Nag.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: I accept of the Present, and tell her I will ride the Nag for her sake.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: My Mistris will be a joy'd Woman, to hear that you will ride for her sake.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: But is thy Mistris rich?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Yes by my truth is she; for she hath store of bags in her Chests.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: But are they full of gold and silver?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Yes: for I have seen her tell the money in the bags, bag after bag.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Is it all her own?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Yes certainly it is all her own.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: How came she to be so rich?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Why the young Ladies Parents give her money or moneys worth to Govern and Educate their Daughters, and the young Ladies bribe her to keep their counsels, and fee her to be their Agent, and their Courtly Servants present her with rich gifts to prefer their Sutes, and to speak in their behalfs to the young Ladies; and thus she gains on every side, and takes gifts on both hands, and she being miserable and sparing, must needs be rich; but now she is become a Lover, she begins to grow prodigal, as all Lovers are; but if she had a million, she says, nay swears, she could bestow it all on her beloved, which beloved is your Worship.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: I could be well content to marry her wealth, and lie with her Maid, but I would not be troubled with the Mistris.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: My Mistris, I believe, will be a very fond Wife.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: And that fondness is the second obstacle I stick at: for first to be old, and then to be fond, will be a double misery, as being an intolerable trouble, and a nauseous vexation; for there is nothing more hateful, than an amorous fond old woman: But if thou wilt be fond of me, I shall like it well; and if any thing could perswade me to marry thy Mistris, next to her wealth, will be in hopes of thy kindness. What say you, will you be kind?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I shall not be undutiful: when you are my Master, I shall deny no service I can do your Worship.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: That's well promis'd: In the mean time remember me to thy Mistris, and thank her for her Present, and tell her, the more such Presents she sends, the welcomer they shall be.

div.head: Scene 21.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Sensuality, and Madamoiselle Portrait.

sp.speaker: SEnsuality.
sp.p: Madamoiselle, you may do a charitable Act.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: As to marry me.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: If it be a Charity to you, it would be none to my self, but the contrary: I should prove cruel to my self, in making my life unhappy.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Yet it will be a meritorious Act: for what is more meritorious than to save a soul?

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: So I shall rob Pluto of his due and just right.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: He will never miss his loss: for on my Conscience he is not so good an Arithmetician, as he could count and number the Millions of souls he hath in Hell, or those he hath right to; nay, if he had the skill of Utlick, he could not number them, for they surmount all Accounts.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: But the torments he puts souls, to will â€¢ ind them out.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: It is a question whether souls are capable of torments; but howsoever; to put it out of question, pray marry me: for I am become of a sudden very consentious.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: But there will be another question, which is, Whether Mariage will save you, or not?

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: O yes: for the Purgatory of Mariage doth purifie Souls, and make them fit for Heaven.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: But I fear, if I should marry you, I should do like those that strive to save a drowning man; so I, indeavouring to save you, should lose my self.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: There is no Honourable Act, without some danger to the Actor.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: But all wise Actions have security.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: There is no security in Nature.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: I will consider, although after a wise consideration I do a foolish action, as most considerers do.

div.head: Scene 22.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Heroick, and Madamoiselle Ambition.

sp.speaker: HEroick.
sp.p: Madam, I hear I live in your good Opinion.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Your merits do.

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: I hope if you do esteem my merits, if I have merits to be esteem'd, you will not despise my Person, nor deny my Sute.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: I esteem of your person for your merits sake, and those that have merits, and are worthy, will make no ignoble Sute: wherefore I may grant it before I know it.

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: My Sute is, to accept of me for your Husband.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: I shall not deny to be your Wife.

div.stage: Enter as to these Couple all the Cabal, as Pleasure, Portrait, Faction, Superbe, Bon' Esprit, Temperance, Matron, Wanton, Excess, Ease, Tranquillitous Peace, Vain-glorious, Censure, Satyrical, Frisk, Sensuality, Busie, Inquisitive, Liberty.

sp.speaker: Tranquill.
sp.p: Well met, Monsieur Heroical, and Madamoiselle Ambition.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: Now we are all met, how shall we pass the time away?

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: Nay rather, how shall we recreate our time?

sp.speaker: Vain-glor.
sp.p: Let us sit and declare what we love or hate.

sp.speaker: All speak.
sp.p: Agreed,

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: Shall we declare our love or our hate first?

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Our love first.

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: Nay faith let love close up our discourse.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Then let hate be the Gentleman-Usher.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: She will usher you into foul ways.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Let her usher us into as foul ways as she will, we will follow her.

sp.speaker: All speak.
sp.p: Begin, begin.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: I hate poverty: for that dejects the Spirits, and oppresseth the Life.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I hate falshood: for that deceives my Reason, and blind-folds my Senses.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: I hate a fool, because he obstructs my Understanding, and sets my Brain on the Rack.

sp.speaker: Tranquill.
sp.p: I hate noise, because it disturbs my thoughts, hurts my hearing, and buries sense, reason, and auricular words.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: I hate sickness, because it is a friend to Death.

sp.speaker: Vain-glor.
sp.p: I hate vain follies, because they bring neither content, pleasure, nor profit.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: I hate a Court, because it puts Modesty out of countenance, Patience out of humour, and Merit out of favour.

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: I hate a slavish Peace, because there is no imployment for noble active spirits.

sp.speaker: Excess.
sp.p: I hate truth, because it tells me my faults.

sp.speaker: Busie.
sp.p: I hate truth, because it hinders my search thereof.

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: I hate motion, because therein there is no rest.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: I hate rest, because it makes no Inquiries.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: I hate life, because therein is more pain and trouble than pleasure or peace.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: I hate restraint, because it inslaves life.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: I hate a Nunnery, because it doth not only restrain, but bar out Sex from the sight of men.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Thou lovest men well, that their very sight delights thee.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: I hate light, because it discovers Lovers.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: I hate darkness, because it conceals Adulteries.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: I hate a chaste Beauty, because she quenches my hopes, and inflames my desires.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: I hate Madamoiselle la Belle, because Monsieur Sensuality did like her.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: I hate Age: for that vades Beauty, and banishes Lovers.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: No more of Age and Hate, take Love without Beauty.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: Mother Matron would have you take her.

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: Nay faith we will leave Mother Matron, and begin with Love.

sp.speaker: Inquisitive.
sp.p: I love plenty: for in plenty lives happiness.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: I love freedom: for in freedom lives pleasure.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: By your favour, Plenty may want happiness, and Freedom pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: I love to go to Church.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: What, to hear a Sermon?

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: No, to meet a Mistris.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Out upon thee thou Reprobate, would you make a Church a Bawdy-house?

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: No, I would make that place where Beauties were, a Church, and the fairest should be the Godess I would pray to.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: There are not any that are fair will hear you.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: And those that are foul I will not pray to.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Follow Love: for that makes all things fair and pleasing.

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: I love silence: for in silence my life lives easily, my thoughts freely, and my mind harmoniously.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Sometimes the thoughts disturb the mind, and so the life, more than noise disturbs the thoughts.

sp.speaker: Vain-glor.
sp.p: I love Honour: for in Honour lives Respect.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: I love Beauty: for in Beauty lives admiration.

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: I love Fame: for in Fame lives the memory of the best of my Actions.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: I love power: for in power lives Adorations.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I love Wit: for that delights my self, and recreates my friends.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: I love Eloquence: for that delights my Ear.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: But Eloquence will deceive your Judgment, delude your Understanding, and flatter your Passions with insinuating perswasions, and will draw you into an Erroneous Belief, and by that unto unjust actions.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: I love Madamoiselle Portrait.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: I love Monsieur Sensuality.

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: I love Madamoiselle Ambition.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: I love Monsieur Heroick.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: I love Madamoiselle Bon' Esprit.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: I love Monsieur Satyrical.

sp.speaker: Vain-glor.
sp.p: I love Madamoiselle Superbe.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: I love Monsieur Vain-glorious.

sp.speaker: Tranquill.
sp.p: I love Madamoiselle Pleasure.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: I love Monsieur Tranquillitous Peace.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: I love Madamoiselle Faction.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: I love Monsieur Censure.

sp.speaker: Busie.
sp.p: I love ma filia Excess.

sp.speaker: Excess.
sp.p: I love Monsieur Busie.

sp.speaker: Liberty.
sp.p: I love ma filia Wanton.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: I love Monsieur Liberty.

sp.speaker: Ease.
sp.p: I love a single life: for in Mariage lives too much trouble to live in Ease.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: I love to continue a Widow: for Temperance is banish'd from most places and persons.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: I love Monsieur Frisk; but Monsieur Frisk loves not me.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Faith I'll perswade him to love, if not thy person, yet thy wealth; for thou art rich, and he hath hardly enough means to bear up his Gentility: Besides, one Maid and one Widow is enough, more would be too much.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: And one Batchelour.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Monsieur Inquisitive.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: Faith 'tis fit and proper he should live a Batchelour: for an Inquisitive Husband would not be good, neither for his own sake, nor his Wifes.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: But Gentlemen and Ladies, although you all say you love such a Lady, and such a Lady loves such a Gentleman, yet you do not say you will marry each other.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: You may be sure, if we do publickly profess love, we intend to marry: for though we may love and not marry, or marry and not love, yet not profess it in an open Assembly; for Love without Mariage lives incognito.

sp.speaker: Tranquill.
sp.p: But mariage without love is visible enough: for it lies to the view of all their neighbours knowledge.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Well, noble Gentlemen, and vertuous Ladies, if you resolve all to marry, I would advise you to marry all in one day.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: O Madam Temperance, you are sick.

sp.speaker: Temperance.
sp.p: Why?

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: By reason healthful temperance never gives such surfetting counsel: for there are as many of us as might be marying a year, and keeping their Festivals, and you would have all marry'd in one day.

sp.speaker: Ambition.
sp.p: Madam Temperance means, she would have a whole year as one Wedding-day

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: And one Wedding-day to the Bride and Bridegroom, is as one whole year.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: Not to every Bride and Bridegroom: for on my Conscience Monsieur Frisk, if he should marry Mother Matron, will think his Wedding-day but a minute long.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: But Mother Matron will think the day an Age.

sp.speaker: Portrait.
sp.p: You speak so loud, she'l hear you.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: O no, for the most part she is deaf: for she many times stops wool into her ears to keep out the cold.

sp.speaker: 1 GEntlem.
sp.p: I hear that Wits Cabal is removing out of Cupids Court into Hymens prison, and there to be bound in bonds of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Faith I pity the Cabal, and condemn their Wit, by reason it did not keep them out of slavery.

sp.speaker: 1 Gentle.
sp.p: Wit is both a Pander and a Traitor: for Wit is a Pimp in Cupids Court, and betrays his Court to Hymens Prison.

sp.speaker: 2 Gentlem.
sp.p: There are no prisoners look so dejectedly as Hymens prisoners.

sp.speaker: 1 Gentle.
sp.p: There is great reason for it: for they are almost starv'd for want of variety, and they have less liberty than other prisoners have.

sp.speaker: 1 GEnt.
sp.p: You hear of the great Mariages that are concluded on, and they are to be dispatch'd out of hand.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Hear of them (say you) I must stop my Ears, and shut my Eyes, if I did not both hear and see their preparations: for all the Tradesmen are so busily imploy'd, as if they were never to sell or work more after these Mariages.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: What Tradesmen are those?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Why Taylors, Shoomakers, Hosiers, Seamstresses, Feather-men, Periwig-makers, Perfumers, Clothiers, Linnengers, Silk men, Mercers, Milleners, Haberdashers, Curlers, Spurriers, Sadlers, Coach-makers, Upholstorers, besides Confectioners, Cooks, Bakers, Brewers, Butchers, Poulterers, and twenty more I cannot think of.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: They will kill and destroy so many creatures for their Feasts, that they will make a massacre.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: A Famine I think:

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: But there will be great dancings at the Court they say: for three will be Masks, Plays, Balls, and such braveries as never was.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: These publick Weddings, and such publick Revellings, put the Gentry to more charges, than many times they are able to spare; which if it were not for Revelling, there would be no need of such vain and idle Expences.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: I mean to be at some charges, as to make me a new Suit or two of Cloaths.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Faith I will spare my purse, and stay at home.

div.head: Scene 25.
div.stage: Enter the several Couples, Heroick and Ambition, Tranquillitous Peace and Pleasure, Satyrical and Bon' Esprit, Vain-glorious and Superbe, Censure and Faction, Sensuality and Portrait, Busie and Excess, Liberty and Wanton, Frisk and Mother Matron.

sp.speaker: VAinglor.
sp.p: Where will you keep your Wedding-Feast?

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: We will keep ours at the Court.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: So will we.

sp.speaker: Vain-glor.
sp.p: And so will we.

sp.speaker: Busie.
sp.p: And so will we.

sp.speaker: Tranquill.
sp.p: If you please, Mistris, we will keep ours in the Country.

sp.speaker: Pleasure.
sp.p: I approve of it.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: If my Mistris agree, we will keep ours at the Play-house, and feast and dance upon the Stage.

sp.speaker: Bon' Esprit.
sp.p: I agree and approve of your Choice.

sp.speaker: Censure.
sp.p: An Ordinary, or Tavern, is a more commodious place for the Society of the Wits: for I am sure all the Wits will meet there.

sp.speaker: Satyrical.
sp.p: But if an Ordinary, or Tavern, be more commodious, yet they are not so publick places as the Theaters of Players; so that Wits may be merrier and freer in a Tavern, but not so divulged as on a Stage in a Play-House.

sp.speaker: Heroick.
sp.p: The truth is, an Ordinary or Tavern is a more proper place for Monsieur Sensuality and his Mistris to keep their Wedding-Feast, than for Monsieur Satyrical and his Mistris.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: By your favour, the most proper place for us is the Court.

sp.speaker: Busie.
sp.p: I think that an Hospitable Gentlemans House in the Country, is most proper for Monsieur Sensuality to keep his Wedding-Feast in.

sp.speaker: Superbe.
sp.p: That is a more proper place for Liberty and Wanton.

sp.speaker: Faction.
sp.p: Nay, by your favour, another House (which shall be nameless, for fear of offending) is fitter for them.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: My Honey sweet Love, where shall we keep our Wedding-Feast?

sp.speaker: Frisk.
sp.p: For your sake, my Sugar-sweeting, we will keep it in Bedlam, and Monsieur Busie and his Bride shall keep us company.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: Thou art a very wag, my Love.

sp.speaker: Sensuality.
sp.p: Pray Jove we speed.

list.head: The Actors Names â€¢
list.item: Madam Bonit, the first Wife of Monsieur Malateste.
Madamoiselle Amor, daughter to Monsieur Sensible.
Nan and Jone, two Maid-servants of Madam Bonit.

div.head: PROLOGUE.
div.l: A Tragedy I usher in to day,
All Mirth is banish'd in this Serious Play;
Yet sad Contentment may She to you bring,
In pleas'd Expressions of each sev'ral thing.
Our Poetress is confident, no Fears,
Though 'gainst her Sex the Tragick Buskins wears,
But you will like it, some few howers spent,
She'l know your Censure by your hands what's meant.
div.byline: This Prologue was written by my Lord Marquiss of Newcastle.

div.head: Scene 1.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Frere, and his Friend.

sp.speaker: MOnsieur Frere.
sp.p: Since we are come out of our own Country to travel, we will go into Turky, if you will, and see that Country.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: With all my heart; but now I think on't better, I will stay here a while longer for the Curtezans sake; for we shall never get such store, nor such choise of Mistrisses; therefore, though the sober and chaste women are kept up here in Italy, yet the wild and wanton are let loose to take their liberty: But in Turky, that barbarous Country, all are kept close, those that will, as well as those that will not; but if they had the custome of Italy, to keep up only their honest women, it were a Charity: for otherwise a man loses his time in Courting those women that will not accept of his love: for how should a man know whether women will, or will not, having all sober faces, and demure countenances, coy carriages, and denying words?

sp.speaker: Frere.
sp.p: But yet they consent at last: for Importunity and Opportunity, 'tis said, wins the chastest â€¢ he.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Faith all the flowry Rhetorick, and the most observing times, and fittest opportunities, and counterfeiting dyings, win nothing upon a cold Icy Constitution, or an obstinate Morality; 'tis true, it may work some good effect upon an Icy Conscience.

div.stage: Enter a man to Monsieur Frere with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Frere.
sp.p: From whence comes that Letter?.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: From France Sir I believe, from your Father.

div.stage: He opens it, and reads it to himself.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What News? Hath thy Father sent thee money?

sp.speaker: Frere.
sp.p: Yes, but it is to return home: for he hath sent me word my Sister is marry'd to a very rich, honest, and sweet-natur'd man; and that also he would have me come home to marry a rich Heir, one that is his Neighbors Daughter: for my Father says he desires to see me setled in the World before he dies, having but us two, my Sister and I.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why, is he sick, that he talks of dying?

sp.speaker: Frere.
sp.p: No, but he is old, and that is more certain of Deaths approach.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: But is your sister marry'd, say you?

sp.speaker: Frere.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Faith I am sorry for't: for I thought to have marry'd her myself.

sp.speaker: Frere.
sp.p: Marry she would have had but a wilde Husband, if she had marry'd you.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: The thoughts of this Rich Heir, make thee speak most precisely, as if thou wert the most temperate man in the world, when there is none so deboist as thou art.

sp.speaker: Frere.
sp.p: Prethee hold thy tongue, for I am very discreet.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Yes, to hide thy faults, to dissemble thy passions, and to compass thy desires; but not to abate any of them: Well, if thy sister had not been marry'd, I would have prais'd thee, but now I will rail against thee: for losers may have leave to talk.

sp.speaker: Frere.
sp.p: Why, what hopes could you have had to marry her?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: VVhy, I was thy Friend, and that was hope enough. But is thy sister so handsome as Fame reports her?

sp.speaker: Frere.
sp.p: I cannot tell; for I never saw her since I was a little boy, and she a very child, I being kept strictly at School, and from thence to the University: And when I was to travel, I went home, but then she was at an Ants house a hundred miles from my Fathers house, so as I saw her not; but I must leave off this discourse, unless you'l return into France with me.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No faith, thou shalt return without me: for I will not goe so soon, unless my Friends had provided me a rich Heiress to welcom me home; but since they have not, I mean to stay and entertain my self and time with the plump Venetians.

sp.speaker: Frere.
sp.p: Fare thee well Friend, and take heed you entertain not a disease.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Thou speakest as if thou wert a Convertito.

div.head: Scene 2.
div.stage: Enter Madam Bonit alone, and s â€¢ ts down to work, as sowing; as she is working, Monsieur Malateste, her Husband, enters.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Malateste.
sp.p: You are always at work, for what use is it? You spend more money in silk, cruel, thread, and the like, than all your work is worth.

sp.speaker: Madam Bonit.
sp.p: I am now making you bands.

sp.speaker: Malateste.
sp.p: Pray let my bands alone: for I'm sure they will be so ill-favour'd as I cannot wear them.

sp.speaker: Bonit.
sp.p: Do not condemn them before you have try'd them.

sp.speaker: Malateste.
sp.p: You may make them; but I wi'l never wear them.

sp.speaker: Bonit.
sp.p: Well, I will not make them, since you dislike it.

sp.speaker: 1 GEnt.
sp.p: Come, will you go to the Gaming-house?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: What to do?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: To play at Cards, or the like Games.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: I will never play at such Games but with women.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Because they are Effeminate Pastimes; and not manly Actions; neither will I meerly rely upon Fortunes favour without merit, as Gamesters do.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Why then will you go to a Tavern?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: To drink.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: I am not thirsty.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: But I would have you drink until you are thirsty.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: That's to drink drunk.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: And that's that I desire to be.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Why drunk.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: So do not I: for I will not wilfully make my self uncapable, as I can neither be able to serve my King, Country, nor Friend, nor defend my Honour: for when I am drunk, I can do neither; for a man drunk, I weaker than a child that hath not strength to go or stand; and is worse than those that are dumb, for the dumb keep silence, when those that are drunk, doe stutter and stammer out non-sense, and make themselves fools; besides, every Coward will take courage to beat, at least affront a man that is drunk, when as he dares not look ascue, or come near him without respect, when he is sober.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Come, come, thou shalt go, if it be but to decide our drunken quarrels, and allay the wrathful vapour of Bacchus.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: No, I will never decide the disputes of Fool, Mad-men, Drunkards, nor Women: for Fools understand no Reason, Mad-men have lost their Reason, Drunkards will hear no Reason, and Women are not capable of Reason.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Why are women not capable of Reason?

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Because it is thought, or rather believ'd, that women have no rational souls, being created out of man, and not from Iove, as man was.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: If Iove hath not given them rational fouls, I am sure Nature hath given them beautiful bodies, with which Iove is enamour'd, or else the Poets lye.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Poets describe Iove according to their own passions, and after their own appetites.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Poets are Ioves Priests.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: And Natures Panders.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Well, if you will neither go to the Gaming-house, Tavern, nor Bawdy-house, will you go and visit the sociable Virgins.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p:
Yes, I like sociable Virginity very well. But pray what are those
sociable Virgins, which you would have me go to see?

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: VVhy a company of young Ladies that meet every day to discourse and talk, to examine, censure, and judge of every body, and of every thing.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: 'Tis pity, if they have not learn'd the rules of Logick, if they talk so much, that they may talk sense.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: I will assure you they have voluble Tongues, and quick VVits.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Let us go then.

div.head: Scene 4.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Malateste, to his Wife Madam Bonit.

sp.speaker: MAlateste.
sp.p: Lord, how ill-favour'd you are drest to day!

sp.speaker: Bonit.
sp.p: VVhy I am cleanly.

sp.speaker: Malateste.
sp.p: You had need be so: for if you were ill-favour'dly drest and sluttish too, it were not to be endur'd.

sp.speaker: Bonit.
sp.p: VVell Husband, I will strive to be more fashionably drest.

div.head: Scene 5.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Pere, and Monsieur Frere, as newly come from Travelling.

sp.speaker: MOnsieur Pere.
sp.p: Well Son, but that you are as a stranger, having not seen you in a long time, I would otherwise have chid you for spending so much since you went to travel.

sp.speaker: Frere.
sp.p: Sir, travelling is chargeable, especially when a man goeth to inform himself of the Fashions, Maners, Customs, and Countries he travelleth through.

div.stage: Enter Madam la Soeur, and Monsieur Marry, her Husband, where they salute and welcome their Brother home.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.p: Look you Son, I have increas'd my Family since you went from home, your Sisters Beauty hath got me another Son.

sp.speaker: Soeur.
sp.p: And I make no question but my Brothers noble and gallant Actions will get you another Daughter.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.p: Well Son, I must have you make haste and marry, that you may give me some Grand-children to uphold my Posterity, for I have but you two; and your sister, I hope, will bring me a Grand-son soon: for her Maids say she is sick a mornings, which is a good sign she is breeding, although she will not confess it: for young marry'd Wives are asham'd to confess when they are with Child, they keep it as private, as if their Child were unlawfully begotten.

div.stage: Monsieur Frere all the while looks upon his Sister very stedfastly.

sp.speaker: Marry.
sp.p: Me thinks my Brother doth something resemble my Wife.

sp.speaker: Frere.
sp.p: No sure, Brother, so rude a made face as mine, can never resemble so well a shap'd face as my sisters.

sp.speaker: Marry.
sp.p: I believe the Venetian Ladies had a better opinion of your face and person than you deliver of your self.

sp.speaker: Soeur.
sp.p: My Brother cannot choose but be weary, comming so long a Journey to day: wherefore it were fit we should leave him to pull off his boots.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.p: Son, now I think of't, I doubt you are grown so tender since you went into Italy, as you can hardly endure your boots to be roughly pull'd off.

sp.speaker: Frere.
sp.p: I am very sound Sir, and in very good health.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.p: Art thou so? Come thy ways then.

div.head: Scene 6.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Malateste, and Madam Bonit his Wife.

sp.speaker: MAlateste.
sp.p: Wife, I have some occasion to sell some Land, and I have none that is so convenient to sell as your Joynture.

sp.speaker: Bonit.
sp.p: All my Friends will condemn me for a fool, if I should part with my Joynture.

sp.speaker: Malateste.
sp.p: Why then you will not part with it?

sp.speaker: Bonit.
sp.p: I do not say so: for I think you so honest a man, that if you should die before me, as Heaven forbid you should.

sp.speaker: Malateste.
sp.p: Nay leave your prayers.

sp.speaker: Bonit.
sp.p: Well Husband; you shall have my Joynture

sp.speaker: Malateste.
sp.p: If I shall, go fetch it.

div.stage: She goes out, and comes back and brings the writings, and gives it him, and then he makes haste to be gone.

sp.speaker: Bonit.
sp.p: Surely Husband, I deserve a kiss for't.

sp.speaker: Malateste.
sp.p: I cannot stay to kiss.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: Madam, what will you have for your supper: for I hear my Master doth not sup at home.

sp.speaker: Bonit.
sp.p: Any thing Ione, a little Ponado, or Water-gruel.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: Your Ladyships Diet is not costly.

div.p: It satisfies Nature as well as costly Olio's or Bisks; and I desire onely to feed my Hunger, not my Gusto: for I am neither gluttonous nor lickerish.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: No, I'll be sworn are you not.

div.head: Scene 7.
div.stage: Enter the Sociable Virgins, and two Grave Matrons.

sp.speaker: MAtron.
sp.p: Come Ladies, what discourse shall we have to day?

sp.speaker: 1 Virgin.
sp.p: Let us sit and rail against men.

sp.speaker: 2 Matron.
sp.p: I know young Ladies love men too well to rail against them; besides, men always praise the Effeminate Sex, and will you rail at those that praise you?

sp.speaker: 2 Virgin.
sp.p: Though men praise us before our faces, they rail at us behind our backs.

sp.speaker: 2 Matron.
sp.p: That's when you are unkind, or cruel.

sp.speaker: 3 Virgin.
sp.p: No, 'tis when we have been too kind, and they have taken a surfet of our company.

sp.speaker: 1 Matron.
sp.p: Indeed an over-plus of Kindness, will soon surfet a mans Affection.

sp.speaker: 4 Virgin.
sp.p: Wherefore I hate them, and resolve to live a single life; and so much I hate men, that if the power of Alexander and Caesar were joyn'd into one Army, and the courage of Achilles and Hector were joyn'd into one Heart, and the wisedom of Solomon and Ulysses into one Brain, and the Eloquence of Tully and Demosthenes into one Tongue, and this all in one man, and had this man the Beauty of Narcissus, and the youth of Adonis, and would marry me, I would not marry him.

sp.speaker: 2 Matron.
sp.p: Lady, let me tell you, the Youth and Beauty would tempt you much.

sp.speaker: 4 Virgin.
sp.p: You are deceiv'd: for if I would marry, I would sooner marry one that were in years: for it were better to chuse grave Age, than fantastical Youth; but howsoever, I will never marry: for those that are unmaried, appear like birds, full of life and spirit; but those that are maried, appear like beasts, dull and heavy, especially maried men.

sp.speaker: 1 Matron.
sp.p: Men never appear like beasts, but when women make them so.

sp.speaker: 1 Virgin.
sp.p: They deserve to be made beasts, when they strive to make women fools.

sp.speaker: 2 Virgin.
sp.p: Nay, they rather think us fools, than make us so: for most Husbands think, when their Wives are good and obedient, that they are simple.

sp.speaker: 1 Virgin.
sp.p: When I am maried, I'll never give my Husband cause to think me simple for my obedience: for I will be crose enough.

sp.speaker: 3 Virg.
sp.p: That's the best way: for Husbands think a cross and contradicting Wife is witty; a hold and commanding Wife, of a heroick spirit; a subtil and crafty Wife to be wise, a prodigal Wife to be generous, a false Wife to be beautiful: And for those good qualities he loves her best, otherwise he hates her; nay, the falser she is, the fonder he is of her.

sp.speaker: 4 Virgin.
sp.p: Nay, by your favour, for the most part, Wives are so inslav'd, as they dare not look upon any man but their Husbands.

sp.speaker: 1 Matron.
sp.p: What better object can a woman have than her Husband?

sp.speaker: 1 Virgin.
sp.p:
By your leave, Matron, one object is tiresome to view often, when variety of objects are very pleasing and delightful: for variety of objects clear the senses, and refresh the mind, when only one object dulls both
sense and mind, that makes maried wives so sad and melancholy, when they keep no other company but their Husbands; and in truth they have reason: for a Husband is a surfet to the Eyes, which causes a loathing dislike unto the mind; and the truth is, that variety is the life and delight of Natures works, and Women being the only Daughters of Nature, and not the Sons of Iove, as men are feigned to be, are more pleased with variety, than men are.

sp.speaker: 1 Matron.
sp.p: Which is no honour to the Effeminate Sex; but I perceive, Lady, you are a right begotten daughter of Nature, and will follow the steps of your Mother.

sp.speaker: 1 Virgin.
sp.p: Yes, or else I should be unnatural, which I will never be.

div.head: Scene 8.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Pere, and Monsieur Frere.

sp.speaker: MOnsieur Frere.
sp.p: Sir, I wonder, since my sister is so handsome, that you did not marry her more to her advantage.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.p: Why Son, I think I have marry'd her very well for your advantage: for her beauty was her only Portion, and she is marry'd to a noble Gentleman who hath a very great Estate.

sp.speaker: Frere.
sp.p: But Sir, her beauty doth deserve a King, nay an Emperour, a Caesar of the World.

sp.speaker: Pere.
sp.p: O Son, you are young, which makes you partial on your sisters side.

div.head: Scene 9.
div.stage: Enter Madam Bonit, and her Maid Nan.

sp.speaker: BOnit.
sp.p: It's a strange forgetfulness not to come near me in two hours, but let me sit without a fire: if you were my Mistris, I should make a conscience to be more diligent than you are, if I did take wages for my service as you do.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: If you do not like me, take another.

sp.speaker: Bonit.
sp.p: If you be weary of my service, pray change; perchance you may get a better Mistris, and I hope I shall get as careful a servant.

div.head: Scene 10.
div.stage: Enter the Sociable Virgins, and the Matrons.

sp.speaker: 1 VIrgin.
sp.p: I would have all women bred to manage Civil Affairs, and men to manage the Military, both by Sea and Land; also women to follow all Manufactures at home, and the men all Affairs that are abroad; likewise all Arts of Labour, the men to be imploy'd in, and for all Arts of Curiosity, the women.

sp.speaker: 2 Virgin.
sp.p: Nay certainly, if women were imploy'd in the Affairs of State, the World would live more happily.

sp.speaker: 3 Virgin.
sp.p: So they were imploy'd in those things or business that were proper for their strength and capacity.

sp.speaker: 1 Matron.
sp.p: Let me tell you, Ladies, women have no more capacity than what is as thin as a Cobweb-la â€¢ n, which every eye may see through, even those that are weak and half blind.

sp.speaker: 4 Virgin.
sp.p: Why we are not Fools, we are capable of Knowledge, we only want Experience and Education, to make us as wise as men.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p: But women are uncapable of publick Imployments.

sp.speaker: 1 Virgin.
sp.p: Some, we will grant are, so are some men: for some are neither made by Heaven, Nature, nor Education, sit to be States-men.

sp.speaker: 2 Virgin.
sp.p: And Education is the chief: for Lawyers and Divines can never be good States-men, they are too learned to be wise; they may be good Orators, but never subtil Counsellors; they are better Disputers than Conuivers; they are fitter for Faction than Reformation; the one make quarrels, or upholds quarrels, the other raises doubts: But good States-men are bred in Courts, Camps, and Cities, and not in Schools and Closets, at Bars and in Pulpits; and women are bred in Courts and Cities, they only want the Camp to give them the perfect State-breeding.

sp.speaker: 3 Virgin.
sp.p: Certainly, if we had that breeding, and did govern, we should govern the world better than it is.

sp.speaker: 4 Virgin.
sp.p: Yes, for it cannot be govern'd worse than it is: for the whole World is together by the Ears, all up in Wars and Blood, which shews there is a general defect in the Rulers and Governors thereof.

sp.speaker: 1 Virgin.
sp.p: Indeed the State-Counsellers in this Age have more Formality than Policy, and Princes more plausible words, than rewardable deeds; insomuch as they are like Fidlers, that play Artificially and Skilfully, yet it is but a sound which they make and give, and not real presences.

sp.speaker: 2 Virg.
sp.p: You say true; and as there is no Prince that hath had the like good fortune as Alexander and Caesar, so none have had the like Generosities as they had, which shews, as if Fortune (when she dealt in good earnest, and not in mockery) measur'd her gifts by the largeness of the Heart, and the liberality of the hand of those she gave to: And as for the death of those two Worthies, she had no hand in them, nor was she any way guilty thereof: for the Gods distribute life and death without the help of Fortune.

sp.speaker: Matron.
sp.p:
