sp.p: Pray Sir let me intreat you to be one of our Guests.

sp.speaker: Disguise.
sp.p: You shall command me, Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Tho. Cuckold.
sp.p: Nay, since the Gentleman hath brought such Newes as hath banished the Bridegroom from the Company, he shall now supply his place.

sp.speaker: Sir Hum. Disagree.
sp.p: Soft Sir, he may at the Board, but not in his Bed.

sp.speaker: Sir Hen. Courtly.
sp.p: He looks so modestly, as if he would play the part of a Bride rather than a Bridegroom.

sp.speaker: Disguise.
sp.p: Lady, will you accept of my modest service?

sp.speaker: Lady Inconst.
sp.p: Sir, I must not refuse Modesty.

div.head: Scene 18.
div.stage: Enter two Maid-servants of Sir John Dotards.

sp.speaker: 1 MAid.
sp.p: 'Tis no wonder that Briget Greasie is so proud now, being maried to my Master, he having made her a Lady. Lord, Lord, to see the fortune that some have over others: why, if my Master would have maried one of his Maids, he might have chosen a prettier wench amongst any of us all than she is.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: Yes 'faith: for she was thought the veriest Puss of us all; for she is neither snout-fair, nor well-shap'd, she hath splay-feet, and chilblainheels.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: Nay all will grant she was the dirtiest slut in the House: for there was never a man-servant but would cry so at her when they kiss'd her; besides, she was the veriest fool amongst us: But Lord, what Wealth and Honour will do! for now she is a Lady, she looks as if she never wash'd a dish, or scour'd a kettle or spit.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: But I wonder how she came to be his Wife, she might have served as her Betters have done before her: I am sure there was Nan, a pretty pert, cleanly Maid, who was kind, and willing to do any thing, either to serve our Master, or fellow servants.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: O but Nan had not an old woman that us'd to come to her to get suet and scraps, as Briget had; and this old woman, they say, counsell'd Briget to seem nice and coy.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: I wonder what Richard the Carter will say, who was turned out of his service, because he should not share with my Master.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: 'Faith I heard that Richard was told of her Advancement, and 'tis said he laugh'd, and said my Master had a hungry stomach, that he could feed of his leavings; but by his Troth he was glad she was become a Lady: for now he could say he had kiss'd and courted a Lady as well as the best Gallant of them all.

div.head: Scene 19.
div.stage: Enter the Lord Widower, and the Lapy Sprightly his Daughter.

sp.speaker: LOrd.
sp.p: Daughter, ald ough you do govern my Family very well for your years, yet you are young, and wanting Experience, may be cozened; and though I have a great Estate, yet it will be all consum'd, if Order and Method be not put into practice: wherefore I would have you take the counsel of Mistris Dorothy Subtilty, to assist you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Who is that, my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Why, do not you know her? she that waited on your Mother.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Pardon me, my Lord, I did not know her by that Title: for she was plain Dol Subtilty when she waited on my Mother, and not knowing of her advancement
from a Chambermaid to a Gentlewoman, I might easily mistake; besides, she is not so much older, as to have much more experience than my self: perchance she may have more craft, which was learned her in her poverty, than I, who have been bred at the Horn of Plenty, that knew no scarcity, nor sharking necessity.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: You have a sharp tongue when spight moves it; but let me hear no more of these words, but do as I command you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I never disobey'd you as I do know.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: Well, no more words.

div.head: Scene 20.
div.stage: Enter the Bride, and all the Bridal Guests; they dance, and Monsieur Disguise dances with the Bride. Sir Spendall seems to whisper Monsieur Disguise in the Ear, being half drunk.

sp.speaker: SPendall.
sp.p: Sir, but that you look more like a woman than a man, you might give the Bridegroom more cause to be melancholy for the living than the dead; but let me intreat you, young Gentleman, that you strike not his Head, as your News hath done his Heart: for I perceive the Brides eyes are fix'd upon you, and from the root of a six'd eye grows Horns, when they are set in a maried Head.

sp.speaker: Disguise.
sp.p: There is no fear.

sp.speaker: Spendall.
sp.p: Yes Sir, as long as there are doubts, there are fears.

sp.speaker: Disguise.
sp.p: There is no doubt Sir.

sp.speaker: Spendall.
sp.p: But that she will be Sir.

sp.speaker: Disguise.
sp.p: What, Sir?

sp.speaker: Spendall.
sp.p: What you please Sir; and let me tell you, young Gentleman, that as long as there are women, there will be Lovers and Cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Disguise.
sp.p: And let me tell you, Sir, that as long as there are men, there will be Fools and Drunkards.

sp.speaker: Lady Inconstant.
sp.p: Sir, I doubt we have invited you rather to your trouble, than your delight.

sp.speaker: Disguise.
sp.p: Madam, you are the Treasure of Pleasure and Delight; which none can receive but from your Bounty, nor enjoy but by your Favour.

div.head: Scene 21.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Sprightly, and Dol Subtilty.

sp.speaker: LAdy Sprightly.
sp.p: What had you to do to contradict my commands?

sp.speaker: Dol Subtilty.
sp.p: They were not sit to be obey'd, wherefore they were forbid.

div.stage: The Lady gives Dol a lox on the Ear.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: There, take that, to remember I forbid you to forbid my commands.

sp.speaker: Dol.
sp.p: I will declare your blows to some that shall revenge me.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: What, are you so light-finger'd? 'Tis time to get you a Husband, to govern and rule your high spirit.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, pray Sir get me no Husband: for if my Father takes part against me, surely a Husband will be worse natur'd.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: So, you will say I am unnatural.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No Sir, I only say it is not my undutifulness that displeases you, but some that hath more wit than I, or at least good fortune to please you better.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: VVell, pray study your Book and VVork, and leave the Houshold. Affairs to my disposal.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Sir, I took the Office, as my duty to your commands, not for Delight, Pleasure, Ease, or Profit, and I shall surrender it up again upon the same account, and with all the trouble, care, labour, vexations and disquiets belonging thereunto.

sp.speaker: Lord.
sp.p: In doing so, you will do very well.

div.head: Scene 32.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Hypocondria as being frightly sick, and her Husband Sir VVilliam Lovewell.

sp.speaker: LOvewell.
sp.p: Heaven bless you wife, what makes you so extremely pale, and to seem so affrighted?

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: O Husband I have an Imposthume broken within me, and the bag will rise and choke me.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: Heaven forbid.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: O I am choak'd, I am choak'd, I cannot fetch my breath.

div.stage: She takes her breath very short. Sir VVilliam Lovewell in a great fright calls for help. Enter some servants.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: O send for Doctors strait: for my wife is ready to die.

div.stage: They go out running, he standing by the Chair his Wife sits in, trembling and quaking.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: How are you, dear VVife? how do you feel your self now? how are you?

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p:
O very ill; but yet me thinks I can fetch my breath a little
better than I could, I believe the Imposthume-bag is fallen down: wherefore I will go to bed.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: Pray do VVife.

div.stage: He leads her out, and she goeth softly.

div.head: Scene 23.
div.stage: Enter Sir Henry Sage, and the Lady Chastity his Wife.

sp.speaker: SAge.
sp.p: Sweet-heart, I was in your Bed-chamber, and in your Cabinet-chamber, and missing you in both, I was afraid I must have been forc'd to have hir'd a Cryer, to have proclamed my loss.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: Many a Wife doth proclame her Husbands loss without the help of a Cryer: for the Wives Adulterous Acts proclame her Husband a Cucold, and the loss of his Honour.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: But I am not afra'd of that: for I am confident of thy Chastity (although the old saying is, Confidence makes Cuckolds.)

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: Your confidence of me shall never harm you.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: But your too serious studies will harm your health; and if you be sick, I cannot be well; besides, it will decay your Beauty, waste your Youth, like Oyl spent in a melancholy Lamp, where Life is always blinking.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: It were better that my Body should be sick, than my Mind idle; my Beauty decay, than my Understanding perish; my Youth waste, than my Fame lost; my Life blinking, than my Honour sinking: for an idle Mind, not well imploy'd creates a restless body, which runs from place to place, and hates to be at home. Thus Mind and Body both being out, extravagant Words and Actions run about, and Riot keeps possession.
sp.l: And though the Beauty withers and decays,
Yet Wit and Wisedome with the ruine stays:
And if the Youth doth waste, and Life's Oyl's spent,
Yet Fame lasts long, and builds a Monument:
A melancholy life doth shadows cast,
But sets forth Virtue, if they are well plac'd.
Then who would entertain an idle Mirth,
Begot by Vanity, and dies in scorn?
Or proud, or pleas'd with Beauty, when the Birth
Becomes the Grave or Tomb as soon as born?
But Wisedome wishes to be old and glad,
When youthful Follies die, which seem as mad:
If Age is subject to repent what's past,
Prudence and Experience redeems what's lost.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: I perceive, Wife, the Muses have kept you company, although you walk by your self; but now I desire you will leave their company for a time, and entertain mine.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: VVith all my heart; but the Muses are never with me, but when you are imploy'd about serious Affairs: for though they are my Visitors, yet they are your Domestick Servants.

div.head: Scene. 24.
div.stage: Enter Sir Humphrey Disagree, and his Wife the Lady Disagree.

sp.speaker: LAdy Disagree.
sp.p: Dear Husband, where have you been?

sp.speaker: Sir Hum. Disagree.
sp.p: My dear kind VVife, I have been in the Garden, where I have heard little Robin Red-breast sing.

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: That's a sign, Sweet-heart, we shall have warm weather, otherwise they would come into the House.

sp.speaker: Sir Hum. Disag.
sp.p: I had rather believe, my pretty Bird, we shall have cold weather: for they sing always in the coldest time of the year, as in the depth of Winter.

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: How ignorantly you speak, good Husband, as if the Robin Redbreast sings onely in the cold Winter, and not in the warm Summer as well?

sp.speaker: Sir Hum. Disagree.
sp.p: Why not, good VVife, as well as Nightingals, which only sing in the Spring, and Swallows in the heat of Summer?

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: That doth not prove that the Robbin doth not sing in Summer.

sp.speaker: Sir Hum. Disag.
sp.p: I never heard the Robbin sing in Summer.

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: Your never hearing of it, is not a sufficient proof.

sp.speaker: Sir Hum. Disag.
sp.p: It is to me.

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: To say it is, without a Reason, proves a Fool.

sp.speaker: Sir Hum. Disag.
sp.p: I only prov'd my self a Fool in marying you.

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: I was accurst when first I gave consent to be your Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Hum. Disag.
sp.p: You were easily won.

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: What, because I consented to a Knave that wooed?

sp.speaker: Sir Hum. Disag.
sp.p: You are a false woman, for calling me a Knave.

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: You are a Cuckold, for calling me false.

sp.speaker: Sir Hum. Disag.
sp.p: Am I so, Mistris? I will be sure to thrust my Horns thorough your Heart.

div.stage: He offers to strike her, she gets up a stool, and slings at him, he gets a cushion and slings at her, and then gets hold of her, she cries out Murder, in comes their friends and servants, and parts them.

sp.speaker: Sir Hum. Disag.
sp.p: Dam me, I'll kill her.

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: You'l be hang'd, will you?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Nay good Sir be not angry.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Good Madam go away, until my Masters anger is pass'd over.

div.head: Scene. 25.
div.stage: Enter Sir Francis Inconstant, alone, as being very melancholy.

sp.speaker: INconstant.
sp.p: I will read this Letter once again, although it shakes my Soul, and makes me almost mad.

p.hi: THe wrongs you have done me, are more than Heaven can give me patience to endure; for which wrongs, may thick black clouds of Infamy overspread your Memory; and may my Sorrows beat upon your Soul, as Northern Winds upon the Sea, and raise up all your thoughts in discontent, as raging billows, causing your voice to roar out loud with hideous noise, confounding all the Actions of your Life; and way your hopes be drown'd in the salt water of despairing Tears. The Heavens cannot condemn me for cursing a man which hath betray'd my Youth by Flattery, violated my Chastity by Proteslations, tormented my harmless thoughts with Perjury, disquieting my peaceable Life with Misfortunes. But the burthen of my wrongs being too weighty for life to bear, hath sunk it to the Grave, where I hope all my disgrace will â€¢ e buried with me, though not the revenges of my Wrongs; for those will punish you when I am dead: For the Gods are just, although Mankind is not.

div.stage: Enter Nic Adviser, Sir Francis Inconstants man.

sp.speaker: Inconstant.
sp.p: O Nick, what a Villain am I!

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: For what Sir?

sp.speaker: Inconstant.
sp.p: For Perjury and Murther: for I did not only break those Bonds I had sealed with holy Vows, but my Falshood hath kill'd a fair young Lady: for she hearing I had forsaken her, and was to be maried to another, she dy'd for grief.

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Alas Sir, we are all by Nature both frail and mortal: wherefore we must complain of Nature, of her Inconstancy and Cruelty, in making our Minds so changeable, and our Bodies so weak, the one being subject to Death, the other subject to Variety. But Sir, in my Opinion, you have no cause to grieve, but rather to rejoyce: for what you have erred by Nature, you have repaired by Fortunes favour: for if that Lady which is dead, had lived, you would have been incumber'd with many troubles.

sp.speaker: Inconstant.
sp.p: As how Nick?

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: Why you would have been as a young Bear baired by two young Whelps; the forsaken Lady railing and exclaming against you in all Company she came into, and your Wife tormenting you with sharp words and loud noise, insomuch as you would have neither ear, drank, or slept in quiet. Thus both abroad and at home you would have heard noth gbut your own reproaches.

sp.speaker: Inconstant.
sp.p: But shall not I be the same now she is dead, think you?

sp.speaker: Adviser.
sp.p: No faith Sir: for Death hath stopt the mouth of the one, and Kisses may chance to muzzle the mouth of the other; but if you be melancholy, your Lady will think you do repent, and will believe that you do prefer the memory of your dead Mistris, before the enjoyment of your living Wife; besides, women are so jealous, as they will not allow their Husbands to think (that makes them talk so much as they do) for they think Thoughts are Bauds to Adulterous Actions, and that Imaginations commit Fornication with the Ghosts and Spirits of the dead.

sp.speaker: Inconstant.
sp.p: Well Nick I will take thy counsel, and cast off melancholy, and be merry in Jovial Company.

div.head: Scene 26.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Jealousie as holding her Head, and Sir Edward Courtly her Husband.

sp.speaker: COurtly.
sp.p: What, are you sick, Wife?

sp.speaker: Iealousie.
sp.p: I have such a pain in my Head, as I am not able to look up, or to speak.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: You should take some Physick.

sp.speaker: Iealousie.
sp.p: I cannot take Physick.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: You must take Physick if you be not well; but pray have a care you do not catch cold, for that will do you hurt. But I must be gone about my several Affairs: wherefore God be with you wife.

div.stage: The Lady Jealousie calls her Maid.

sp.speaker: Iealousie.
sp.p: Nan.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Madam?

sp.speaker: Iealousie.
sp.p: Go make me a White-wine Caudle.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I shall Madam.

div.head: Scene 27.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Chastity, and the Lady Procurer.

sp.speaker: PRocurer.
sp.p: Madam, I am not come upon my own Score, but upon a new one: for I am intreated, or rather commanded by a young Gentleman to kiss your Ladiships hands, as from him who durst not come to do it himself without your leave.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: Truly he shall never have leave from me.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: He begs that your Ladiship would give him leave to be your admiring Servant.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: He may admire without my leave; and I wish I had Merits; worth admiring.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: By my Troth, Madam, he is a most sweet young Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: Hath Nature perfum'd him, or Art?

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Both, Madam.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: That's too much, and will be apt to give the Head-ach.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: O Madam, he is most desperately in Love with your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: Pray Heaven, Madam, he doth not hang himself before my door!

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: 'Faith Madam, it is to be fear'd he will do some violent Act upon himself, unless you pity him.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: Is he in distress?

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: As much as Love can make him.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: How should I help him, Madam?

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Nothing can help him but Love's Returns in kind Imbracements.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: Would you have me a maried Wife, imbrace an Amorous Lover?

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: O Madam, stolen pleasures are sweet, and Mariage is a Cloak to hide Love's meetings.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: And can it hide the sin from the Gods, and the falshood from my Husband, as well as from the World? But let me tell you, the World is quick-fighted as to Particulars, though blind as to the General, complaining against single crimes, yet never helps to mend them.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: 'Faith Madam, the Gods easily pardon natural faults, and Husbands dare not spy them, at least not to divulge them; and the World censures all the Virtuous as much as the Wicked, and the Chaste as much as the Wanton; besides, you are excusable, being maried to an antient man.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: Doth Age deserve no Love?

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: 'Faith little: for Love wears out with Time, and Age wears out of Love; and if you said you did love your Husband, no body would believe you: for who can think you that are young and fair, can love a man that's old?

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: By Heaven I never thought my Husband old: for he doth appear to me to be just at Maturity; adorhed with all the Graces.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Surely you do not think his silver Hair Apollo's Locks!

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: No; but I think them Pa as's his Head-peece.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Nor can you think his hollow Eyes, that's sunk into his Head, are Cupids golden Arrows?

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: No; but I think them Minerva's Loom, which hath inter-weav'd several Objects, making various and most curious works of Knowledge, and of Wit, where Judgment in the midst is plac'd, and Understanding borders it.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: And can you think his shoulder, bent by weak old Age, are Cupids. Bow?

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: No; but I can think it's like a Bank swell'd out by Generosity, to bear Necessities burdens on; or else a heap of Noble Deeds, fals'd by Heroick Actions, whereon Fame sits in Triumph, and blows his praise abroad, that all the World may hear it.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p:
I will never believe you can think the surrows in his face,
plough'd up by Time, as smooth as waters be when in a calm.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: No; but I can think them Tracks or Paths made by Experience, in which walks Prudence, Fortitude, Justice, and Temperance: And though you strive to make my Husband seem much older than he is, yet I believe that neither Time nor Age hath power over him: for to my sight his Skin is as smooth as Light, his Eyes as darting as Apollo's Beams, his Body is as straight as Serzes Wand, able to charm the youngest she, and turn her all to Love; his Strength is active, and his Spirits quick, to carry Arms, or sight his Enewies; and for his Brain, 'tis equally temper'd, not burnt with heat, nor frozen up with cold; nor are his Sinews out of tune by flacken'd Nerves, but just set to Lifes Harmony, Strength strings the Cords, and Health doth keep just Time.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, sweet Lady, your love hath made him a most Heavenly Creature.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: Foul Devil, that seeks for to corrupt the Mariage-bed with false Dispraise, and flattering Insinuations, carrying fond Loves recommendations from Ear to Ear! Youth being credulous, they are soon receiv'd, which you perceiving, strait strive to sow in tender hearts Loves Amorous Passions, from whence Adultery doth grow, and Vices do increase. You a Lady, a Bawd. O that Honour, the mark of Merit, should be plac'd on such base subjects as you are! Be gone, such Bawds as you are not only able to disorder a private Family, but to ruine a whole Kingdome; you are worse than Witches, and do more mischief.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: O that I had that power, to make her Husband so jealous, as he might hate her!

div.head: Scene 28.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Hypocondria, and Sir VVilliam Lovewell.

sp.speaker: HYpocondria.
sp.p: O Husband, I am a dead woman: for all my side is numb, nay in a dead Palsie, I cannot feel my Arm.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: Heaven forbid: let me rub your Arm.
But Wife, if it were dead, you could not move it, and you can move it, can you not?

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: Yes, but very weakly.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: Wrap it up with warm cloaths, until such time as the Doctor can be sent for. Come into your Chamber, and I will send for the Doctor strait.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: No, pray do not send for the Doctor now: for with your rubbing my Arm, you have brought the lively spirits into it again.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: I am glad of it; but pray keep your bed.

div.head: Scene 29.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Jealousies Waiting-Gentlewoman, and her Chamber-maid.

sp.speaker: GEntlewoman.
sp.p: My Lady doth not like her Caudle: wherefore she will have a Sack-posset made her.

sp.speaker: Chambermaid.
sp.p: Not like it? why she eat a great porrenger of it:

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman.
sp.p: That's all one, my Lady did not like it; and therefore you must make a Sack-posset,

sp.speaker: Chambermaid.
sp.p: What fault found she with it?

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman.
sp.p: She did not express her particular dislike, but in the general.

sp.speaker: Chambermaid.
sp.p: Well, I shall make her a Posset strait.

div.head: Scene 30.
div.stage: Enter two servant-maids of the Lady Disagrees.

sp.speaker: 1 MAid.
sp.p: Heaven be thanked, my Master and Lady are perfectly friends again: for she sits in his lap, and he kisses her very lovingly. Lord, what a disquietous house have we had!

div.stage: Sir Humphry and his Lady make a noise within, as being fallen out again.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: Hark, what noise is that?
sp.stage: They hearken, and hear the Shovel and Tongs slung about.
sp.p: Iuno bless us, I think they'l fling the house out at the windows.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: Run, run Iane, they are fallen out again, and will kill each other.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: O call the Chaplin to part them: for we shall never do it: Call him, call him.

div.stage: Exeunt Maids in a frighted haste.

div.head: Scene 31.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Hypocondria's Maid in a frighted haste: And enter Roger Trusty, Sir VVilliam Lovewel's Man.

sp.speaker: MAid.
sp.p: O Trusty, where is my Master? my Lady is so ill, as we think she'll die: for she faith that she is in an Apoplexy.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: If she were in an Apoplexy, she could not speak.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Hold thy prating, Fool: for hers is a speaking Apoplexy.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: You are a Slut for calling me Fool.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: You are a Knave for calling me Slut.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Am I so? there's for you for calling me Knave.

div.stage: He kicks her, she cries out; in comes more servants: Then follows the Lady Hypocondria running after them.

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: What in the name of Iuno is the matter? what Thieves are enter'd? or is my house on fire?

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: No Madam, only Roger and Ioan are beating one another.

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: May the Devil beat them for frighting me so.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: My dear VVife, what is the cause you sent for me in such haste?

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: O Husband, I was dying of an Apoplexie, my Spirits were stopt, and my Brain was smother'd in a cloud of gross vapours; but your Man and my Maid falling out, they fell a bearing each other, and she crying out for help, did so affright me, as I came running hither, thinking Thieves had broken in, or Fire had broken out of our house, which fright hath unstopt the Sluce-passages, and dispers'd the Vapour.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: I perceive a bad Cause may sometimes produce a good Effect, if their sighting hath cured you.

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: Yes; but I will turn away my Maid, for crying, and quarrelling, and making such a noise.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: That were unjust: for should the sick Patient, that had been sick to death, when he was restored to health, banish the Physician that restored him, without a Fee? No, he ought to have his Fee doubl'd or trebl'd, so you ought not onely to keep your Maid, but to double or treble her wages.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: It were more just to treble my wages than hers; for I was the cause of the Out-cry: for when I beat her, she roared, and her voice thorough her throat, made as great a rumbling noise, as a foul chimney set on fire, and in my Conscience as much sooty flegm fell from her head, as from a Cooks Chimney; and when she scolded, her words were so harsh, as they creeke just so as when a door is taken off the hinges, which made my Lady strait apprehend either Fire, or Thieves, or both.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: No, you deserve nothing, by reason a man ought not to strike a woman.

sp.speaker: Roger Trusty.
sp.p: Why Sir? she would sooner have been hang'd about my neck, than have cried, if I had kiss'd her instead of kicking her.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: Hold your prating, and learn to be civiller to women.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Roger and Joan.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: If I had kiss'd you, Ioan, as I perceive my Master would have had me done, you had been silent, and in your silence my Lady would have died, and then my Master had been a lusty Widower, and a free Wooer, and a fresh man, as one may say, where now he is bound to a sickly Wife; and this is the reason my Master would not increase my wages: which if I had kiss'd you, I had been inriched by my Masters favour: wherefore Ioan, I will kiss thee, but kick thee no more.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: Go hang your self, it is too late now, you should have kiss'd me before.

div.head: Scene. 32.
div.stage: Enter the Waiting-woman and Chambermaid of the Lady Jealousie.

sp.speaker: GEntlewoman.
sp.p: You are a strange wench, to make the Posset-curd so tough, that now my Lady hath eat it, it lies so hard, so hard in her stomach, as it cannot digest.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Tough, say you? I am sure to my taste it was as tender as Cream.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman.
sp.p: Well, in my Ladies stomach it proves as hard as stone: wherefore you must go and burn some Claret-wine for her, with Cloves, Mace, and Nutmegs, and make it very sweet with sine loaf-sugar, presently, presently.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: But if my Lady hath one meat after another so quick, she will not be able to hold all in her stomach, by reason her stomach must of necessity overflow.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman.
sp.p: If the wine make her stomach to overflow, it will be like washing the mouth, and rubbing the teeth after meat, the which will scour her stomach clean.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Nay, if the stomach be not scour'd and cleans'd somtimes, it would be very foul, by reason it is so often us'd.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman.
sp.p: And if it be scour'd too often, it will wear it out, as the Learned say: But Nan, go your ways and burn the wine, otherwise my Lady will chide.

div.head: Scene 33.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Amorous, and the Lady Procurer, as Visitants to the Lady VVanton.

sp.speaker: LAdy Procurer.
sp.p: Well Monsieur Amorous, now I have brought you to this Lady, I will leave you to make your Complements, the whilst I will go, Madam, to your woman, to Mistris Watcher, and chide her for not sending me that you promis'd me.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: She is much asham'd for her forgetfulness, and had rather die than see you.

div.stage: Monsieur Amorous seems to stagger, as being weak and faint, almost ready to fall into a Swoun; then takes his handkerchief, and wipes his face, as if he did sweat.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: Are not you well Sir?

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: A sudden passion hath surrounded my Heart, and hath surprized my Senses, sending out cold damp sweats over all my body.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: Sir, will you drink any cordial water?

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: Lady, it was your Beauty that struck me with a trembling fear, and made my spirits faint; but this delicious kiss that I have taken from your hand, restores me more, and gives me greater strength than all the Spirits Chymists can extract.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: I perceive now it was a dissembling fit, and not a real sickness.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: Misconstrue not my Admirations and Affections, which do adore and worship you.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: If we women should believe the words of men, they would make us more conceited of our selves than yet we are.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: There are not thoughts to equal your great Beauty, nor words for to express it.

div.stage: Enter the Lady Procurer in great haste.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Madam, Madam, your Husband is comming, your Husband is comming.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: For Venus sake stay by me, Madam, that my Husband may see I have a woman in my company.

div.stage: Enter Sir Thomas Cuckold, Sir Thomas and Monsieur Amorous congee to one another.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: Sir, my ambition grew impatient to be acquainted, and to render my self, and offer my service to you Sir.

sp.speaker: Cuckold.
sp.p: Sir, I am your most humble Servant, and shall strive by all the ways I can to appear worthy your favours.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: Lord, Lady Procurer, how are you drest to day in a most careless fashion?

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: It is the mode, it is the mode to go undrest,

sp.speaker: Cuckold.
sp.p: Wife, this is not a fit room to entertain this noble Gentleman, Sir, will you be pleas'd to walk into another room?

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: All rooms are fine Sir, where you and your Virtuous Lady are.

div.stage: Exeunt Sir Thomas Cuckold and Monsieur Amorous.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: 'Faith if I had not come running in before your Husband, he had catch'd you.

div.stage: Lady Wanton claps the Lady Procurer on the cloaths.

sp.speaker: VVanton.
sp.p: 'Faith Procurer, thou art such another Lady-wag, as all the Town cannot match thee.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: I was, I was, but now I am grown old, I am grown old; but I was born to do good Offices.

div.head: Scene 34.
div.stage: Enter two Maids of the Lady Poverty's.

sp.speaker: 1 MAid.
sp.p: I wonder my Lady is able to stay in the room with my Master: his vomiting hath so fumed the room, as there is such a stink, that by my troth I am almost strangled with the smell of the corrupted drink.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: Alas poor Lady! she is forc'd to stay for fear he should be outragious in his drunken humour: for if she stirs or speaks, he swears as if he would draw the Devils out of Hell.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: Hell is not so bad, as to be where he is now he is drunk.

sp.speaker: 3 Maid.
sp.p: My Master is asleep, and my Lady would have you make lesse noise, and not to talk so loud, for fear you should awake him.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: If he be asleep, we may make what noise we will or can make, he will not wake until such time as the fume or vapour of wine be out of his head, no sound can enter: But I wonder my Lady will take such care of him, when he hath no respect to her, but transforms himself from man to beast every day; indeed she sees him only a beast, not a man: for before he is wholy sober, he rises to go to a Tavern to be drunk again.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: If my Master transforms himself into a beast ere that he comes to my Lady, he imitates Iove: for he transform'd himself into a Bull for the sake of sair Europa.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: But not into a drunken roaring Bull as my Master is.

sp.speaker: 3 Maid.
sp.p: 'Faith if I were my Lady, I would hold by his Horns, and then let him roar, and drink â€¢ and whore as much as he will.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: Yes, so she might chance to be drench'd in a Bathing-tub, as Europa in the Sea.

div.head: Scene 35.
div.stage: Enter Nan the Lady Jealousies Chamber-maid, and her Master Sir Henry Courtly meets her, and kisses her. Enter the Lady Jealousie, and sees him.

sp.speaker: LAdy Iealousie.
sp.p: So Husband, I perceive Nan is in your favour.

div.stage: Nan runs out of the room.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: 'Faith Wife Nan is a careful and industrious Wench! for she strives to serve us both, for she makes you candles and feeds me with kisses.

sp.speaker: Lady Iealousie.
sp.p: Or rather Husband you feed Nan, and Nan feeds me.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Faith the truth is I â€¢ eed you both.

sp.speaker: Lady Iealousie.
sp.p: But Nan hath the greatest share, that makes her so proud, and I so sickly; But since you are so liberal to her, and so sparing to me, I will board elsewhere, and so as I may carve where I like best.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Sure Wife you will not.

sp.speaker: Lady Iealousie.
sp.p: Surely Husband I will do my endeavour.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: What to be a Whore?

sp.speaker: Lady Iealousie.
sp.p: Yes, if being a whore will make you a Cuckold.

div.head: Scene. 36.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Hypocondria and her Maid.

sp.speaker: LAdy Hypocondria.
sp.p: My Husband hath been a long time abroad, pray Iove he be safe, if he should chance to have a quarrel and fight, a hundred to one but he is killd: for otherwise he would have come home; do you think he is well Ioan?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: You need not fear, for my master is of so civil a behaviour, and of so sweet a disposition, as he can have no enemies.

sp.speaker: Lady Hypocon.
sp.p: O But he is a man that is very valiant, and one that is very sensible of disgrace, and affronts.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Truly I believe you have no reason to fear.

sp.speaker: Lady Hypocon.
sp.p: Do you but believe so, nay then you doubt, and therefore I know he is kill'd and I will go and find out the murtherer, and kill him my self.

div.stage: The Lady Hypocondria offers to run out of the room, as in a frighted passion, the maid stops her.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: My Noble Lady, do not run in this passion: for all the idle men, and women, and boyes, and girles will run after you, as thinking you mad; for they make no difference betwixt melancholy, and madnesse.

sp.speaker: Lady Hypocon.
sp.p: I am not able to overcome this fear, I shall die.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Pray stay and send out one of our men to inquire where he is.

sp.speaker: Lady Hypocon.
sp.p: Call Roger Trusty.

sp.speaker: Lady Hypocon.
sp.p: O You defendant Gods assist my Husband.

sp.speaker: Lady Hypocon.
sp.p: Trusty go presently, and seek out your master, and bring me word where he is, and how he doth, and be sure if you see a grim look't fellow near him, that you stir not from your Master, but wait upon him home, for fear some trechery should beset him.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Who shall bring you word of his health, or sicknesse, life, or death?

sp.speaker: Lady Hypocon.
sp.p: Death do you say, O you have heard he is kill'd.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: By Pluto I have heard no such thing.

sp.speaker: Lady Hypocon.
sp.p: Why do you talk of death then?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Because you send me to know whether he be dead, or alive.

sp.speaker: Lady Hypocon.
sp.p: That is true, wherefore let one of the Foot-boyes go along with you to bring me an answer; but be sure you stay with your Master.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: I shall.

sp.speaker: Lady Hypocon.
sp.p: Make all the haste you can to find him.

div.head: Scene 37.
div.stage: Enter Sir Henry Sage, and the Lady Chastity.

sp.speaker: SIr Hen. Sage.
sp.p: Is the Lady Procurer a Baud say you?

sp.speaker: Lady Chastity.
sp.p: A perfect one I think: for she pleaded as earnestly, as Lawyers for a fee.

sp.speaker: Sir Hen. Sage.
sp.p: No doubt, but she hath as much reason: for sure she doth it for gain, not out of love to wicked basenesse; but I believe poverty perswades her, or rather inforces her.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: No surely, it is an inborn, or at least an inbred baseness: for neither death, nor torments can inforce, nor riches, nor preferrments allure a noble mind to such base acts; but some are so unworthy, or rather wicked, as to delight to intice, and to pervert all they can get acquaintance with.

sp.speaker: Sir Hen. Sage.
sp.p: And some doe it to hide their own faults, thinking to bury them under the vices of others, or smother them in the presse of a multitude: but let me advise you not to entertain her company any more.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: I believe she will not visit me again.

div.head: Scene 38.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Sprightly, and one of her wom â€¢ n.

sp.speaker: LAdy Sprightly.
sp.p:
Lord, Lord, this nasty love, or rather this heastly lust that doth corrupt all good manners, as gentle civility, free society, lawfull recreations, honest friendship, natural affections; it cuts off the feet of obedience, it breaks the knees of duty, it wounds the breast of fidelity, it pulls out the heart of loyalty; it turns away prudence, it banishes temperance, and murthers justice; it breaks peace and makes warrs, and t â€¢ rns arms i â€¢â€¢ o petticoats. O sweet pure Chastity, how amiable thou art, how beautifull thou appearst in women, how heroick in men: for Chast women have such innocent thoughts, such pure, clean, clear, white immaculate minds, such modest countenances, such gentle behaviour, such civil discourses, such noble actions, such discreet entertainments, such cautionarie recreations; otherwise they are bold, impudent, rude, flanting, ranting, romping women: also Chastity in men makes them heroick, for propriety, justice constancy, and natural and honest love is the basis, pillars, or foundation whereon true valour is built, when amorous affections make men effeminate, causing them to cast away their hard iron arms to lie in the soft arms of beauty, and stops their cares from loud alarums, with charming notes of Musick, it takes them from being masters of themselves, and others, and makes them become servants, and slaves; from commanding an Army to be commanded by single women, by whom he is checkt like a school-boy, lead like a dog in a string, as after his mistrisses humours, her frowns make him crouch like a cur, her smiles make him skip, and make face like a Jack a â€¢
apes, and their beastly appetites make them so rude, and wilde, as they regard no civility of behaviour, no gentleness of disposition, no constancy of affection, they keep no friendship, constancy, or vowes, they break all decent customs, and disobey all honest laws; but this is a theam too wilde to be preacht on.

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman.
sp.p: Why Madam, my Lord your father may be a very chast man although he lieth with his maid, if he hath made her his wife before he made her his bedfellow.

sp.speaker: Lady Sprightly.
sp.p: His wife? he scorns the thought, and hates the act?

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman.
sp.p: Pardon me Madam, if I offer to lay a wager of it.

sp.speaker: Lady Sprightly.
sp.p: Are you so confident that you dare lay a wager?

sp.speaker: Gentlewoman.
sp.p: If you inquire more I believe you will find it to be true.

div.head: Scene 39.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Chastity, and her woman gives her a letter.

sp.speaker: LAdy Chastity.
sp.p: Who brought this letter?

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: A kind of a Gentleman servingman.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: Pray receive no more letters from that man.

sp.speaker: Woman.
sp.p: He said he would come in the evening to receive an answer.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: If he comes, tell him it needs no answer.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: Husband, will you read a Love letter?

sp.speaker: Sir Hen. Sage.
sp.p: From whence comes it, and to whom is it sent?

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: You will soon find from whence it comes, and to whom it is sent.

sp.speaker: Sir Hen. Sage.
sp.p: So wife, I perceive I am in danger to be made a Cuckold.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: Doth the letter beget your faith to that opinion?

sp.speaker: Sir Hen. Sage.
sp.p: But the praises, and professions this letter brings you, raises â€¢â€¢ uples, and those scruples beget controversies, and those controversies may in time make a convert.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: Rather a pervert Husband; but be you constant, and I will warrant you safe.

sp.speaker: Sir Hen. Sage.
sp.p: But Youth and Beauty wife, when they plead, are greater Bawds, and have a more perswasive power than the Lady Procurer.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p:
Truly all three, as Beauty, Youth, or the Lady Procurer, rather than perswade me, would divert me, had I a wanton nature; as first, for the Lady Procurer her baseness appeared such as made me hate my self for being of the same sex she was of, and grieved me to see the follies of mankind, the one appearing like a Devil, the other like a beast, so seem'd the Lover and the Bawd, when men have Reason to govern, as much as Appetite to perswade, the one proceeding from the Soul, the other from the body; besides, Virtue is the Natural Complexion of the Soul, not Vice: for Vice is bred, not born in man: As for Youth, it is so fantastical, extravagant, wilde, and self-opinionated, doing such ridiculous Actions, putting themselves into such affected Postures, as I might be as soon enamour'd with a Jack-anapes: Besides, the discourses of Youth are so flashy, as it gives the hearers no relish; and their Judgment is so shallow, and their Understanding so mysty, as when Reason discourses with them, it is apt to be lost in the darkness of Ignorance. Lastly, for Beauty in men, it is worse than unhansomeness in women: for an ill-favour'd woman seems masculine, as if she had an Heroick Spirit,
though she were a Coward; to have a judicious Understanding, though she should be a Fool; to be Chaste, although she were Wanton; when on the contrary, a beautiful man appears Effeminate, Foolish, and Cowardly, when (perchance) he may be Wise and Valiant, yet 'tis Beauty makes him seem otherwise; and (for the most part) a beautiful man is more nice and curious about his person, as in his cloathing, dressing, trimming, perfuming, powdering, curling, and some will pomate and paine themselves, all which seems to me preposterous to men, insomuch as I could as soon be amorously affected with my own Sex, as those that are accounted beautiful men; and you might sooner be jealous of Age than Youth, with a Sun-burnt face and a wither'd skin, than a face that looks as if it had not seen the Sun, or the Sun it, nor felt the nipping Frost nor parching Wind; but I hope you have a better opinion of your self than to be jealous, as to think I can like any man better, or so well as you: And if you have not so good an opinion of me, us to believe I am constantly honest, yet I have such an assurance of my self, as to know I am not liable to be corrupted, and I am so Chaste, as I have not a thought subject to fully the purity of my chaste Mind and honest Heart.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: I believe you.

div.head: Scene 40.
div.stage: Enter Roger Trusty, as to his Master Sir VVilliam Lovewell.

sp.speaker: LOvewell.
sp.p: What is the matter, Roger, that you are come?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: And't please your Worship, my Lady hath sent me to know how your VVorship is in health.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: VVhy very well. How does she?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: She's well, but that she's afraid your VVorship's kill'd.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: If I were kill'd, I were past sickness or health. But who should kill me?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Nay that her Ladyship could not guess.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: Return home to your Lady, and tell her I shall be with her within an hour.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: I dare not leave your VVorship: for she hath sent me to guard and protect you from all harm, and to fight in your quarrel, and hath sent one of the Foot-boys to bring her word how your VVorship doth.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: Go you and return back, and tell your Lady from me, that Honesty, Civility, and Courage, is a sufficient Guard and Protection; if not, then my Sword, and my Skill to use it, will fight, and maintain my quarrel.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: If I should go home with that Message, you would find her dead at your return.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: VVhy so?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: VVhy, Sir, the very name of a Sword will kill her: I wonder your VVorship should forget it, and knows her humour so well.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: Yes, I know she hath a sweet Humour, and a tender Nature: wherefore return home without any more prating, and tell her that I am safe, and in very good health. Run all the way.

div.head: Scene 41.
div.stage: Enter Sir Edward Courtly, and his Wife the Lady Jealousie.

sp.speaker: COurtly.
sp.p: VVife, you may win me from the imbracing of other women, if you have Discretion and Chastity answerable to your Wit and Beauty.

sp.speaker: Iealousie.
sp.p: But I perceive men love variety; and if so, had I the Beauty of Venus, and the Wit of Mercury, the Wisedom of Pallas, and the Chastity of Diana, you would be like Iupiter still, and make love to mortals, which are common Wenches: But do not think I will do as Iuno did, as to torment my self with vexing and fretting for that which I cannot mend or help; but I will please my self with variety as much as you, and in the clouds of night will hide my Self and Lovers.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: 'Faith Wife I shall dissolve your Clouds into showers of Tears, and strike your Lover with my Thunder-bolt, which is my Poniard: But Wife, let me advise you to be as you ought to be, a good Wife: for, as I will not incroach upon my Wifes Prerogative, so Wife, you shall not incroach upon mine, being your Husband.

sp.speaker: Iealousie.
sp.p: You will not give me leave to have the variety of Courting Servants; yet you will take the liberty of variety to Court several Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: It is part of my Prerogative.

sp.speaker: Iealousie.
sp.p: What, to have whores?

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Yes; and its part of the Wifes duty which she owes to her Husband, to be content.

sp.speaker: Iealousie.
sp.p: She is not bound to that duty.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: She is bound to obey all duties: for the fundamental Laws in Mariage, are for the Husband to rule, the Wife to obey; the Husband to cherish, the VVife to love; the Husband to be Valiant to defend and protect her, the VVife to be Chaste, to suffer and submit; and when I leave to Command, you may leave for to Obey; when I leave to Cherish, you may leave to Love; when I am a Coward, you may be a VVhore: for when I basely part with my Honour, you are not bound to keep it; but until I do part with my Honour, I charge you to keep it as you would do your life.

sp.speaker: Iealousie.
sp.p: By these Rules maried men are not bound to be constant.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Yes, to the Sex, but not to his VVife, in the case of Amorous Imbracements: for a Husband hath liberty for variety, but the VVife is refrain'd to one.

sp.speaker: Iealousie.
sp.p: These are Laws that neither the Gods nor Nature have prescribed, but only impartial men which make what Laws they please.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Nature taught men to make them for propriety-sake, and Gods command men to keep them, and that men should do their endeavour to force the Effeminate Sex to obey and practice them strictly, for the sake of Civil Common-wealths, wherein the Gods are best serv'd.

sp.speaker: Iealousie.
sp.p: But women are not such Fools, to be forc'd, such Asses, to bear such intollerable burdens of Troubles, Vexations, Crosses, and Neglects, from their Husbands and their VVhores.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: VVomen are best pleas'd when they are made Asses.

sp.speaker: Iealousie.
sp.p: Indeed Husbands make Asses of their VVives; but in faith you shall not make one of me.

div.head: Scene 42.
div.stage: Enter two Maids of the Lady Poverties:

sp.speaker: 1 MAid.
sp.p: My poor Lady sits so melancholy, and sighs and weeps, as it grieves my Soul to see her.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: Can you blame her, when she and her children must go a begging, or sit and starve: for my Master hath sold most of his Estate at several times, and hath spent the money in Drink and VVhores, and hath lost it at play: and now he hath sent for all his Plate to play away, her Jewels were pawn'd before.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: But when all is lost and spent, he will be forc'd to be a good Husband.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: VVhen all is gone, it will not be in his power: for none can be good Husbands as concerning Husbandry, when they have nothing to Husband.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: The best of it is, he will suffer as much as my Lady.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: No faith: for he will rook, and shark, and cheat, and baud, to get a poor living, when she, poor Lady, must work hard for her Living.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: Alas she cannot work.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: Then she must get some acquaintance, and turn Lady Bawd, and shew Ladies how to dress themselves, and sell paint, pomatoms, wax-gloves, oyl'd-masks, and the like Commodities privately; or else she must pretend Skill in Chirurgery or Physick, and to make Plaisters, Salves, Oyntments, and the like, or make Cordial Powders, or Cordial Waters, and other waters and powders; then perswade old Ladies to take thereof, telling them those will make them look as young as one of fifteen.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: But those things require cost to make them.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: No 'faith, there requires not much charge: for Paint, Pomatom, and the like Commodities, will sell at any price, and will be made at a little charge: and for Salves and Plaisters, and Oyls and Oyntments, Hogsgrease, Turpentine, and Bole-Armonike, serves for all sorts of those things, and Bread, and Meal, and Milk, and some chopt Herbs, and Sallet-oyl, serves for all Pultesses; and for Cordial Powders, some hot Seeds, as Anniseed, Caroway-seed, Coriander-seed, and the like Seeds, with some powder of Liquoras, and beaten Spices, with some sorts of Gums, as Mastick, Myrrh, and the like, will serve their turn.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: But Cordial Powders are made of Pearl, Amber, Corall, and the like.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p:
'Faith a little powder of posts serves as well: for they cannot be distinguish'd by their taste; but howsoever, it is but putting a grain of Musk and Ambergrease, and instead of Amber, Coral, and Pearl, 'tis but poudring some shav'd Harts-horn and Chiny, and they will serve as well, and (perchance work as good Effects:) Indeed Cordial Waters are chargeable to
make: for they require fire to distill them; but there is some remedy for that: for it is but buying several sorts of ordinary hot waters, and mix them together, so as no one of the waters may predominate in taste, and it will pass for rare extracted Spirits, so as she shall never need to venture to distill, or lay out money, but just for the present to fetch it from those that sell Aquavitae, Rosasolus, and the like, which may be had at a cheap rate, and she may sell them at a great price.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: But what shall become of the poor young Children?

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: VVhy, he rooking, and she bawding, may make a shift to feed them with bread: and those two Trades will never fail as long as Mankind lasts: for VVhoring and Knaving will last till Dooms-day, or for ever.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p:
But
â€¢ rsly, my Lady hath given us warning to be gone: wherefore we must seek out new services.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: My Lady is so good a Lady, as I wish I could serve her so as to maintain her, since she is not able to maintain a servant.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: But since we cannot maintain her, nor she us, we must leave her.

div.head: Scene 43.
div.stage: Enter Roger Trusty to his Lady all in a sweat with running: she seeing him come in such haste, cries out.

sp.speaker: HYpocondria.
sp.p: O help me, help me, you merciful Powers, to destroy me, and let me not outlive my Husband.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: 'Tis like the Gods will hear your prayers: for ten to one my Master out-lives you.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: VVhy, is he alive?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Yes, and alive's like.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: VVhat makes you sweat so?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: To bring you the good news of his well-being, and to prove the old Proverb a Lyar, which sayes, Bad Newes hath wings, and good Newes no legs.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: Where did you meet your Master?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: In Westminster-Hall.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: How did he look?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Healthful and well.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: Did he seem angry or pleas'd, merry or sad?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Why he neither seem'd angry nor pleas'd, merry nor sad, which I wonder'd at: for in Lawyers Courts, and places of Judicature, I never saw any face but was cloathed with a merry green countenance, or a sad black countenance, or a red cholerick face, or a pale malicious face; but my Masters face appeared like naked Truth, and clean Temperance, wash'd white with Innocency; being plump with health, and smooth with plenty.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: But why did you leave him?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p:
VVhy he commanded me so to doe, and to run every step, to tell you he was comming home, and I chose as the wisest to run, although
I sweat for it, than stay and have a broken Head.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: VVell, I give you here a twenty-shilling-piece to dry your sweat with a cup of Sack.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: May all my labours be rewarded thus.

sp.speaker: Maid Ioan.
sp.p: I perceive you take the gift as a due reward, and not as my Ladies bounty.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Hold your prating: what need we thank the Gods, if Saints merit Heaven?

div.head: Scene 44.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Sprightly, and the Lord VVidower her Father.

sp.speaker: LAdy Sprightly.
sp.p: Sir, I desire you would not think me undutiful to ask you a question: for I hope I am not so much in your disfavour, as not to resolve me, since it is in your power.

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: VVell, what is't that you would know?

sp.speaker: Sprightly.
sp.p: VVhether you are maried, or not?

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: VVhat if I am? Mariage is lawful.

sp.speaker: Sprightly.
sp.p: Yes Sir, but I doubt whether it be honourable or not: for 'tis said you are maried to my Chamber-maid Dol Subtilty.

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: Perchance I am.

sp.speaker: Sprightly.
sp.p: Then I desire your Lordship will let me marry too.

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: VVith all my heart, and I shall do my part towards thy mariage; but to whom would you be maried?

sp.speaker: Sprightly.
sp.p: Your Butler Sir.

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: Out upon thee base Girl, would you marry a Tapster?

sp.speaker: Sprightly.
sp.p: Why Sir, a Tapster is as good as a piss-pot emptier; besides, they say you have done the fellow wrong: for she (they say) was his by promise, and if Conscience hath right, he ought to have her; and perhaps, did not Ambition come in the way, Affection might prevail: wherefore to gratifie him, you ought in justice to bestow me upon him.

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: Well, because you shall not marry my Butler, I will not marry your Maid: for the truth is, I never had so low a thought. But let me tell you, it is in the way of disobedience to question a Fathers Actions, and a presumption for a Child to think their Father is not wise enough to govern himself; besides, Children were ingrateful to Parents, to desire that from them, which they cannot, or will not keep to themselves, as neither to suffer a Father to marry, or keep a Mistress: Do Children think a Father is bound to so many Children, and no more?

sp.speaker: Sprightly.
sp.p: Sir, I dare answer for the part of Children, that they would be well content that their Father should have Mistrisses, but they would be unwilling and griev'd that their Fathers should be their Mistrisses slave, whereby they incaptivate their Children, or ruine their Estates.

sp.speaker: Widower.
sp.p: Well then inquire no more after any Mistris I shall have, until you are incaptivated.

list.head: The Actors Names.
list.item: Sir William Lovewell, and the Lady Hypocondria his wife.
Sir Henry Sage, and the Lady Chastity his wife.
Sir Edward Courtly, and the Lady Jealousie his Wife.
Sir Humphrey Disagree, and the Lady Disagree his Wife.
Sir Thomas Cuckold, and the Lady Wanton his wife.
Sir Timothy Spendall, and the Lady Poverty his wife.
Sir Francis Inconstant, and the Lady Inconstant his wife.
Mistris Single, sister to the Lady Jealousie.
Master Make-peace, Sir Humphrey Disagree's Friend.
Master Perswader, the Lady Disagree's Chaplin.
Nan Lightheel, and Many other Maid-Servants of the several Ladies.
Roger Trusty, man to Sir VVilliam Lovewel, and other men-ser-servants of his, and the rest of the Knights.
Raillery Jester, the Lady Jealousies Fool.

div.head: THE Second Part of the PLAY Called the MATRIMONIAL TROUBLE A COME-TRAGEDY.
ACT I.
Scene. 1.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Procurer, and Sir Henry Sage.

sp.speaker: LAdy Procurer.
sp.p: Sir Henry, by reason my Lady is gone abroad, I make bold to visit you.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: I perceive I am oblig'd to my Wifes absence for your Visit, Madam.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: 'Faith, to tell you the truth, we women had rather visit men when they are alone, than when they have company.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: Then men and women agree better with particular, than with the general.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: They do so, yet they love varietyes best.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: That's natural, for the Senses to delight in variety.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: It is so, and yet our Civil and Divine Laws have forbid the use of Varieties, which (me thinks) is very unconscionable and unnatural.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: But if some of the natural Appetites and Actions were not restrain'd by Laws, no Comman-wealth could subsist.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: How did the Lacedemonians subsist? they liv'd all in common; and had not all Greece been imbroyl'd with VVars, their Common-wealth might have lasted to this day.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: The Lacedemonians had stricter Lawes than the Common-wealth which we live in, and are of: for though they gave more liberty and freedom to some Actions than our Governments do, yet they were stricter in others; and breakers of their Lawes were more severely punish'd, even in the smallest breach, than the breakers of our Laws are almost in the greatest breach.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p:
I am sure the Maker of the Lacedemonian Laws was a wise man,
and a kind-hearted man, in Decreeing for the Increase of Mankino, yet by some of his Laws he seem'd but a Sloven: for he banish'd all curidsity and neatness, and I believe, many conveniences: Also he seem'd to be a man of a weak stomach,

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: He rather seem'd of a strong stomach, and a greedy appetite, by the course diet he brought men to live with; but (for my part) If I should judge of the Lacedemonians Laws, I should judge that they strove to bring men to be like beasts, rather than to make them like as Gods, which men should strive to be.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: By your favour Sir, there can be no Law that can keep men from being horned beasts.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: Whose fault is that, Madam? not mens which make the Laws, but womens that break the Laws.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: It is mens fault, for giving women such liberty: And let me tell you Sir, women are such subtil creatures, as they strive first to get an honourable esteem from their Friends and Husbands, and a belief of their Chastity; and when they have secured mens jealousies, they make their Husbands Cuckolds, which all their Neighbours perceive, although the Husband is blind and muffl'd with affection.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: Madam, your Sex deserve a better Character than you give of them: for by your description there are few chaste.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Every woman knows the humours of her own Sex better than men know the humours of one another: wherefore let me advise you, Sir Henry Sage, to watch my Lady your Wife: for many, to my knowledge, seek for to corrupt her.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: Madam, although she is one of your Sex, yet she is of an Angelical nature, and not corruptible.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Sir, I am your humble servant, and I wish your Angel may not fall from Virtue into Vice.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: I have no jealous doubt, Madam.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: I wonder at it: for wise men use to doubt.

div.head: Scene 2.
div.stage: Enter Sir Edward Courtly, and the Lady Jealousie.

sp.speaker: COurtly.
sp.p: Wife, I have given you warning twice, beware of the third time, that you receive no Masculine Visiters: for by Heaven, if you do, I will hang you up in my garters.

sp.speaker: Iealousie.
sp.p: Do if you dare, I will have those that shall cut your throat.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: You could not fright me with your Champions, were I a coward: for they are Carpet-Knights, and dare not fight.

sp.speaker: Iealousie.
sp.p: They dare more than you dare.

div.stage: Sir Edward Courtly takes off a garter, or some other string or ribband about his cloaths, and makes her believe he will strangle her.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: By Heaven I'll give an Example to all men that love their Honour, and hate to be Cuckolds.

div.stage: He takes the string, and offers to put it about her neck. She is afraid.

sp.speaker: Iealousie.
sp.p: O Husband, Husband, spare me, spare me.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Wife, you may make me a Fool, but not unman me; you may flatter me, but not frighten me; you may make me commit an indiscretion, but never to be Effeminate.

sp.speaker: Iealousie.
sp.p: O mercy, mercy, Husband, do but spare me this time, and I will be the best wife in the World.

sp.speaker: Courtly.
sp.p: Well, I will pardon you this time; and know, VVife, that though I am willing to part with my Breeches and Doublet to give them you, yet I will never part with my Sword and my Spurs, which is my Courage and my Management: And I will give you all liberty in Vanity, but not in Dishonesty; you shall keep the Purse, but not manage the Horse: Also let me tell you, that it is not enough to be honest, but you must give no suspicion to the contrary.

div.head: Scene 3.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Procurer, and the Lady VVanton.

sp.speaker: LAdy Procurer.
sp.p: Come, Come Madam, are you ready? for Monsieur Amorous hath provided a great and costly Banquet for you.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: I am ready, I did only stay for you to go along with me.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: But will not your Husband watch whither we go?

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: O no: for he believes I am going to the Lady Breeders Upsitting.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: That's well be is so credulous to believe so easily whatsoever you would have him believe, and if he be but as obstinate of belief of that you would not have him believe you are happy, for let me tell you, that all men hath not that spiritual gift of Faith, but have strange opinions, and full of doubts, and suspitions.

sp.speaker: VVanton.
sp.p: Nay, I thank Iove, I have as good a Husband, as any woman whatsoever hath.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Prethee Madam leave some thanks for your loving servant, which loves, and adores you more than he doth Heaven, and worships you as his only Goddess.

sp.speaker: VVanton.
sp.p: He shall not pray in vain, nor shall I be as an Idoll made of Stone, or Brass.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Come your wayes then.

sp.speaker: MOnsieur Disguise.
sp.p: O man! O man! inconstant man! false and perjurious man! flattering dissembling man! and the worst of Mankind is Sir Francis Inconstant! He hath not only forsaken me, but forgot me, drowning the memory of me in his superfluous Cups. O Pluto, from whence all wickedness proceeds, make his fair Bride as false to him, as he hath prov'd to me, and sill his mind with furious Jealousie.

div.head: Scene 5.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Hypocondria, as at her Husband Sir VVilliam Lovewells Closet-door; she knocks at the door.

sp.speaker: LOvewel.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: 'Tis I, Husband.

sp.speaker: Lovewel.
sp.p: I may bid you welcome, VVife: for you are a stranger here.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: Truly Husband, I should not have disturb'd you, but that I was afraid you were not well: for I came two or three times to the door, and heard no noise, which made me afraid you might be in a swoun, or dead.

sp.speaker: Lovewel.
sp.p: I thank you for your loving fear and care of me.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: You may think this is an over-fond humour in me; but I have heard of many that have been found dead in their Beds, and in their Closets, when as their Friends never mistrusted it, but thought they were asleep, or a â€¢ study, which if they had been found or known in time, they might have been recover'd.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: You say true Wife.

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: But now I know you are well, I will not disturb you any longer.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: I will bear your kindness company.

div.head: Scene 6.
div.stage: Enter Sir Henry Sage, and the Lady Chastity his Wife.

sp.speaker: SAge.
sp.p: VVife, thou art false.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: 'Tis strange to hear you say so, when but yesterday you made me such protestations of your Faith, believing I was Virtuous, Chaste, and full of Truth, which I did think Time had not power to alter your belief, and such Vows and Protestations of your Affections to me, as if the fire of Love within your heart did burn so clear, and flame so high, as nought could quench it out but Death's cold damps, yet not so much, but still a heat within the ashes would remain.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: I confess, VVife, my doubts of Love did make me to try, at least to say so to you.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: True Love never makes doubts; and though you can dissemble with me, I cannot dissemble with you, could the Gods command me, as they cannot, things unjust.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: I perceive you are angry, VVife.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: No truly Husband, I am rather griev'd than angry, to think my honest truth mistrusted: for Doubts are unjust to great Affections, true Love, and good Intentions; and Examinations are scandalous to a strict chaste life, and makes it seem as criminal: but could the VVorld lay falshood to your charge, and should condemn you, yet my Affections would set you free, and rather tax my self for want of Merit to deserve your Love, than you want love to give Desert.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: Prethee VVife be not griev'd nor angry, for 'tis natural for Love to be suspicious: wherefore pray forgive my doubts.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: My nature is to forgive, and not to bear a grudge or spleen in minde.

sp.speaker: Sage.
sp.p: Then we are friends again.

sp.speaker: Chastity.
sp.p: My love is still the same, not to be alter'd.

div.head: Scene 7.
div.stage: Enter Mistris Single, the Lady Jealousies sister, and Raillery Jester the Fool.

sp.speaker: MIstris Single.
sp.p: Fool, How many degrees is there in Understanding?

sp.speaker: Iester.
sp.p: Three.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Distinguish them.

sp.speaker: Iester.
sp.p: There is a Coelestial Understanding, a Terrestrial Understanding, and an Understanding betwixt both, as an Airestial Understanding: Those that are Coelestial, are wise men; those that are Terrestrial, are fools; and those that are betwixt both, as Airestial, are half-witted men.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: I thought you would have said that those that were Terrestrial, were beasts.

sp.speaker: Iester.
sp.p: O no: for beasts are one degree above wise men, two degrees above half witted men, and three degrees above fools.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: But how will you make that good, that beasts are wiser than wise men?

sp.speaker: Iester.
sp.p: By all their actions: for beasts (for the most part) are more industrious, prudent, temperate, and peaceable, than the best of men; neither do they trouble their heads, nor break their sleeps, about the trifles of the World, but govern their Affairs easily, and live orderly, every several kind agreeing amongst themselves; besides, we are taught to imitate the Serpent and the Dove, and Examples are Principles, and the Original is to be preferr'd before the Copy, the Sample before the Pattern. Thus a Beast is preferr'd before a Wise man, by reason all Men must learn of Beasts to be wise, and of Birds to be virtuously honest, as to be harmless.

div.head: Scene 8.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Hypocondria, and her Maid Joan.

sp.speaker: MAid Ioan.
sp.p: Certainly Madam, you will starve your self with eating so little.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: Why a little serves Nature.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: Yes; but there are great differences betwixt Natures: for mankind requires more food than some kind of beasts or birds; for a man would be starv'd, if he should eat no more than a Dormouse, or a Camelion, or a Sparrow.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: But a Sparrow cannot eat so much as an Eagle, nor an Eagle so much as an Estrich: Likewise, as it is with Bird-kind, so it is with Mankind, some would starve with that proportion another would surfet on.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: But surely there are none that could surfet with your diet, as with Water and Air, nay (most commonly) nothing but Air, Camelion-like: for you oft times for a week together neither eat bit, nor drink a drop; and that which makes me wonder more, is, that you naturally have a very good stomach, and can eat, when you please, very heartily, and it thrives well with you; but my greater wonder is, that when you do fast, eating now and then a bit, week after week, nay moneth after moneth, yet you are not so lean, as to appear a Skeleton, nor so weak, but you can walk two hours without resting, or being very weary.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: Oh Custome is a second Nature, Ioan.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: I would have your Ladyship accustome your self to live without eating, and then you will be set in a Chronicle.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: Who would strive for that, since most think Chronologers are Artificers, and that their Chronicles are false.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: Why some will believe it; and it were better to live in the memory of a few, than to die to all memory, and to live by nothing.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: I would have my Fame live only by singular and transcending Merits, not by singular and melancholy Follies. I know my Errors, though I cannot mend my Faults.

div.head: Scene 9.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Procurer, and the Lady VVanton.

sp.speaker: PRocurer.
sp.p: Well Madam, you are to give me thanks for bringing you acquainted with Monsieur Amorous: for he is as fine a Gentleman as any our Nation hath.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: Indeed he is the most obligingst person as ever I met with; but pray Madam, what said he of me?

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: O he raves in your praise: He says you are the finest, sweetest, fairest and kindest Lady that ever was: but did not your Husband examine you when you came home?

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: No 'faith, not much, some slight questions he ask'd; but come into my Chamber, and there let us discourse of Monsieur Amorous.

div.head: Scene 10.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Jealousie, beating her Maid Nan.

sp.speaker: JEalousie.
sp.p: I will make you humbler than to give me such unmannerly words. What had you to do in my Husbands, your Masters Chamber?

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: I went to speak with Tom my Masters barber.

sp.speaker: Iealousie.
sp.p: What had you to do with your Masters barber? I am sure you had no use for him; but I will beat you so, as you shall not be able to stir, much less to go frisking into your Masters Chamber so often as you do.

div.stage: Falls a beating her again: Nan runs crying from her Lady, her Lady follows her. Enters Raillery Jester the Fool.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: What a Volly of words their gun-powder breath, and the fire-lock of their anger hath shot into my Ears, giving me no warning to baracade them up, but hath surprized my brain by their sudden assault, and hath blown up the Magazines of my Contemplations; but all creatures love to make a noise, beasts vocally, men verbally, and some actually in boysterous deeds.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: How now Fool, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Why this is the matter fool, thy Sister fool hath beaten her Maid fool, for kissing her Master fool.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: For kissing her Masters fool, say you?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Nay by'r Lady, if she had done so, she had been wise: for if she had kiss'd me, she had not been beaten; but she did not kiss me, Ergo she's a fool.

div.head: Scene. 11.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Hypocondria, and Sir VVilliam Lovewell her Husband.

sp.speaker: HYpocondria.
sp.p: Husband, why seem you so sad?

sp.speaker: Lovewel.
sp.p: My love to you makes me sad.

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: To me? Heaven bless me, what do you see in me to make you sad?

sp.speaker: Lovewel.
sp.p: Why for these passions and â€¢ rights that you fall into, like one in an Epilepsie, and now you look as pale, as if you were ready to fall down dead.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: Alas Husband, consider it is a timorous effect of Love, which is to be pardon'd, since it proceeds from the kindness I have to my Friends; it is honourable to the World, and no dishonour to you, but only troublesome to my self, and to those I naturally love, as Husband, Children, Father, Mother, Brothers, and Sisters: And though fond Love and vain Fears may be produced from the melancholy Spleen, yet those fears that proceed from my firm, true, and honest Affection, are created in the Soul: for noble, and honourable, and honest Fears, are the natural Issues of pure Love.

sp.speaker: Lovewel.
sp.p: But Reason, the chief Magistrate of the Soul, and Governour of the Passions, should temper the Excess.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: O Husband, when Love comes to be temper'd, it loses or quit â€¢ the essential part, and the vertical strength: for true Love is pure like gold, which is debased with an allay.

sp.speaker: Lovewel.
sp.p: But as Allay makes gold work better for use, so Temperance makes Love Happy for life.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: Well Husband, I will strive to love with Discretion.

sp.speaker: Lovewel.
sp.p: Pray do, and goe abroad, to divert your melancholy, and eat as others do, that may have good meat and drink, and not live by the Air, as you do.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: I shall obey you.

sp.speaker: LAdy Inconstant.
sp.p:
O Cupid, thou art a cruel Tyrant, making more wounds than remedies! And I am wounded so, as I am sick with Love, and
cannot live unless I am belov'd again.
sp.l: To make my Passions know, is all my care,
Lest he should love me not, is all my fear.

div.head: Scene. 13.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Procurer, and Sir Thomas Cuckold.

sp.speaker: LAdy Procurer.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Cuckold, Monsieur Amorous desires very much to make friendship with you: for he is so taken with your Civilities, and your courteous Demeanors when he was to visit you, that he swears you are one of the finest Gentlemen in the Kingdome: He says you are so gravely wise, so hospitably kind, and so generously free, as he honours you, and loves you with his soul.

sp.speaker: Cuckold.
sp.p: I am his very humble Servant, and shall be glad, nay proud of such a worthy Friend as Monsieur Amorous.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Have you returned his Visit?

sp.speaker: Cuckold.
sp.p: No; but I'll go wait upon him immediatly.

div.head: Scene 14.
div.stage: Enter Nan the Lady Jealousies Maid, going through the room crying, and the Fool following her singing.

sp.speaker: FOol.
sp.l: Childrens eyes are always flowing,
Womens tongues are always going,
And mens brains are always musing,
And mans natures all abusing,
And mans life is always running,
And mans death is always comming.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: VVhose death is comming?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Yours for any thing I know: wherefore take heed; for let me tell you; Death is a rough fellow: for he pulls the soul out of the body, as a Barber-Chirurgeon doth a tooth, sometimes with less pain, sometimes with more; but many times Death is forc'd to tear the body, as a Tooth-drawer tears the jaw-bone, before he can get it out.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: VVhat Instruments doth Death draw out the Soul with?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Sickness, VVounds, Passions, Accidents, and the like.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: But how came Death and you so well acquainted?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: VVe are near a Kin: for Death and Ignorance are Cousin-Germans.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: 'Faith thou art rather a Knave than a Fool, and a Knave is nearer a-kin to Life than Death.

div.head: Scene 15.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Disagree, and her Chaplin Master Perswader.

sp.speaker: DIsagree.
sp.p: VVell, I am resolv'd to be Divorced from my Husband, for I cannot endure his tyranny any longer: for he will let me have my will in nothing, crosses and contradicts me in every thing.

sp.speaker: Perswader.
sp.p: Madam, we are taught to obey and humble our selves to our Superiours, and the Husband is the Master of his Family, the Governour of his Estate, and Ruler and Disposer of his Children, the Guide and Protector of his VVife.

sp.speaker: Disagree.
sp.p: Yes, he protects me well indeed, when he breaks my head.

sp.speaker: Perswader.
sp.p: May be your Ladyship doth provoke him with some unkind words.

sp.speaker: Disagree.
