sp.p: VVhat unkind words were they? I only said that Goos-quils made the best pens to write with, and he said no, that Crows-quils were better for that purpose: 'tis true, at last I returned as bad words as he flung at me.

sp.speaker: Perswader.
sp.p: Truly Madam, it is a great grief to your friends and servants, to see yoo live so disquietous together; besides, you torment your selves with your own anger.

sp.speaker: Disagree.
sp.p: That's the reason I would part: for I will never be a slave to his humour, I will rather chuse to die first.

div.head: Scene 16.
div.stage: Enter Sir Humphrey Disagree, and Master Makepeace his Friend.

sp.speaker: SIr Hum. Disagree.
sp.p: It were better we were parted, than to live in a perpetual war together.

sp.speaker: Makepeace.
sp.p: But Sir, is it not possible to temper your Passion?

sp.speaker: Disagree.
sp.p: No truly: for her words are so sharp, and pierce so deep, that they make me as furious as a wilde Boar that is hurt with a Javelin: And since she cannot temper her Tongue, nor I temper my Passion, it will be best for us to live asunder: for absence is the best and most certain remedy I can think of.

div.head: Scene 17.
div.stage: Enter two Serving-men of Sir VVilliam Lovewels.

sp.speaker: 1 SErvant.
sp.p: Have not you heard that my Master hath had a Quarrel, and is wounded?

sp.speaker: 2 Servant.
sp.p: Yes; and 'tis said he fought so valiantly, as he beat half a dozen lusty men, and followed them so close, as they were forc'd to take shelter; and I have also heard, that one of them he beat, swears to be revenged.

sp.speaker: 1 Servant.
sp.p: But if my Lady hears of it, she will run mad, or die.

sp.speaker: 2 Servant.
sp.p: O no, my Lady (Ioan says) hath left those follies, and is become discreet.

sp.speaker: 1 Servant.
sp.p: Discreet? what is that? to be ill-natur'd, as not to care if her Husband or Friends be kill'd?

sp.speaker: 2 Servant.
sp.p: O yes, so much to care, as to pity them, and be sorry, nay sad, if they should be kill'd; but not passionately to drown themselves in tears, or to let their grief feed on their life, and die.

div.head: Scene 18.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Amorous and Sir Thomas Cuckold: They meet each other, and imbrace as two dear Friends.

sp.speaker: CUckold.
sp.p: O my sweet Amorous!

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: O my dear Cuckold, the delight of my Life!

sp.speaker: Cuckold.
sp.p: 'Faith Amorous I have been to seek you all the Town over, and my Lady Procurer met me, and sent me to the other end of the City, telling me you were at the Horn-Tavern.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: Why do you not know her humour? she will serve you twenty such tricks: for she is the veriest Wag in all the Town, although she is in years.

sp.speaker: Cuckold.
sp.p: Well, if I be not even with her, as very a Wag as she is, let me be condemn'd for a fool.

div.head: Scene 19.
div.stage: Enter a Maid as to her Lady, the Lady Hypocondria.

sp.speaker: MAid.
sp.p: O Madam, my Master is comming home, being wounded in a Duel.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Help, help, my Lady, my Lady.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: My Lady is kill'd with the report of my Masters being hurt.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: It were fit you should be punish'd for telling her of it.

div.stage: They raise the Lady, and bow her forward: She revives, but with a groan.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: Take life again: for my Master is not so much hurt, as to be in danger of Death.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: Do you speak this as a known truth, or for to recover me?

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: As a truth upon my Conscience, Madam.

sp.speaker: Hypocon.
sp.p: Then I charge you do not discover my Passion.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: We shall not.

div.head: Scene 20.
div.stage: Enter Sir VVilliam Lovewell, and two of his men, and his Man Roger Trusty.

sp.speaker: LOvewell.
sp.p: Go, and give charge to my Footmen, that none of them run home to tell my Wife of my hurt, for fear of frighting her: for if she hears I am hurt before she sees me, she will apprehend me worse than I am, and that may kill her.

sp.speaker: Servant.
sp.p: Sir, she hath heard of it already.

sp.speaker: Lovewel.
sp.p: Rogue that he was that he was that told her: who was it?

sp.speaker: Roger Trusty.
sp.p: It was I Sir, when I went to fetch your Leaguer-cloak to keep you warm.

sp.speaker: Lovewel.
sp.p: Villain, I'll run you through.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p:
What you please Sir; but my Lady takes it very patiently: for
when she heard of it, she was playing on the Lute, and did not leave playing at the report.

sp.speaker: Lovewel.
sp.p: I am glad she is so discreet.

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: Truly Sir I think my Lady is now one of the wisest and discreetest Ladies in the Town.

sp.speaker: Lovewel.
sp.p: What, for playing on the Lute?

sp.speaker: Trusty.
sp.p: No Sir; but for being so patient and temperate, as all wise persons are, who bear afflictions with that Moral Philosophical Carelesness, and (as they call it) passive Courage, composing their Faces into a Grave, surly Countenance, fashioning their Behaviour with Formality, walking with a slow and stately Pace, speaking nothing but Wise Sentences, and Learned Morals.

sp.speaker: Lovewel.
sp.p: You are a moral Ass; and although my wounds are but small, yet I grow faint with standing to hear a fool talk.

div.head: Scene 21.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Inconstant, and Monsieur Disguise.

sp.speaker: LAdy Inconst.
sp.p: Sir, I believe you may wonder, and think it strange, that a woman can love a stranger so soon and so much.

sp.speaker: Disguise.
sp.p: I doe not think it strange in Nature, but I think it strange you should affect me, a person which is no way worthy of your Favour and your Love, unless you (like a Deity) humbly descend to mortals, accepting of their Adorations and Offerings: And, as a mortal to a Deity, I offer up my Heart on the Altar of your Obligations.

sp.speaker: Inconstant.
sp.p: Here I do vow to Venus, not only to offer you my person, and all delights that it can yield, but I offer you my Honour, my Fathers Honour, my Husbands Honour, nay their lives, if you require it.

sp.speaker: Disguise.
sp.p: I must confess your Husbands life is dangerous, for we cannot well enjoy our loves with safety, if that your Husband lives.

sp.speaker: Inconstant.
sp.p: Name but the way unto his Death, and I will execute it.

sp.speaker: Disguise.
sp.p: I cannot; for you must do it as you find Fortune gives you opportunity.

sp.speaker: Inconstant.
sp.p: Farewel and believe, I shall let no opportunity slip, that might bring my designs to pass.

sp.speaker: Disguise.
sp.p: My revenge is too big for words, all actions to little for his punishment: wherefore you furies, I invoke you to assist me, and if Hell gives me not help, Heaven or Death give me ease.

div.head: Scene 22.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Procurer, and Monsieur Amorous.

sp.speaker: LAdy Procurer.
sp.p: Now Monsieur Amorous, you and the Lady Wanton shall not need to make so many excuses to meet, for your going into the Country, with Sir Thomas Cuckold, you will be always in the House with his Lady.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: Faith, I have a great deal of business in the City, which may suffer, if I should go out of the Town.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Out upon you, make excuses already.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: I do not make excuses, I only tell you the truth of my affairs.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Can you have any affairs greater, or of more concernment, than waiting on a Mistriss, and such a Mistriss as you were a dying for to enjoy, but a little time since? well go thy ways Monsieur Amorous, for thou art like a woman that hath fits of the Mother, often swouning and sick, but never dyes in any of them.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: The Lady Chastity would be like a draught of cold water, to bring me to life again.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Let me tell thee, as those fits will never kill thee, so all the Chastity in the Town can never cure thee.

div.head: Scene 23.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Hypocondria, and Joan her Maid.

sp.speaker: LAdy Hypocondria.
sp.p: Pray Iuno, my Husband doth not perceive I have cry'd.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: You need not fear it, for the hot Cloath you laid to your eyes hath so â€¢ 'd out the redness, and abated the swelling thereof; but I doubt you will cry when you see him.

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: I hope I shall be wiser, than to cry; for I would not have my Husband think me a Fool, or troublesome, for the world.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: But surely Madam, you must needs torment your Soul, to strive so much against nature.

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: Love had rather torment it self, then torment what it loves.

sp.speaker: Ioan.
sp.p: Your Ladyship will make the old Proverb good, which sayes, love overcomes all things, and surely it overcomes all when it overcomes nature it self.

div.head: Scene 24.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Jealousy, and the Fool.

sp.speaker: LAdy Iealousy.
sp.p: Prethy Fool watch thy Master, and my Maid Nan, and when they are together give notice, and I will give thee a new Coat.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: I shall stand Sentinel, and give the watch-word.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Most Creatures their tails lyes in their heads, or their heads lyes in their Neighbours tayles, nose to breech; for they are always thinking thereof; which makes their thoughts as sluts and slovens, their brains like to a heap â€¢ -up Dunghil; but I must watch, my Master and his Maid to catch.

div.head: Scene 25.
div.stage: Enter Master Makepeace, and Master Perswader, friend and Chaplain to Sir Humphrey Disagree.

sp.speaker: MAster Makepeace.
sp.p: 'Tis strange, that Sir Humphrey Disagree, and his Lady, cannot agree, yet they are both of good natures, and generous Souls; keep a noble House, and are bountifull to their Servants, kind and courteous to their Friends, and he a very understanding Gentleman, and a learned Scholar, and an honest Man.

sp.speaker: Perswader.
sp.p: And she is a very Chast Lady, a good Huswife, and very orderly in her House, as concerning what she is to take care of, or to direct, and is very pious and devout, and yet both to be so indiscreet as to fall out about light toys, and frivolous matters.

sp.speaker: Makepeace.
sp.p: 'Tis strange, and truly great pitty; wherefore, we ought to do our indeavour, to try if we can make them friends.

sp.speaker: Perswader.
sp.p: Surely that might be easily done; for they are as apt, and as soon friends when their anger's over, as they are apt to fall out when they are friends, and I make no doubt to make them friends; but the business is to keep them friends, and the question is, whether it were not better they should be parted friends, than present enemies.

sp.speaker: Makepeace.
sp.p: Yet we have discharged our parts, if we make or do our indeavour to make them friends.

sp.speaker: Perswader.
sp.p: Well Sir, perswade the Husband, and I will try to perswade the Wife.

div.head: Scene 26.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Disguise, and Sir Francis Inconstant.

sp.speaker: SIr Francis Inconstant.
sp.p: Sir, you do amaze me; for I have not been so long married as to give her time for Incontinency, nor have I been so ill a Husband as yet, as to create, or beget her hate towards me.

sp.speaker: Disguise.
sp.p: Sir, if I do not prove it, I shall be content to suffer the heaviest punishment you can inflict upon me; and because your belief is wavering, I will place you, where you shall hear her declare her intentions, as towards your Death.

sp.speaker: Inconstant.
sp.p: I long to prove the Truth.

div.head: Scene 27.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Wanton, and the Lady Procurer.

sp.speaker: LAdy Wanton.
sp.p: Prethy my Lady Procurer, go into the Country with us, since we shall have such good Company this Summer, as Monsieur Amorous, we will be so merry, and have such sports and pastimes, as you shall not repent your journey.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Faith Madam I cannot; besides, you have no use of me now.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: I am not as many others are, that when they can make no more use of a friend, they strive to shun their Company.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Well, if I can go with you I will; but I doubt I cannot, at lest I cannot stay above a week, or such a time with you.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: Nay, if I once get you there, I will make you stay.

div.head: Scene 28.

sp.speaker: MIstriss Single.
sp.p: What a troublesome life is a Married life, bless me Heaven, who would Marry?

div.stage: Enter Raillery Jester at her last words.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: That would you if you could get a Husband; for Maids long to be Wives, and Wives longs to be Widows, that they might Marry again.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: That is, because Maids do not know the vexations of Marriage, which Wives do.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Faith Women take a pleasure in being vext, crost, and injured; for then they have a ground for their anger, and revenge is the sweetest, and dearest imployment they have, or would wish to have; otherwise, they would be dull, and idle without it; and to prove it, Widows are as â€¢ arae â€¢â€¢ , and industrious to Marry as Maids, and all is, because they would be vext and crost.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: And are not men as desirous, and hasty to Marry as Women?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Yes, those that are Fools.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Why then you should marry, if any VVoman would have you.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Such Fools as I, never, or very seldom Marry, for though we are Christened Fools, we were Born VVise (where other men were Born Fool â€¢ , but Christened VVise) as bearing the name of VVise and understanding Men, so as they have only the name, but not the wisdome; the Truth is, we Fool, and other men are fool'd.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Then VVomen are Born VVise, for they Fool Men.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Nay saith, poor Souls, they are for the most part double fool'd; first, thinking they fool, and then in being fooled.

div.stage: Enter a Maid of the Lady Jealousy's.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Mistriss, my Lady is very angry, that you let your Lute-Master stay, whilst you talk to the fool; she says you will be as much a fool as he, with talking so often with him.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Tell my Sister, I shall learn more good from the fool, than the sidler.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Mark you that Maid.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: I mark that Children and Fools keep company together.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: And the Maids and the Master.

div.head: Scene 29.
div.stage: Enter two Maids of the Lady Hypocondria.

sp.speaker: 1 MAid.
sp.p: Alas my poor Lady looks as if she would drop to the earth, so pale and ill.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: How should she be otherwise, for she smothers in her grief, and dares not discover it; and then she seldom sleeps, or eats, or drinks: and is so restless, as she cannot sit still, but walks about her Chamber.

div.head: Scene 30.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Hypocondria, and a Doctor.

sp.speaker: LAdy Hypocondria.
sp.p: O Master Doctor, what do you think of my Husband, I hope he is in no danger, is he?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: I dare assure you Madam, he will be very well again; for he is only weak and faint with loss of blood: for he taking the wound to be slight, did not take care to stop it soon enough, whereupon his Spirits with his blood issued out so much, as makes him so weak, as you see he is forc'd to keep his Bed.

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: But Doctor, Spirits is life, and if he wants the one, he must soon lose the other.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: 'Tis true, if there were no Spirits left: but let me tell you Madam, there is more danger when the Body hath too many Spirits, than when there is but a few; for many Spirits make the Body too hot, by giving the Pulse too quick a motion; which quick motion, fires the heart so much, as the blood becomes boyling hot; which Perboyls the Liver, and the rest of the vital parts, and melts the fat, wastes the flesh, and weakens the Sinnews, or Nerves, as being boyled as to a soft, tender, quaking Jelly; that is the cause that the Sick is so weak they cannot stand, having not that tough strength in their Sickness, and some after their sickness; and shall continue weak, untill such time as the Sinnews, and Nerves grow harder, and tough again; and many times from the boyling blood there arises such gross, and so many Vapours, which Vapours is Smoak, as they stif â€¢ le the life, or at least disquiet the Brain.

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: But will you assure me Doctor?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: As far as Human skill can assure you I will.

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: Fair Iuno hear me, send to thy Brother Pluto, to imprison Death in his dark Vault, or at least for to forbid him to touch my Husband; and fair Goddess, send health to raise his weary limbs from off his hated Couch, if not, give order to grim Death to strike me too; for thou hast power on all, as being chief in power.

sp.speaker: Maid.
sp.p: Madam, my Master desires you would be pleased to come to him.

sp.speaker: MOnsieur Disguise.
sp.p: I will not only make me a Garland, but a Bower of Willow, where I will sit and lament all forsaken Lovers; nay, I will sit and Curse so long, till I have laid those Curses so thick together, as neither sighs, nor tears, nor prayers, shall dissolve them.

div.head: Scene 32.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Procurer, and Monsieur Amorous.

sp.speaker: LAdy Procurer.
sp.p: I am come to bring you good news, Monsieur Amorous.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: What is that my comfortable Lady?

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: The Lady Wanton is come to Town.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: What do you swear, because she is come to Town?

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: No I swear, because I must go out of Town.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: I hope you will not go out of the Town, now she is come to town.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: Alas my occasions are such, as I shall be utterly ruined if I stay.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Then let me tell you, the Lady Chastity begins to listen to your Sute.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: And is there hopes I shall enjoy her?

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: Nay Dear Lady, speak some comfort?

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: It is a solly, if you must go into the Country.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: Neptune shall swallow the Country, rather than I will endanger to lose a Paradise.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: But if you stay, you will be ruined.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: I rather shall be ruined if I go, for now I have considered it, I find, I have such potent affairs here in the City, as they will force me to stay.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: O Iupiter! how Inconstant is Mankind; for what they have enjoyed they despise, and what they cannot get, they earnestly desire, and are restless in the pursute.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: What say you?

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: I say you are an unthankfull Man, and not worthy of a Ladyes favour, as to forsake her that loves you, and seek her that hates you; for know, the Lady Chastity scorns your Sute, despises your Person, and hates your Humour.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: Pluto take all your sex.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p:
If he should, you would whiningly follow them to Hell, rather
than miss their Company, refusing Heaven, for effeminate Society.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: They torment men more than Devils do.

div.head: Scene 33.
div.stage: Enter Master Makepeace, and Master Perswader.

sp.speaker: MAster Makepeace.
sp.p: Now Sir Humphrey Disagree and his Lady are made good friends, they are become a loving Couple.

sp.speaker: Perswader.
sp.p: Heaven keep them so.

sp.speaker: Makepeace.
sp.p: Truly I begin to believe they will; for they seem very sensible of their errors, and they laugh at their one follies, to see, what ridiculous, frivolous, and small matters, their quarels are built with, and upon.

div.stage: Enter Sir Humphrey Disagree, and his Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Humphrey Disagree.
sp.p: Look you Wife, here is the Priest that hath new married us, and our friend that hath joyned us in a loving friendship again.

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: And I will celebrate this Union with a Feast, to which, I will invite my good friends as to my wedding day.

sp.speaker: Humphrey Disagree.
sp.p: I perceive we shall be merry, pray let us have Fidlers, and Dance.

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: That we will.

div.head: Scene 34.
div.stage: Enter Sir VVilliam Lovewell upon a Couch, as being weak, and his Lady following him.

sp.speaker: SIr William Lovewell.
sp.p: Come, come Wife, you are not so kind as you were wont to be; for you did use to watch my looks, my sleep, and how I fetcht my breath in my sleep, and what I did eat, and how much I did eat, for fear I should be sick, and no help unsought to cure me: But I perceive you are as all other women are, inconstant; for now you do neglect me, and seldom come near me but when I send for you.

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: I dare not, for fear my diligence may prove loves indiscretion, and so my service become a burthensome trouble.

div.stage: Enter one of the Men Sir William fought with, and beat, with a Pistol in his hand, the Lady Hypocondria sees him, and on the sudden runs to the Man, and snatches the Pistol out of his hand, the whilst the Man was in amaze at it, She Shoots him with his own Pistol, the noise of the Pistol brings in the Servants.

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: You Cowardly Rogue, do you take the advantage of sickness to work your revenge, do you come when my Husband is not able to defend himself?

div.stage: The Man falls, and sayes, O I am kill'd.

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: Kill'd? if you had a thousand lives, my single life would kill them all, rather than suffer my Husband to be murdered.

div.stage: The Servants all the while stand at a distance, as being all afrighted.

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: You Company of dull dead statues, move for shame, and bear away this Villain, this murderous Villain.

sp.speaker: Servants.
sp.p: Where should we carry him Madam?

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: Why any where, cast him into a Ditch, there let him ly and rot, like Beasts without Butiall.

div.stage: The mean while Sir William Lovewell having recovered his breath, which was spent in striving to get up from his Couch, but being very weak he could not.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: Carry him to a Justice, and bid the Justice dispose of him as he thinks fit, telling him of his crime.

sp.speaker: Servants.
sp.p: Let us search him, to see if he hath never another Pistol.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: Go you Cowards, and carry him away.
sp.stage: The Servants and Man goes out.
sp.p: O this effeminate sickness hath disgraced me; O how like a worm a sick man is, which lyes so low, and is so shiftless, that any beast treads out his life?

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: Why, had you been in health and strength, it would have been no Honour to beat a Coward.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: He seem'd not such a Coward, but that he had some courage, or otherwise he would not have adventur'd himself alone into a House, wherein were many persons, which would have been his Enemies; but I am glad that you have the honour of his wounds, but it is a miracle to me, to see how valiantly you did behave your self, and yet by nature is so fearfull.

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: Mistake not Love; for true Love is only a fraid when it cannot help, but when it hath hopes to rescue what it loves, Mars is not Valianter.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: Well Wife, I owe my life to your love, and I shall account you as Pallas, that hath defended me with a prudent courage.

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: If you think I have done you service worthy a reward, pray give me a request.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: That I shall, if it be that life you have defended, what is it?

sp.speaker: Hypocondria.
sp.p: It is to set love free from the Chains of discretion, and Jailer of temperance; for it is impossible to confine love, but either it will dy, or break out in revenge.

sp.speaker: Lovewell.
sp.p: VVell VVife, hereafter I will never oppose loves wayes.

div.head: Scene 35.
div.stage: Enter Sir Francis Inconstant, and Monsieur Disguise.

sp.speaker: MOnsieur Disguise.
sp.p: Sir, did you hear what your Lady said?

sp.speaker: Francis Inconstant.
sp.p: Yes, I heard her say, she would poyson me in a mess of broath.

sp.speaker: Disguise.
sp.p: VVhat will you do to prevent it?

sp.speaker: Inconstant.
sp.p: Leave that care to me, I shall be my own Sentinel, to discern the aproaching Poyson.

sp.speaker: Disguise.
sp.p: Their Deaths will be my triumph, and my Death a reprieve.

div.head: Scene 36.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Amorous, and the Lady Procurer:

sp.speaker: LAdy Procurer.
sp.p: I am come to invite you to a Collation, for the Lady Wanton, for whom you at first made costly Collations, is forced to invite you now to the like.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: Faith Madam, I am so squezy stomacked, that the very sight of a Banquet will put me into an Apoplexy, as with an obstructed Surfit.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: If you should deny her, you would lose you reputation amongst our Sex for ever.

sp.speaker: Amorous.
sp.p: Well I will go, upon condition that you carry a message from me to another Lady.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Most willingly, so it be not to the Lady Chastity.

div.head: Scene 37.
div.stage: Enter Mistriss Single, and Raillery Jester the Fool.

sp.speaker: MIstriss Single.
sp.p: Prethy Fool give me advice, as how to choose a Husband.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Faith you are wise to take a Fools Counsel; for Fools have for the most part, best Fortune, either in their Counsel or Choice.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Why, are Fools Fortunes favourites?

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Yes, for by Fools Fortune plainly shews her power, when wise men usurp it, striving to take her power from her.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Then Fortune direct thee, to direct me.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: Fortune is giddy, and directs by chance, which causes so many misfortunes.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Then by your direction, I may be unfortunate; but I will venture, wherefore tell me how to choose.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: VVhy then, you must choose a Husband by the Ear.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: By the Eye you mean.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: No faith, those that would be happily match'd, must choose a Husband, or VVife by the Ear, and not by the Eye: for though report is oft-times false, yet it seldom flatters; nay for the most part, it is so far from giving merit its due Praises, as it detracts therefrom.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: But Fortune carries worthless men upon the tongue of fame.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: 'Tis true, but Fortune being giddy, is apt to stagger, and so to stumble, and oft-times flings those worthless men in soul disgrace.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: But hopes and fears, bribe or force the VVorld to praise a worthless He, or Shee.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: 'Tis true, hopes of gain are bribes, and fear of punishments are threats, for to perswade, or force the tongue to flatter; yet none but Gods and Kings, are subject to this flattery, and you are not to marry, either the one, nor yet the other; for Gods joyn not to Mortals, and Kings are far too proud to marry Subjects; nor were it good for you, if that they would, as that you were matcht to a King: for happiness lives in equallity.

sp.speaker: Single.
sp.p: Faith thou art too wise to wear a Fools-Coat; wherefore cast it oft.

sp.speaker: Fool.
sp.p: And faith I should be more Fool than my profession makes me, if I should cast it off; therefore I will keep it on.

div.head: Scene 39.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Inconstant, and Monsieur Disguise.

sp.speaker: LAdy Inconstant.
sp.p: O my Dear love, I have such an opportunity, that Fortune could never have given me a better; for my Husband is fallen Sick, and if I Poyson him now, the VVorld will say, and think it was his Sickness that kill'd him, and that will secure me.

sp.speaker: Disguise.
sp.p: I he be Sick, perchance he may dye, and that will save you the labour, and hazard of poysoning.

sp.speaker: Inconstant.
sp.p: O But if he should recover again, then I were undone; wherefore I will not venture to rely upon his Sickness.

sp.speaker: Disguise.
sp.p: Use your discretion, but tis not fit we should be seen together; wherefore, I will kiss your hands, and leave you for a time.

sp.speaker: Inconstant.
sp.p: And I hope the next time we meet, we shall be rid of the obstructor of our loves:

div.head: Scene. 39.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Wanton, and the Lady Procurer.

sp.speaker: LAdy Wanton.
sp.p: Madam, did you give Monsieur Amorous the present I sent you to give him?

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Yes, there was Shirts, Caps, and Handkerchiefs, of each two dozen.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: There were so.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: They were of the finest Holland, and Flanders Lace, that ever I saw, what might the present cost you?

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: Not much above five hundred pounds.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: You speak as if it were but a slight present, but if your Husband knew of it, he would think it were too much by four hundred ninety and nine pound nineteen shillings eleven pence halfpeny farthing.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: But what said Monsieur Amorous, when you presented that present, as from me?

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: At the first he would not receive the present, saying it was too costly, and that he could not return enough thanks for it, and so should seem as ungratefull against his will; but at last upon my perswasion, he took your present, and to Morrow he will come and give you thanks.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: I had rather meet him in some other place, than receive his visit at home, where my Husband is.

div.head: Scene 40.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Poverty weeping, and two or three Children following her: Then Enters her Husband.

sp.speaker: LAdy Poverty.
sp.p: Husband, how shall these Children live?

sp.speaker: Spendall.
sp.p: By Heavens Providence Wife.

sp.speaker: Poverty.
sp.p: I fear they will starve, unless your providence feeds them.

sp.speaker: Spendall.
sp.p: It was imprudently done to get them.

sp.speaker: Poverty.
sp.p: But now they are got, they must be provided for.

sp.speaker: Spendall.
sp.p: Yes, as Beggers provide for their Children, put them to the Parish.

sp.speaker: Poverty.
sp.p: The Parish will not keep them.

sp.speaker: Spendall.
sp.p: Then sell them to Animal Merchants, they will Traffick with them into the Barbadoes, or Barmudes, or Virginy, or the like places.

sp.speaker: Poverty.
sp.p: And how shall I live?

sp.speaker: Spendall.
sp.p: Why you may go along, and be their Nurse.

sp.speaker: Poverty.
sp.p: And the Merchants Whore.

sp.speaker: Spendall.
sp.p: As you can agree; for he may sell you at as great a prize after, as if you were honest; besides, your Children will prove you to be fruitfull, for which, they will give a double, or trebble price for you; and if you thrive send me word, and I will come to you, if I cannot live here.

sp.speaker: Poverty.
sp.p: I thank you Husband, for you have made me miserably unhappy, by your mispendings, yet you would feed upon my good fortune, if it can be call'd good fortune, to thrive with dishonesty.

sp.speaker: Spendall.
sp.p: Faith Fortune hath undone me; but may be she will be charitable to you.

sp.speaker: Poverty.
sp.p: I hope so, for Fortune never befriends those whom Vices besots, and though your deboysteries have undone you, I hope my Virtues will help to save me.

sp.speaker: Spendall.
sp.p: But I never perceived your virtue to do you any good, but for any thing I perceive to the contrary, you are like to starve, for all your virtues.

sp.speaker: Poverty.
sp.p: I hope when I am parted from you and your wickedness, Heaven will powre down some mercy on me.

div.head: Scene 41.
div.stage: Enter the Lady VVanton, and the Lady Procurer.

sp.speaker: LAdy Wanton.
sp.p: Pray Madam inform me where Monsieur Amorous is, for I have sent two or three times to his Lodging, and my Messenger is answered still he is from home.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: He is a wanderer.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: I think he is wandred into some other parts of the World, for after he went from us, I sent a dozen Letters, whilst I staid in the Country, and received not one answer.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Faith Madam Monsieur Amorous is one of the lasiest of Mankind.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: I am resolv'd when I see him to chide him, for I could not conveniently do it when he came to give me thanks for my present.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Sir Thomas Cuckold, you are welcome to the Town, for though I have had the Honour to see your Lady two or three times, yet I could not got a sight of you never since you came out of the Country.

sp.speaker: Cuckold.
sp.p: My Wife did wish for your Company whilst we were in the Country, a hundred times.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: I should be glad to be in any place, to do my Lady Service.

sp.speaker: Cuckold.
sp.p: I was abroad even now, where I met Monsicur Amorous, who lookt upon me as if he knew me not, or rather as if he did despise me.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Perchance he did not know you.

sp.speaker: Cuckold.
sp.p: His memory must be very short, if he could forget me so soon.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: Perchance Husband you lookt strangely upon him.

sp.speaker: Cuckold.
sp.p: Truly Wife I went to imbrace him, as I was used to do, with kind love, and he crost the street to shun me.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: I dare lay my life it is some mistake Husband.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Friends (Sir Thomas) must never be exceptious.

sp.speaker: Cuckold.
sp.p: I am not apt to be exceptious, I will assure you Madam no Man is freer from that humour than I am.

div.head: Scene 42.
div.stage: Enter Sir Francis Inconstant as sick upon a Couch, he being alone.

sp.speaker: SIr Francis Inconstant.
sp.p: This feigned Sickness shall serve as a snare, to catch my Wives design.

sp.speaker: Lady Inconstant.
sp.p: My dear heart how are you?

sp.speaker: Francis Inconstant.
sp.p: Very Sick, so Sick as I fear Heaven doth envy my happiness, and will part us by Death.

sp.speaker: Lady Inconstant.
sp.p: The Gods forbid! I hope you will live so long, as to Crown your Virtuous life with aged years.

sp.speaker: Francis Inconstant.
sp.p: O no, I find my life draws towards an end, and Death will separate us from each other; but you being young Wife, will soon forget me, placing your love upon some other Man, in whom, all the remembrance of me will be buried.

sp.speaker: Lady Inconstant.
sp.p: Dear Husband speak not so Melancholy; your words strike such terrour into my heart, as I cannot indure to hear them, I had rather Death should strike me, than you; Dear Husband, cheer up your self, your Disease is only Melancholly; wherefore take such nurishing things, as may give your Spirits strength and life; shall I bring you a little Burnt Wine, to comfort your Spirits, or some Jelly broath to strenghten your Stomack?

sp.speaker: Francis Inconstant.
sp.p: If you please VVife.

sp.speaker: Francis Inconstant.
sp.p: Now for the poysoned Draught.

div.stage: Enter the Lady with a Porrenger of Broath.

sp.speaker: Lady Inconstant.
sp.p: Here my dear heart, drink this.

div.stage: He takes the Porrenger, and when it was in his hand, he rises and goeth to the Chamber Door, and locks it.

sp.speaker: Lady Inconstant.
sp.p: VVhat mean you Husband to lock the Door?

sp.speaker: Francis Inconstant.
sp.p: Because none shall enter, untill the Broath be drunk VVife.

div.stage: She seems to be afraid, and desires to go forth of the Chamber.

sp.speaker: Francis Inconstant.
sp.p: No Wife, you must not go out, for I mean to nourish you with that Broath that you would have nourished me with.

sp.speaker: Lady Inconstant.
sp.p: Why Husband I am not Sick, I do not require Broath.

sp.speaker: Francis Inconstant.
sp.p: O yes VVife, your Soul is Sick, although your Body is well, and this Broath may perchance cure the one, although it kills the other; wherefore drink it.

sp.speaker: Lady Inconstant.
sp.p: I will not.

sp.speaker: Francis Inconstant.
sp.p: You shall, and if you drink it not willingly, I will force it down you throat.

sp.speaker: Lady Inconstant.
sp.p: Dear Husband spare me.

sp.speaker: Francis Inconstant.
sp.p: Why, I give you nothing but that which you prepared for me, and if it were good for me, it is good for you.

sp.speaker: Lady Inconstant.
sp.p: Dear Husband have mercy on me, and I will confess my crimes.

sp.speaker: Francis Inconstant.
sp.p: No VVife, no more mercy than you would have had one me, and therefore drink it:

sp.speaker: Lady Inconstant.
sp.p: 'Tis Poyson Husband.

sp.speaker: Francis Inconstant.
sp.p: That is the reason you shall drink it VVife.

sp.speaker: Lady Inconstant.
sp.p: Dear Husband, let me live but to repent my sinns, which like a black thick cloud do cover all my Soul.

sp.speaker: Francis Inconstant.
sp.p: This will be a sufficient punishment, for if you be punished in this World, you may escape the punishment of the next.

sp.speaker: Lady Inconstant.
sp.p: Good Husband consider youth, that is apt to run into errors, not being guided with good Counsel, as it ought.

sp.speaker: Francis Inconstant.
sp.p: I will consider nothing, and therefore drink it, or by Heaven I will force you to it, and therefore linger not.

div.stage: The Lady Inconstant takes the Cap, and then kneels and lifts up her eyes towards Heaven, and then prayes.

sp.speaker: Lady Inconstant.
sp.p: You Gods forgive me my crimes, and let this deadly draught purge clean my Soul from sin.

sp.speaker: Francis Inconstant.
sp.p: Now VVife have you any Amorous desires to Monsieur Disguise.

sp.speaker: Lady Inconstant.
sp.p: No, the fire of my unlawfull love is quencht.

div.stage: She sinks to the ground, Heaven receive my Soul; O, O, Husband forgive me.

sp.speaker: Francis Inconstant.
sp.p:
Ha she is dead, what hath my furious passion done, I was too sudden to crop her tender life so hastily, without more strickt examinations; for it was likely thus spruse Gallant corrupted her with his alluring
looks, and smoth inticing words, which he knew well how to apply; and youth is credulous, and women soon perswaded, and being joyned in one they easily are overcome. I do repent.
sp.stage: He walks a turn or two in a Melancholy muse.
sp.p: I will revenge my self of those that were the cause.

div.head: Scene 43.
div.stage: Enter the Lady Procurer, and the Lady VVanton.

sp.speaker: LAdy Wanton.
sp.p: Where is Monsieur Amorous that he comes not with you, you said you would bring him with you?

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Faith he desires to be excused, for he saith he is not well.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: This is but an excuse, for he hath made an hundred within this week; but since he doth neglect me, I will have another that shall be more constant.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: You are wise Madam: for since men are so various as they are, women would seem but fools, should they be constant.

sp.speaker: Wanton.
sp.p: Well then Madam, you must do me a favour, for since I became acquainted with Monsieur Amorous, upon your perswasion, you must contrive a private meeting for me and another Gentleman, upon my perswasion.

sp.speaker: Procurer.
sp.p: Sweet Lady, you do oblige me to imploy me in your Service.

div.head: Scene 44.
div.stage: Enter two Maid Servants, that were the Lady Poverties.

sp.speaker: 1 MAid.
sp.p: O Ursely, I am glad to see thee with all my heart.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: Truly Ioan, so am I to see you.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: When did you hear of our good Lady, the Lady Poverty?

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: It was not long since I saw her.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: And how doth she live poor Lady?

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: Why she lives privately, but is likely to live happy enough; for let friends have now taken care of her and her Children, upon the condition that she will receive no visits from her Husband, but banish his Company; left he should encrease their charge with more Children; neither will they allow him any thing.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: By my trath he doth not deserve any maintenance; but I am glad she is provided for, being a shiftless creature for her self and Children, but where do you live Ursely?

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: Why I live with an old Widower.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p:
And I with a grave Matronly Widow, wherefore let us endeavour
to make a match betwixt them, that so we may live once again in a House together; for you and I were always dear friends you know.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: 'Tis true Iane, but as you are my friend I must tell you, I should be an ill friend to my self, if I should perswade my Master to marry.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: Nay if it be so Ursely, make the best of him; and if thou wilt shew me where thou dwellest, I will come and visit thee when I have leisure.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: Come with me, and I will shew you where I live.

div.head: Scene 45.
div.stage: A Table set out cover'd, and furnish'd with meat. Enter Sir Humphrey Disagree, and the Lady Disagree, and their Friends; every one takes their place, and sits as to eat.

sp.speaker: SIr Humphrey Disagree.
sp.p: Wife, where are the Fidlers that you promist we should have.

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: I did forbid them to play, untill such time as we had half din'd, for their scraping would hinder our eating.

sp.speaker: Humphrey Disagree.
sp.p: Pray wife let them come in, for I love my meat should dance in my mouth, my teeth keeping just time to the tune; and the Musick will make my meat turn nimbly in my mouth, and will heat my cast to a high gusto.

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: The noise that they will make, will take away my Stomack, and will make my head ake; besides, no body will hear one another speak, neither will our Servants hear what we call for.

sp.speaker: Humphrey Disagree.
sp.p: It will make our Servants the more diligent, for Musick will revive their Spirits, and will make them agil; wherefore pray VVife let them come in and play.

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: No pray Husband let them alone a little while longer.

sp.speaker: Humphrey Disagree.
sp.p: If you keep them out untill our Stomacks be full, we shall be so dull and heavy with the vapour of the meat, as it will not be in the power of Musick to move our minds to mirth, or so drunk with VVine, as the Musick will make us mad.

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: I hope you will not be mad before you are drunk.

sp.speaker: Humphrey Disagree.
sp.p: No VVife, I will be merry before I am drunk, wherefore Servants call them in.

div.stage: She speaks as to the Servants.

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: Let them alone.

sp.speaker: Humphrey Disagree.
sp.p: I say they shall come and play, and therefore call them in.

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: I say they shall not come in, nor play, therefore forbid them.

sp.speaker: Humphrey Disagree.
sp.p: Surely I will be Master, and therefore they shall play.

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: Surely I will be Mistriss of this Feast, and therefore they shall not play.

sp.speaker: Humphrey Disagree.
sp.p: Call them.

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: Let them alone.

div.stage: The Servants the while sometimes run as to the door, and then as from it, not knowing whether they should obey.
[Sir Humphrey rises as to call them himself, She rises also.]

sp.speaker: Humphrey Disagree.
sp.p: They shall come and play.

div.stage: He offers to go, She puls him back.

sp.speaker: Lady Disagree.
sp.p: They shall not play.

div.stage: He shoves her from him, she takes her Napkin and rouls it, flings it at him, he flings another at her; she takes a Plate, and throws at him, he Curses, and she Scolds, their Friends strive to part them, and in the strife and bussle, down goeth all the Pots and Dishes, and so they go sighting, and striving off the Stage.
The Servants take away all the meat and things, and after all was gone Enter two Maid-Servants.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: Lord there is such doings within, as it is wonderfull, my Master swears, my Lady cries, and rails, and rails and cries.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: in truth it is a sad Feast, and I was joyed to think how merry we should all be.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: And I pleased my self to think, what good cheer we should have, and what dainties we should eat.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: Why, so you may still.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: No Faith in this Hurlyburby every one catcht who catch could, that all is vanish'd, and purloyn'd away in this disorder.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: Come let us go, and see whether they can agree or not.

sp.speaker: 1 Maid.
sp.p: That they can never do, so long as the sound of their tongues is within the distance of their Ears; besides nature hath not matcht their dispositions, or humours.

sp.speaker: 2 Maid.
sp.p: You say right, intruth their Souls are mismatcht, and therefore it is impossible they should ever agree.

div.head: Scene 46.
div.stage: Enter Sir Francis Inconstant, and Monsieur Disguise.

sp.speaker: SIr Francis Inconstant.
sp.p: Sir my VVife your Mistriss is Dead.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Disguise.
sp.p: No Sir, my Mistriss and your VVhore is Dead.

sp.speaker: Inconstant.
sp.p: You are a Villain to corrupt her.

sp.speaker: Disguise.
sp.p: You are a Villain to marry her.

sp.speaker: Inconstant.
sp.p: Draw, for either or both of us Villains shall dy.

sp.speaker: Disguise.
sp.p: I fear not Death nor you.

sp.speaker: Disguise.
sp.p: Justice defend the wrong'd, and take my part.

div.stage: They fight and give each other deadly wounds; Sir Francis Inconstant falls, and as he lay on the ground speaks.

sp.speaker: Inconstant.
sp.p: Heaven is just, to punish perjury with violent Death; O my Conscience, how it stings me at my Death, with the remembrance of the wrongs I did my first love.

div.stage: Monsieur Disguise sinks close by Sir Francis; and then discovers her self.

sp.speaker: Mistriss Forsaken.
sp.p: Do you know this Face, or have my sorrows disfigur'd it so much, as you cannot call it to remembrance?

sp.speaker: Inconstant.
sp.p: You powers above, affright not my fleeting Soul with visions, but let it gently pass, and leave my body to the silent grave.

div.stage: He directs his Speech to her.

sp.speaker: Inconstant.
sp.p: You Spirit divine, take not revenge; for I am truly sorry for the wrongs I did thee in thy life.

sp.speaker: Mistriss Forsaken.
sp.p: I forgive you, and know I am no Spirit, and though I cannot say I live, because I am dying, yet I am not dead, and that Letter I brought you, was to disguise me the more by a false report; but I have acted the design of my Travel, which was to end my life with yours, for since I could not enjoy you in life, I desir'd to imbrace you by Death, and so I shall.

div.stage: She flings her arms over him and dyes.

sp.speaker: Inconstant.
sp.p: O my Soul make haste and follow hers.

div.stage: He kisses her, and on her lips dyes.

list.head: THE ACTORS NAMES.
list.item: Monsieur Adviser, and several other Gentlemen.
Madamoiselle Esperance, Wife to Monsieur Esperance.

div.head: THE FIRST PART OF NATURES three DAUGHTERS, Beauty, Love, and Wit.
ACT I.
Scene 1.
div.stage: Enter Madamoiselle Detractor, Madamoiselle Spightfull, Madamoiselle Malicious, and Madamoiselle Tell-truth.

sp.speaker: TEll-truth.
sp.p: The Lady Natures Daughters are the only Ladies that are admired, praised, adored, worshiped, and sued to; all other women are despised.

sp.speaker: Spightfull.
sp.p: We may go into a Nunnery; for we shall never get Servants, nor Husbands, as long as they live.

sp.speaker: Tell-truth.
sp.p: Why there are but three of them, and three women cannot serve and content all the men in the VVorld.

sp.speaker: Detractor.
sp.p: No, but they may discontent all the men so much, as to make them all to be Male-contented Lovers, who will reject all, because they cannot have what they desire.

sp.speaker: Malicious.
sp.p: Let us make a Faction against them.

sp.speaker: Spightfull.
sp.p: Alas what Faction against them, can hurt and destroy Love, Wit, and Beauty?

sp.speaker: Detractor.
sp.p: Jealousy will weaken Love, Dispraise will disgrace Wit, and Beauty, Time will soon bring that to decay.

sp.speaker: Tell-truth.
sp.p: But Jealousy cannot weaken true and virtuous Love, nor Dispraise cannot disgrace pure Wit, nor Time cannot decay the Beauty of the mind; wherefore all the faction you can make against them, will do them no hurt; besides, you will be condemned by all the Masculine Sex, if not punished with infamy, for your treachery; and since you cannot do them harm, your best way will be to imitate them for your own good.

sp.speaker: Spightfull.
sp.p: So we shall be laughed at, and stared on as Monkies, and scorned; forasmuch as we offer at that which is beyond our abilities, and whatsoever is forced, and constrained, appeareth ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Malicious.
sp.p: Come let us leave speaking of them, and thinking of them, if we can.

div.head: Scene 2.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Esperance, and his Wife Madamoiselle Esperance.

sp.speaker: MOnsieur Esperance.
sp.p: Surely Wife you do not love me, you are not any way kind to me.

sp.speaker: Madamoiselle Esperance.
sp.p: True Love Husband, is not so fond as serviceable.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Esperance.
sp.p: But true Love will express it self sometimes: for if you did truly Love me, you would hang about my Neck, as if you meant to dwell there.

sp.speaker: Madamoiselle Esperance.
sp.p: If I thought my kindness might not Surfet your affection, I would hang about your Neck, as the Earth to the Center, and as you move should bear me still about you; but I am afraid if overfond, you should be weary of me, and account me a trouble, and I had rather starve all my delights, than make you loath my Company.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Esperance.
sp.p: This is but an excuse Wife.

sp.speaker: Madamoiselle Esperance.
sp.p: Why are you Jealouse, that you think my words speak not my thoughts? have I behaved my self so indiscreetly, or have my actions been so light, as you believe I shall be wanton?

sp.speaker: Monsieur Esperance.
sp.p: No, I do not fear your Virtue.

sp.speaker: Madamoiselle Esperance.
sp.p: Do you fear my Indiscretion?

sp.speaker: Monsieur Esperance.
sp.p: I hope you will give me no cause to fear, although Husbands are oftner dishonoured by their Wives Indiscretions, than their Inconstant affections.

sp.speaker: Madamoiselle Esperance.
sp.p: Pray be confident, that I shall have a greater care of your Honour, than of my own Life.

sp.speaker: 1 GEntleman.
sp.p: The Lady Natures three Daughters, namely Wit, Beauty, and Love, are the sweetest, and most Virtuous Ladies in the VVorld.

sp.speaker: 2 Gentleman.
sp.p: I have heard so much of their fame, as I have a great desire to see them.

sp.speaker: 1 Gentleman.
sp.p: You may see the Lady VVit, for she doth discourse often in publick; but for the other two Sisters, they are somewhat more retired.

sp.speaker: 2 Gentleman.
sp.p: How shall we know the time, that the Lady VVit discourses in publick?

sp.speaker: 1 Gentleman.
sp.p: I am now going to see if I can get a place, where I may

sp.speaker: 2 Gentleman.
sp.p: I will go with you, if you will give me leave.

sp.speaker: 1 Gentleman.
sp.p: VVith all my Heart.

div.head: Scene 4.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Nobilissimo, and Monsieur Poverty.

sp.speaker: MOnsieur Poverty.
sp.p: My Noble Lord, I am a Gentleman, one that is ruin'd by Fortunes spight, and not by my own Carelesness, Vanity, Luxury, or Prodigality; for my Poverty is honest: but though my Poverty hath an honest face, yet it is ashamed to appear in the open sight of publick knowledg, which makes me whisper my wants to your Lordships private Ear.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Nobilissimo.
sp.p: Sir, if your necessities can conceal themselves, they shall never be divulged by me; and what I can honestly give you out of my Estate, and not very imprudently from my self, I shall freely, and secretly, distribute to you, and such as are in your condition.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Poverty.
sp.p: Your Lordships Servant.

sp.speaker: MAdamoiselle Amor.
sp.p: The mind is the best Tutor, and ought to instruct the Senses how to choose; for the Senses are but as the working Labourers, to bring Lifes materials in; but O my Senses have betrayed my mind, in bringing through my Ears, and Eyes, Beauty, and VVit, which like as creeping Serpents, got passage to my heart, and winding round about with flattering imbraces, yet sting the peace, and quiet of my mind, raising therein blisters of discontent, causing an anguish of restless thoughts, which work, and beat like pulsive pa â€¢ n.
sp.l: But O had I been born both Deaf and Blind,
Then might I scape this Hell tormenting mind;
His Wit like various Musick pierc'd my Ear,
Some being solemn, and some pleasant were
And when he spake, his person did appear
Like to the Sun, when no dark Clouds were neer;
Fame of his valour, like a trumpet sound,
Through Ears from Heart, unto the Eyes rebound;
And then his person, like Mars did appear,
Yet so, as when fair Venus Queen was neer.
O Love forbear, use not this cruelty,
Either bind him, or give me liberty.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Adresser.
sp.p: VVhat are you all alone sweet Mistriss?

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: No Sir, I have the Company of thoughts.

sp.speaker: Adresser.
sp.p: Those are Melancholy Companions.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Indeed mine are so at this time; yet thoughts with thoughts may discourse wittily, and converse pleasantly together, without articulate words.

sp.speaker: Adresser.
sp.p: Certainly your thoughts must needs be pleasant, your words are so witty.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: No truly, for my thoughts lie in my brain like a Chaos in a confused heap, and my brain being young, hath not enough natural heat to disgest them into a Methodical order; neither hath Time cookt them ready for the Mind to dish out, or the Tongue to carry to the Ears of the hearers.

sp.speaker: Adresser.
sp.p: The oftner I hear, and see you, the more I wonder at you.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Why, I hope Sir I am no Monster?

sp.speaker: Adresser.
sp.p: No, for you seem to me something divine.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Then you should rather admire me: for Admiration proceeds from things excellent, Wonder from things strange and unusuall.

sp.speaker: Adresser.
sp.p: So you are strange, and unusal: for things divine are not common; and certainly you are a thing illuminated beyond Natures Art, and are the only delight of Mankind.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Men take no worldly delight in Coelestial Creatures, but with Earthly; wherefore the most refined and illuminated, is oftenest rejected.

sp.speaker: Adresser.
sp.p: No Lady, they are not rejected, but as Angels, they will not reside with us.

sp.speaker: Amor.
sp.p: Sir, for fear I should lose the Angelical opinion you have of me, I will depart soon as Angels do.

div.head: Scene 6.
div.stage: Enter Madamoiselle Detractor, Madamoiselle Spightfull, Madamoiselle Malicious, and Madamoiselle Tell-truth.

sp.speaker: TEll-truth.
sp.p: Come, will you go to hear the Lady Wit discourse?

sp.speaker: Spightfull.
sp.p: Not I.

sp.speaker: Tell-truth.
sp.p: Will you go?

sp.speaker: Detractor.
sp.p: I will not go to hear a prating preaching woman.

sp.speaker: Malicious.
sp.p: O that all the Masculine Sex would say as much.

sp.speaker: Tell-truth.
sp.p: Let us go to learn Wit.

sp.speaker: Spightfull.
sp.p: I had rather be a Dunce all my Life.

sp.speaker: Detractor.
sp.p: So had I, if I must have none but a Woman instructor.

sp.speaker: Malicious.
sp.p: Indeed women should learn, not teach.

sp.speaker: Detractor.
sp.p: It's a sign Men want VVit, when they go to hear a VVoman preach.

sp.speaker: Spightfull.
sp.p: But let us go, if it be but to censure; for an hundred to one, but she will say something which may be contradicted.

sp.speaker: Malicious.
sp.p: Then let us agree to be her contradictors: for whatsoever she saith we will confute.

sp.speaker: Tell-truth.
sp.p: Nay by your favour, that you cannot do; for though you may contradict any argument, yet not confute it: for though Envy and Spight have bred Sophistry, yet Envy and Spight cannot confute the Truth.

sp.speaker: Spightfull.
sp.p: Well, let us go howsoever, if it be but to see, and be seen of those men as will be there to hear her.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: Content.

div.head: Scene 7.
div.stage: Enter Madamoiselle Grand Esprit, and her Audience. She takes her place, and then speaks.

sp.speaker: GRand Esprit.
sp.l: Great Fortune, I at this time do implore,
That thou wilt open every hearing door,
Which are the Ears: let not my Wit be lost,
For want of bearing, nor my words be crost,
Nor yet destructed by a busling noise,
Or gazing, or observing some light toyes:
But let their Ears be sixt, as if their sight
Did view my words, till on their Ears they light.
sp.p: I shall take my discourse at this time out of Ignorance, which discourse, I shall divide into Five Parts, the Gods, Fates, Nature, the VVorld, and Man; for although Ignorance be obscure, and hard to be discovered, yet it is printed in a general Language, being spread and communicated over all the VVorld. I begin with the First, and prime Creature, Ignorant Man. Man takes himself to be the most knowing Creature, for which he hath placed himself next to the Gods; yet Man is ignorant: for what Man is, or ever was created, that knows what the Gods are, or how many there are? Or what power they have, or where they reside? What Man did ever know the Mansions of Glory, the Bowers of bliss, or the Fields of pleasure? What Man ever knew whether the Gods were Eternal, or bred out of infinite, or rule, or govern, infinite Eternally?

Secondly the Fates. What Man is, or ever was, that knows the Fates? As whether they are Gods or Creatures, or whether the Fates are limited, or decree as they please? Or what Man is, or ever was, that knows the decrees of Fate, the links of Destiny, or the chance of Fortune, or the lots of Chance.

Thirdly. What Man is, or ever was, that knows what Nature is, or from whence her power proceeds? As whether from the Gods, or Eternity, or infinite, or from the Fates? Or whether the Gods, or Fates, proceed from her? Or what at first set her to work? Or whether her work is prescribed, or limited? Or of what she works on? Or what instruments she worketh with? Or to what end she works for? Or whether she shall desist from working, or shall work Eternally? Or whether she worked from all Eternity? Or whether her work had a beginning, or shall have an ending? What Man knows the beginning of Motion, or the Fountain of Knowledge, or the Spring of Life, or Gulph of Death? Or what Life is? Or what Death is? Or whether Life, Motion, and Death, had a beginning, or shall have an ending?
Fourthly the World. VVhat Man is, or ever was, that knows how the VVorld was made? Or for what it is made? Or by whom it was made? Or whether it had beginning, or shall have end?

The Fift and last is Man. VVhat Man is, or ever was, that knows how he was formed, or of what composition, or what is that he calls a Rational Soul? VVhether it is imbodyed, or not imbodyed? VVhether it is Divine, or Mortal? VVhether it proceeds from the Gods, or was created by Nature? VVhether it shall live for ever, or shall have a period? VVhether it shall live in Knowledge, or ly in Ignorance? VVhether it be capable of pain, or pleasure? VVhether it shall have a residing place, or no certain place assigned? Or if it have none, where it shall wander? Or if it have, where that residing place is.

As for the Body, who knows the perfect Sense of each Sense, or what mistake, or illusions, each Sense is apt to make, or give, or take? VVhat Man knows how the Body dissolves, or to what it shall dissolve? VVhat Man knows whether there be Sense in Death, or not? VVhat Man knows the motion of the thoughts, or whether the thoughts belong only to the Soul, or only to the Body, or partly to both, or of neither? VVhat Man is there that knows strength of passion? As what Faith may beget? Or what Doubts may dissolve? Or what Hopes may unite? Or what Fears may disorder? Or what Love can suffer? Or what Hate can act?

VVhat Man is there that knows the Circumpherence of Admiration, the rigour of Adoration, the hight of Ambition, or the bottom of Covetousness? Or what Man knows the end of Sorrow, or beginning of Joy? And as for the Appetites, what Man knows the length and bredth of desire? As for the Senses, what Man is there, that knows the true Sense of Pleasure, or the uttermost bounds of Pain? VVho can number the varieties of Tast, Sent, Touch, Sound, and Sight? VVhat Man knows the perfect effects of each Sense? Or what Man is there that knows any thing, truly as it is? Yet certainly there cannot be an Athest; for though men may be so irrelligious, as to be of no Religion; yet their can be none so willfull, and utterly void of all Sense, and Reason, as not to believe there is a God; for though we have not the true light of knowledge, yet we have as it were a perpetual twilight; Man lives as at the poles of knowledge; for though we cannot say it is truly day, yet it is not night. Man may perceive an Infinite power, by the perfect distinctions of all particular varieties, by the orderly production of several Creatures, and by the fit, and proper shapes of every several kind of Creature; by their orderly Births, by the times and Seasons, to produce, flourish, and decay; by the distinct degrees, qualities, properties, places and
motions of all things, and to, and in every thing, by the exact form of this VVorld; by the prudent seperations, and situations of the Heavens and Earth; by the Circumferent lines, and poyzing Centers; by their bounds and limits; by their orderly, and timely motions; by their assigned tracts, constant Journies, convenient distances; by their intermixing, and well tempering of the Elements; by the profitable Commerce, betwixt the Heavens and the Earth; by the different kinds, several sorts, various Natures, numerous numbers of Creatures; by their passions, humours, appetites; by their Sympathies, and Antipathies; by their warrs and parties; by the Harmony that is made out of discord, shews that there is onely one absolute power, and wise disposer, that cannot be opposed, having no Copartners, produces all things, being not produced by any thing, wherefore must be Eternall, and consequently infinite; this absolute, wise, and Eternal power Man calls God; but this absolute power, being infinite, he must of necessity be incomprehensible, and being incomprehensible, must of necessity be unknown, yet glimses of his power is, or may be seen; yet not so, but that Man is forced to set up Candels of Faith, to light them, or direct them to that they cannot perfectly know, and for want of the clear light of knowledge, Man calls all Creations of this mighty power Nature; his wise decrees, Man calls Fates; his pointed will, Man calls Destiny; his several Changes, Man calls Fortune; his Intermixing Man calls Life; his seperating, Man calls Death; the Sympathetical, and Antipathetical motions of the Senses, and their Objects, Humours, and their Subjects, Man calls Pleasure, and Pain; the interchanging motions in Man, Men call Sense, and Knowledge; the seperating motions, Man calls Ignorance, Stupidity, and Insensibility; my application is, that this absolute Power, wise Disposer, and decreeing Creator, hath created himself Worship, in making Creatures to worship him; and it is probable, Truth decreed Judgment, Punishment, and Bliss, to such of his Creatures as shall omit, or submit thereunto: my exhoration to you is, to bough humbly, to pray constantly, to implore servently, to love truly, to live awfully to the worship of this incomprehensible power; that you may injoy bliss and avoid torment.

div.head: Scene 8.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur NObilissimo, and three or four Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: I wonder who brought up that careless fashion, to go without their Swords; and I wonder more, how gallant valiant men, came to follow that fashion; for a Sword is a valiant mans trusty friend, to whose protection, he delivers his Honour, his Safety, and his Peace; for a Sword is a Mans Guardian, to maintain his Right, to revenge his Wrongs, or Disgraces, and his Mistriss, for whole service he wears his Life, and studies the worth and use thereof, and takes delight in the Honourable, and allowable practices therein.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: Faith my Lord I believe it was some Lover that brought up that fashion, who was loath to affright his Mistriss, with so dangerous a weapon.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Some Carpet Knight upon my life my Lord.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: It was no true Lover; for certainly he would be sure to provide a safeguard, lest his Mistriss might be taken from him, or lest he should be affronted in her sight, which a Man of Honour, and a true Lover, will rather dy than part or suffer; and as for my part, I commend the Man that would neither eat, drink, nor sleep, without his Sword were by him, and made it his Bedfellow, and Bord Companion; as a friend that held to his side, and would sight in his quarrell.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: My Lord, if a man should do so in these times, his Neighbours would say it was out of fear, not courage.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: O no, for a Coward is affraid to use a Sword, and a Valiant man is affraid to be without the use, otherwise a strong sturdy Clown, might cuff him down, and kick him like a Football on the ground, which a Sword, and skill to use it, will prevent; for a Clown hath not skill to defend, or assault a Sword, having no practice therewith, nor ought they to have; for the use of this kind of Arms makes a Clown a Gentleman, and the want of skill makes a Gentleman a Clown; for a Right bred Gentleman, is to know the use of the Sword, and it is more manly to assault, than to defend; also to know how to mannage Horses, whereby we know how to assault our Enemy as well as to defend our selves; for it is not playing with a Fidle, and dancing a Measure, makes a Gentleman; for then Princes should dub Knighthood with a Fidle, and give the stick, and a pair of Pumps, insteed of a Sword, and a pair of Spurs.

sp.speaker: 1 Gent.
sp.p: My Lord, we are so far from wearing our Swords our selves now a dayes, as we give them our Footmen to carry, as if it were a disgrace to carry a Sword our selves.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: Tis true, and we are well beaten for our follies, for disarming our selves, and arming our Slaves; for now a Groom is made a Gentlemans equal, nay his Superior sometimes; for if a Groom kills a Gentleman, the Gentleman dyes in disgrace, and the Groom lives with Honour, and gets the Fame of a gallant Person; for that is the phrase to all those that have fought, although they were forced thereto as Slaves, not distinguishing true valor, which is voluntary, temperate and just.

sp.speaker: 2 Gent.
sp.p: Why then there should be a Decree, of Law, that none should wear Swords but Gentlemen, nor Arms allowed, but to those of approved merit.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: You say right, unless in time of Forein Wars, and then there should be a difference in their Arms; for if there be no difference of Arms, no difference of persons, and if there be no difference of persons, there will be no Supremacy of Power, if no Supremacy, no Royal Government; for as the Sword maintains the Prerogative of the Crown, so it doth the Honour of a Gentleman; and as the Sword keeps up the dignity of the Crown, so a Sword keeps up the Heraldry of a Gentleman; and no man ought to be accounted a Gentleman, that knows not how to use his Sword, and manage his Horse; for the one defends himself, and kills his Enemies; the other, doth front and charge his Enemy, and pursues him if need require.

div.head: Scene 9.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Esperance, and Madamoiselle Esperance his Wife.

sp.speaker: MOnsieur Esperance.
sp.p: Lord Wife you are very brave to day.

sp.speaker: Madamoiselle Esperance.
sp.p: I strive to be so every day.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Esperance.
sp.p: For whose sake.

sp.speaker: Madamoiselle Esperance.
sp.p: For yours.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Esperance.
sp.p: For mine? why sure that is not so, for certainly you would not take that pains, and bestow so much cost, for one you do enjoy allready, for a Husband that is tied to you for life, and cannot quit on Honourable terms; wherefore it is for one is loose and free, which you do strive by setting forth your self with garments rich, for to attract, and draw to your desires.

sp.speaker: Madamoiselle Esperance.
sp.p: The Circumference of my desires is only your delight.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Esperance.
sp.p: Why, my delight is in your Virtue, youth, and Beauty, not in your Cloathes.

sp.speaker: Madamoiselle Esperance.
sp.p: But Virtue is best acceptable, when Beauty doth present it; and Beauty finds most favour, when well attired; but were I sure you would like me better in mean Garments, and careless dresses, I then should Cloath my self in Freez, & like a Hermit my loose course Garments ty with single cord about my waste; but I will go and pull these Cloaths off, since they are thought a crime, and I thought false for wearing them.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Esperance.
sp.p: No, I like them very well, if I were sure they were worn only for love to me.

sp.speaker: Madamoiselle Esperance.
sp.p: I never gave you cause to think I wear them for the love of any other.

div.head: Scene 10.
div.stage: Enter Madamoiselle Spightfull, Madamoiselle Detractor, Madamoiselle Malicious, and Madamoiselle Tell-truth.

sp.speaker: SPightfull
sp.p: Madamoiselle La Belle is cryed up to be the only Beauty in the Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Malicious.
sp.p: Lord that is nothing, for sometimes opinion will carry a black Blowse up to Fames high Tower.

sp.speaker: Spightfull.
sp.p: Yes faith, and most commonly they are cast down in disgrace.

sp.speaker: Detractor.
sp.p:
Why should she be cryed up so? for she is neither well featured, nor well shaped, nor well fashioned, nor well drest, nor well bred, nor good natured; for she is of a brown Complexion, a heavy Eye, a sad Countenance, a lazy Garb; she dresses Phantastically, speaks Childishly,
looks shamefastly; she is proud, reserved, coy, disdainfull, and self-conceited.

sp.speaker: Tell-truth.
sp.p: Let me tell you, it is reported that she hath most lovely features, a clear Complexion, a modest Countenance, a bashfull Eye, a pleasing Speech, a winning behaviour, a Majesticall presence; besides it is reported that her disposition is civil, courteous, and obliging, her Nature sweet and gentle, her Education virtuous, her life temperate and Chast, her actions noble and wise, her discourse witty and delighful.

sp.speaker: Spightfull.
sp.p: Hey day, hey day, good Mistriss Tell-truth run not so fast in the wayes of vain Reports, lest your judgment fail into a Quagmire.

sp.speaker: Malicious.
sp.p: Monsieur Phantasie, tis said you are one of Madamoiselle La Belles admirers.

sp.speaker: Phantasie.
sp.p: All the World would admire her, if they saw her, she is so Heavenly a Creature.

sp.speaker: Spightfull.
sp.p: If she be so Heavenly a Creature, she would be known to the whole World by the splendor of her Beams.

sp.speaker: Phantasie.
sp.p: Heaven is not made known to all; neither can the gloryes be suddenly comprehended, by weak Mortals.

sp.speaker: Detractor.
sp.p: Good Lord, if she hath such an infinite Beauty, that it cannot be comprehended, it is obscure.

sp.speaker: Phantasie.
sp.p: But those that comprehend least will be astonish'd, and struck with deep amaze.

sp.speaker: Detractor.
sp.p: I believe you are struck with Love, which makes you Blind, or Mad, that makes you think you see your own imaginations: wherefore fare you well, untill you are sober.

sp.speaker: Phantasie.
sp.p: I am struck indeed, for I am wonded deeper than Swords can pierce, or Bullets shoot at.

div.head: Scene 11.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Nobilissimo, and many Gentlemen with him.

sp.speaker: 1 GEntleman.
sp.p: Your Lordship rid to day beyond Perseus on his Pegasus.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: No Monsieur, he went (if Poets speak truth) in higher Capreols than ever I shall make my Horse go.

sp.speaker: 2 Gentleman.
sp.p: He might go higher my Lord, but never keep so just a time, and place, as to pitch from whence he riss, his feet in the same Circle, his leggs in the same lines, and your Lordship in the same Center.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: The truth is, my Horses went well to day; they were like Musical Instruments, fitly strung, and justly tun'd.

sp.speaker: 3 Gentleman.
sp.p: And your Lordship, like a skillfull Musician, played rarely thereon.

sp.speaker: Nobilissimo.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, let us to Dinner, for I have uncivilly tyred your Stomacks with a long fast.

div.head: Scene 12.
div.stage: Enter Monsieur Phantasie as in a muse, sometimes Sighing, sometimes strikes his Brest, and sometimes turns up his Eyes; and at these postures Enters Madamoiselle Bon, at her approach he starts.

sp.speaker: MAdamoiselle Bon.
sp.p: Sir, you may very well start to see me here, I do not use modesty, pardon me to be so bold to visit Men; it is the first visit I ever made your Sex, and hope it will be the last, but I am come, since neither Letter, nor Messenger, could have access to be resolved by your own Confession, whether you have forsaken me or not.

sp.speaker: Phantasie.
sp.p: No, I have not forsaken you.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: But your affection prefers another before me.

sp.speaker: Phantasie.
sp.p: If I should say I did not, I should belly Truth, which baseness I abhor.

sp.speaker: Bon.
sp.p: I am glad for your own sake you keep so much Honour, though sorry, that you are no constanter, and more sorry for the Oaths you took, and Vows you made to me, since they became the witnesses of your perjury. I was not suddenly, nor easily brought to draw a Supreme Love to one; for before such time my Love was placed on you, my affections run equally in purling Brooks of Pitty, and Compassion, and clear fresh Rivulets of Charity and Humanity, from the pure Springs of good Nature and Religion; and hard it will be for me to turn this River to each stream again, if not, yet I shall be a rest, 'twill overflow my heart and drown me.

sp.speaker: Monsieur Phantasie.
sp.p: Oh I must curse my Fortune, and my Fate; lament my own condition to love without return, and only pitty what I loved most.

div.head: Scene 13.
div.stage: Enter Madamoiselle Grand Esprit, and her Audience.

sp.speaker: GRand Esprit.
sp.l: Great Mercury to thee I now address,
Imploy thy favour, help me in distress;
Thou God of Eloquence, so guide my tongue,
Let all my words on even sense be slrung,
And let my Speech be tun'd to every Ear,
That every Ear each several word may hear:
That every passion may in measure move,
And let the figure of the Dance be Love.
sp.p:
I will discourse at this time of Love, not of the superfluous Branches, or wither'd leaves, or rotten fruits, but of the Root of Love, which is Self-love; It is the Root and Original Love in Nature; it is the Foundation of Nature, it is the Fountain from whence issues all the several Springs; Self-love was the cause of the Worlds Creation; for the Gods out of love to themselves, caused Creatures to be Created, to worship them: thus all Creatures being created out of self-love, and their chief being proceeding out of self-love, is the cause that every particular Creature loves themselves in the first place, and what Love is placed on any other, or to any other, from any particular, is derived from self-love; for we love the Gods but out of self-love, as believing the Gods love us; we adore the Gods but out of self-love, because we think we proceed from them, or were produced by their commands; we pray to the Gods but out of self-love, because we hope the Gods will help us in distress; we bless the Gods but out of self-love, because we do verrily believe the Gods will exalt, and Crown us with everlasting glory; and to shew that we Love the Gods, not as they are Gods, but for our own sakes, as believing they will or can do us good, is, that we are apt to murmure at the Gods, when we have not our own desires; we are apt to accuse the Gods, when any wordly thing crosses us; we are apt to curse the Gods at ill Accidents, Misfortunes, or Natural losses; we are apt to forget the Gods in the midst of pleasure; we are apt to think our selves Gods in the pride of prosperity; we strive to make our selves Gods in the hight of worldly power; and we do not only strive to make our selves equal with the Gods, but to raise our selves above the Gods, taking, or commanding to our selves more worship than we give unto the Gods; nay, those that are accounted the most holy and devout Servants of the Gods, belie the Gods, taking the name of the Gods to cover their own follies; as for example, whensoever any eminent person hath had ill success, either in, or after their Foolish, Ambitious, and Vain-glorious actions, they charge the Gods Decrees and pleasure, as it was the Gods will it should be so; like as she that Vaingloriously had her two and only Sons to draw her Chariot, like two Horses, or Dogs, or Slaves, and being both found Dead the next day, she had prayed to the Gods to reward them with that which was best for them, and being both dead, she said the Gods accounted Death as the best reward, when they no doubt dyed with over heating themselves, striving beyond
their natural power and strength; yet these two Sonns that drew the vain Mother in a Chariot, drew and died out of self-love; either like as vain Sonns like their vain Mother, vaingloriously to get a fame, or believing the Gods would reward them for their Act, either with extraordinary prosperity, power, or blessedness in the Life to come; and many the like examples may be given; for how ordinary is it in these our times, and in former times, for the politicks to perswade the people, with promises from the Gods, or to tell them it is the Gods commands they should do such and such acts, even such acts as are unnatural, wicked, and most horrid? thus Men bely the Gods to abuse their fellow Creatures. But most Noble and Right Honourable, my explanation of this discourse is, that since Self-love is the Fountain of and in Nature from whence issue out several Springs to every several Creature, wherein Mankind being her chiefest and Supreme work, is filled with the fullest Springs from that Fountain, which is the cause that Mankind is more industrious, cruel, and unsatiable, to and for his self ends, than any other Creature, he spares nothing that he hath power to destroy, if he fears any hurt, or hopes for any gain, or finds any pleasure, or can make any sport, or to imploy his idle time; he melts metalls, distills and dissolves plants, dissects animals, substracts and extracts Elements, he digs up the bowels of the Earth, cuts through the Ocean of the Sea, gathers the winds into Sails, fresh waters into Mills, and imprisons the thinner Ayre;
